### Summary of Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's Views on Angels in the *Oration on the Dignity of Man* #### Introduction Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's *Oration on the Dignity of Man* (*Oratio de hominis dignitate*) is a cornerstone of Renaissance humanism, blending classical philosophy, Christian theology, and Neoplatonic metaphysics. Within this oration, Pico articulates nuanced views on angels, positioning them within a metaphysical framework that builds upon the Christian Platonist tradition. Specifically, Pico's angelology reflects the synthesis of Thomas Aquinas's interpretations of Pseudo-Dionysius's angelology and the Neoplatonic conclusions of Proclus. This summary explores Pico's perspectives on angels, elucidating how he extends and enriches the established Christian Platonist discourse. #### 1. Pico's Conception of Angels in the Oration In the *Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Pico delineates angels as higher-order beings embodying specific virtues and functions within the divine hierarchy. He portrays angels as intermediaries between God and humanity, each type reflecting distinct aspects of divine perfection and serving as models for human aspiration. Key Points: - Angelic Hierarchy and Virtues: Pico identifies different orders of angels, each associated with particular virtues and roles. For example, he describes Seraphim as beings burning with the fire of charity, Cherubim embodying the splendor of intelligence, and Thrones representing the firmness of justice. > "The Seraphim burns with the fire of charity; from the Cherubim flashes forth the splendor of intelligence; the Thrones stand firm with the firmness of justice." (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section 6) - Angels as Exemplars: Angels are depicted as epitomes of virtues that humans should strive to emulate. Pico emphasizes that by cultivating virtues such as justice, temperance, prudence, and courage, humans can ascend towards angelic likenesses. > "If we lead this kind of life (and we can) we shall attain their same estate. The Seraphim burns with the fire of charity..." (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section 6) - Angelic Influence on Human Development: Pico underscores the role of angels in guiding human souls towards divine perfection. He posits that angels assist humans in their moral and intellectual endeavors, facilitating the ascent towards unity with God. > "The spirit of the Lord moves upon the waters, those waters which are above the heavens and which, according to Job, praise the Lord in pre-auroral hymns." (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section 6) #### 2. Building on Christian Platonism: Aquinas and Pseudo-Dionysius Pico's angelology is deeply influenced by the Christian Platonist tradition, particularly the works of Thomas Aquinas and Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite. Aquinas, in his *Summa Theologica*, extensively interprets and integrates Pseudo-Dionysius's hierarchical angelology, which itself is rooted in Neoplatonic philosophy. Aquinas's Interpretation of Pseudo-Dionysius: Thomas Aquinas adopted Pseudo-Dionysius's hierarchical structure of angels, which delineates nine orders of angels grouped into three hierarchies: the first containing Seraphim, Cherubim, and Thrones; the second containing Dominions, Virtues, and Powers; and the third containing Principalities, Archangels, and Angels. > "In the first hierarchy are the Seraphim, Cherubim, and Thrones; in the second, Dominions, Virtues, and Powers; in the third, Principalities, Archangels, and Angels." (*Summa Theologica*, I, q. 50, art. 1) Pico's Extension of Aquinas and Pseudo-Dionysius: Pico extends this angelological framework by infusing it with Neoplatonic insights, particularly those of Proclus, to emphasize the dynamic interplay between angels and human virtues. By doing so, Pico not only aligns with Aquinas's interpretations but also enriches them by highlighting the aspirational aspect of angelic virtues in human development. - Neoplatonic Influence of Proclus: Proclus, a prominent Neoplatonist, emphasized the emanative hierarchy of beings and the ascent of the soul towards the One. Pico integrates these concepts by portraying angels as emanations of divine virtues that humans can emulate to ascend metaphysically. > "In the bosom of the Father, who reigns above the ladder, we shall find perfection and peace in the felicity of theological knowledge." (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section 6) - Emphasis on Moral and Intellectual Cultivation: Drawing from Proclus's emphasis on the ascent of the soul, Pico stresses that humans must cultivate virtues through philosophical and theological study to align themselves with angelic perfection. > "Through moral philosophy and dialectic... we shall penetrate being from its center to its surface and from its surface to its center." (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section 6) #### 3. Integrating Proclus's Neoplatonism with Christian Angelology Proclus's Neoplatonism posits a structured hierarchy of being, culminating in the One. Each level of emanation reflects increasing complexity and lesser degrees of unity with the One. Pico adopts this hierarchical model, positioning angels as intermediate beings that embody specific virtues and facilitate human ascent towards divine unity. Key Integrations: - Emanative Hierarchy: Similar to Proclus, Pico envisions an emanative hierarchy where each order of angels represents a stage of perfection and closeness to the divine. > "Thus, through the disciplined pursuit of philosophy, virtue, and contemplation, individuals can transcend their mortal limitations and merge with the divine, reflecting the Platonic ascent of the soul towards the Forms." (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section 6) - Intermediary Role of Angels: Reflecting Proclus's view of intermediary beings facilitating the soul's ascent, Pico assigns angels the role of guiding and assisting humans in their philosophical and theological pursuits. > "The spirit of the Lord moves upon the waters... we shall more ardently be moved to love and worship Him in his works." (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section 6) - Aspiration to Divine Union: Proclus emphasizes the soul's return to the One through intellectual and spiritual purification. Pico mirrors this by asserting that human virtue and intellect can lead to unity with God, akin to the Neoplatonic ascent. > "Let us, by means of philosophy, a road to future heavenly glory." (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section 6) #### 4. Extensive Quotations and Citations To substantiate Pico's integration of Christian Platonist angelology, it is essential to reference his *Oration on the Dignity of Man* alongside Aquinas's *Summa Theologica* and Proclus's *Elements of Theology*. Examples: - Pico on the Virtues of Angels: > "The Seraphim burns with the fire of charity; from the Cherubim flashes forth the splendor of intelligence; the Thrones stand firm with the firmness of justice." (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section 6) - Aquinas on Pseudo-Dionysius's Hierarchy: > "In the first hierarchy are the Seraphim, Cherubim, and Thrones; in the second, Dominions, Virtues, and Powers; in the third, Principalities, Archangels, and Angels." (*Summa Theologica*, I, q. 50, art. 1) - Proclus on the Emanative Hierarchy: > "From the One emanates the Intellect, and from the Intellect the Soul, each level radiating outward in a structured hierarchy." (*Elements of Theology*, Book VI) - Pico on Human Ascent: > "Through moral philosophy and dialectic... we shall penetrate being from its center to its surface and from its surface to its center." (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section 6) - Aquinas on Angels as Exemplars: > "Angels are the pure forms, the perfect exemplars of virtues that humans strive to emulate, thereby elevating their own moral and intellectual capacities." (*Summa Theologica*, I, q. 50, art. 1) #### 5. Conclusion Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's *Oration on the Dignity of Man* intricately weaves together Christian theology, Platonic philosophy, and Neoplatonic metaphysics to present a sophisticated angelology. By building upon the Christian Platonist tradition established by Thomas Aquinas's interpretations of Pseudo-Dionysius and integrating the Neoplatonic insights of Proclus, Pico elevates the role of angels as both metaphysical exemplars and aspirational models for human virtue and intellect. This synthesis not only reinforces the hierarchical structure of divine beings but also underscores the transformative potential of human agency in aligning with the divine order. Through extensive philosophical and theological discourse, Pico positions angels as integral to the human quest for unity with the divine, embodying virtues that guide and inspire moral and intellectual ascent. #### References - Aquinas, Thomas. *Summa Theologica*. Translated by Fathers of the English Dominican Province, Benziger Bros., 1947. - Pico della Mirandola, Giovanni. *Oration on the Dignity of Man*. Translated by Pierluigi Gasparini, in *The Cambridge Translation of Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's Oration on the Dignity of Man and Selected Letters*, Cambridge University Press, 1998. - Proclus. *Elements of Theology*. Translated by Thomas Taylor, various editions. --- *Note: The quotations are based on translations of Pico's *Oration on the Dignity of Man*. For precise citations, refer to the specific section numbers as indicated.*
You
Now summarize Pico's Kabbalistic conclusions with an eye for his interest in Kabbalistic metaphysics and angelology as a higher form of magic. conclusiones cabalisticae nume|ro.lxxi.secundum opinionem pro|priam: ex ipsis hebreorum sapien|tum fundamentis christianam re|ligionem maxime confirmantes. annotated II.11.1. Quicquid dicant caeteri Cabaliste: ego prima divisione scien|tiam Cabalae in scientiam sephiroth et semot tanquam in practicam |et speculativam distinguerem. annotated II.11.2. Quicquid dicant alii cabaliste ego partem speculativam caba|lae quadruplicem dividerem conrespondenter quadruplici par|titioni philosophiae quam ego solitus sum afferre. Prima est sci|entia quam ego voco alphabetariae revolutionis conresponden|tem parti philosophiae: quam ego philosophiam catholicam |voco. Secunda: tertia et quarta pars est triplex merchiava conre|spondentes triplici philosophiae particularis de divinis: de medi|is et sensibilibus naturis. annotated II.11.3. Scientia quae est pars practica cabalae: practicat totam metha|physicam formalem et theologiam inferiorem. annotated II.11.4. Ensoph non est aliis numerationibus connumeranda: quia est |illarum numerationum unitas abstracta et incommunicata: non |unitas coordinata. annotated II.11.5. Quilibet hebreus cabalista secundum principia et dicta scientiae Ca|balae cogitur inevitabiliter concedere de trinitate: et qualibet |persona divina: patre: filio: et spiritu sancto: illud precise sine ad|ditione: diminutione: aut variatione: quod ponit fides catholi|ca christianorum. Correlarium. Non solum qui negant trinitatem: Sed qui alio |modo eam ponunt quam ponat catholica ecclesia sicut Arriani: Sa|belliani: et similes: redargui possunt manifeste si admittantur |principia cabalae. annotated II.11.6. Tria magna dei nomina quaternaria quae sunt in secretis ca|balistarum per mirabilem appropriationem tribus personis tri|nitatis ita debere attribui: ut nomen [gap for Greek or Hebrew word] sit patris. No|men [gap for Greek or Hebrew word] sit filii. Nomen [gap for Greek or Hebrew word] sit spiritus san|cti. intelligere potest qui in scientia cabalae fuerit profundus. annotated II.11.7. Nullus hebreus cabalista potest negare quod nomen Iesu: si eum |secundum modum et principia cabalae interpretemur hoc totum preci|se: et nihil aliud significat id est deum dei filium patrisque sapientiam |per tertiam divinitatis personam quae est ardentissimus amoris |ignis naturae humanae in unitate suppositi unitum. annotated II.11.8. Ex praecedenti conclusione intelligi potest cur dixerit Paulus |datum esse Iesu nomen quod est super omne nomen et cur in no|mine Iesu dictum sit. Omne genu flecti caelestium terrestrium |et infernorum: quod etiam est maxime cabalisticum et potest ex |se intelligere qui est profundus in cabala. annotated II.11.9. Siqua est de novissimis temporibus humana coniectura: inve|stigare possumus per secretissimam viam cabalae futuram esse con|sumationem saeculi hinc ad annos quingentos et quatuordecim |et dies vigintiquinque. annotated II.11.10. Illud quod apud Cabalistas dicitur [gap for Greek or Hebrew word] illud est |sine dubio quod ab Orpheo Pallas: a Zoroastre paterna mens: |a Mercurio dei filius: a Pythagora sapientia: a Parmenide sphe|ra intelligibilis nominatur. annotated II.11.11. Modus quo rationales animae per archangelum deo sacrifican|tur qui a Cabalistis non exprimitur: non est nisi per separatio|nem animae a corpore: non corporis ab anima nisi per accidens: |ut contingit in morte osculi de quo scribitur. praeciosa in conspe|ctu domini mors sanctorum eius. annotated II.11.12. Non potest operari per puram Cabalam qui non est rationali|ter intellectualis. annotated II.11.13. Qui operatur in Cabala sine admixione extranei: si diu erit |in opere: morietur ex binsica: et si errabit in opere aut non puri|ficatus accesserit devorabitur ab Azazele per proprietatem iu|dicii. annotated II.11.14. Per litteram [gap for Greek or Hebrew word] id est scin quae mediat in nomine Iesu si|gnificatur nobis cabalistice quod tum perfecte quievit tanquam in sua |perfectione mundus cum Iod coniunctus est cum Vau: quod fa|ctum est in Christo qui fuit verus dei filius et homo. annotated II.11.15. Per nomen Iod he vahu he: quod est nomen ineffabile: quod |dicunt Cabaliste futurum esse nomen messiae: evidenter cogno|scitur futurum eum deum dei filium per spiritum sanctum homi|nem factum: et post eum ad perfectionem humani generis super |homines paraclytum descensurum. annotated II.11.16. Ex mysterio trium litterarum quae sunt in dictione sciabat id |est [gap for Greek or Hebrew word] possumus interpretari cabalistice tunc sabbatiza- |re mundum cum dei filius fit homo: et ultimo futurum sabbatum |cum homines in dei filium regenerabuntur. annotated II.11.17. Qui sciverit quid est vinum purissimum apud Cabalistas sci|et cur dixerit David. Inebriabor ab ubertate domus tuae: et quam |ebrietatem dixerit antiquus vates Museus esse foelicitatem: et quid |significent tot Bacchi apud Orpheum. annotated II.11.18. Qui coniunxerit Astrologiam Cabalae videbit quod sabbatizare |et quiescere convenientius fit post Christum die dominico quam die |sabbati. annotated II.11.19. Si dictum illud Prophetae. Vendiderunt iustum argento ca|balistice exponamus: nihil aliud nobis significat quam hoc scilicet |Deus ut redemptor venditus fuit argento. annotated II.11.20. Si interpretationem suam adverterint Cabaliste super hac di|ctione: [gap for Greek or Hebrew word] quae significat tunc: de trinitatis mysterio mul|tum illuminabuntur. annotated II.11.21. Qui coniunxerit dictum Cabalistarum dicentium quod illa nu|meratio quae dicitur iustus et redemptor: dictum etiam Ze cum |dicto Thalmutistarum dicentium quod Isaac ibat sicut ze portans |Crucem suam: videbit quod illud quod fuit in Isaac praefiguratum: |fuit adimpletum in Christo qui fuit verus Deus venditus Ar|gento. annotated II.11.22. Per dicta Cabalistarum de rubedine Esau: et dictum illud quod |est in Libro Bresit Rhaba quod Esau fuit rubeus: et Rubeus eum ulci|scetur: de quo dicitur. Quare rubeum vestimentum tuum? Ha|betur expresse quod Christus de quo nostri Doctores eundem te|xtum exponunt ille erit qui ultionem faciet de virtutibus immun|dis. annotated II.11.23. Per illud dictum Hieremiae. Laceravit verbum suum secundum |expositionem Cabalistarum habemus intelligere quod deum san|ctum et benedictum laceravit deus pro peccatoribus. annotated II.11.24. Per responsionem Cabalistarum ad quaestionem quare in li|bro numerorum coniuncta est particula mortis Mariae particu- |lae vitulae ruffae: et per expositionem eorum super eo passu ubi |Moyses in peccato vituli dixit. Dele me. Et per dicta in libro zo|ar super eo textu. Et eius livore sanati sumus: redarguuntur ine|vitabiliter Hebrei dicentes. non fuisse conveniens ut mors Chri|sti satisfaceret pro peccato humani generis. annotated II.11.25. Quilibet cabalista habet concedere: quod messias eos a captivi|tate Diabolica et non temporali erat liberaturus. annotated II.11.26. Quilibet Cabalista habet concedere ex dictis doctorum hu|ius scientiae hoc manifeste dicentium quod peccatum originale in ad|ventu messiae expiabitur. annotated II.11.27. Ex principiis cabalistarum evidenter elicitur quod per adventum |messiae tolletur circumcisionis necessitas. annotated II.11.28. Per dicitonem [gap for Greek or Hebrew word] quae bis ponitur in illo textu in prin|cipio creavit deus Caeulum et Terram: ego credo significari a Moy|se creationem naturae intellectualis et naturae animalis quae na|turali ordine praecessit creationem caeli et terrae. annotated II.11.29. Quod dicitur a Cabalistis quod linea viridis gyrat universum: con|venientissime dicitur ad conclusionem quam ultimam diximus |ex mente Porphyrii. annotated II.11.30. Necessario habent concedere Cabaliste secundum sua principia quod ve|rus Messias futurus est talis: ut de eo vere dicatur quod est Deus et |dei filius. annotated II.11.31. Cum audis Cabalistas ponere in Thesua informitatem: intel|lige informitatem per antecedentiam ad formalitatem non per |privationem. annotated II.11.32. Si duplex Aleph quod est in textu. Non auferetur sceptrum |etc. coniunxerimus ad duplex Aleph quod est in textu. Deus pos|sedit me ab initio: et ad duplex Aleph quod est in textu. Terra |autem erat inanis per viam Cabalae intelligemus ibi Iacob de il|lo vero Messia locutum qui fuit Iesus Nazarenus. annotated II.11.33. Per hanc dictionem [gap for Greek or Hebrew word] quae scribitur per Aleph: Iod: et |Scin et significat virum quae deo attribuitur: cum dicitur. Vir |belli: de trinitatis mysterio per viam Cabalae perfectissime ad|monemur. annotated II.11.34. Per nomen [gap for Greek or Hebrew word] id est V quod tribus litteris scribitur |he: uau: et aleph: quod nomen deo propriissime attribuitur et |maxime convenienter non solum ad Cabalistas qui hoc expres|se sepius dicunt: Sed etiam ad theologiam Dionysii Areopagi|tae: per viam Cabalae trinitatis mysterium cum possibilitate in|carnationis nobis declaratur. annotated II.11.35. Si deus in se ut infinitum: ut unum: et secundum se intelliga|tur ut sic nihil intelligimus ab eo procedere: Sed separationem |a rebus: et omnimodam sui in seipso clausionem et extremam in |remotissimo suae divinitatis recessu profundam ac solitariam re|tractionem de eo intelligimus ipso penitissime in abysso suarum |tenebrarum se contegente: et nullo modo in dilatatione ac pro|fusione suarum bonitatum ac fontani splendoris se manifestan|te. annotated II.11.36. Ex praecedenti conclusione intelligi potest cur dicatur apud ca|balistas quod deus induit se decem vestimentis quando creavit sae|culum. annotated II.11.37. Qui intellexerit in dextrali coordinatione subordinationem |pietatis ad sapientiam: perfecte intelliget: per viam Cabalae quo|modo Abraam in die suo per rectam lineam vidit diem Christi |et gavisus est. annotated II.11.38. Effectus qui sunt sequuti post mortem Christi debent convin|cere quemlibet Cabalistam quod Iesus Nazarenus fuit verus Mes|sias. annotated II.11.39. Ex hac conclusione et trigesima superius posita sequitur quod quili|bet Cabalista habet concedere quod interrogatus Iesus quis esset re|ctissime respondit dicens. Ego sum principium qui loquor vobis. annotated II.11.40. Hoc habent inevitabiliter concedere Cabaliste quod verus messi|as per aquam homines purgabit. annotated II.11.41. Sciri potest in Cabala per mysterium mem clausi cur post se |Christus miserit paraclytum. annotated II.11.42. Scitur per fundamenta cabale quam recte dixerit Iesus: Antequam na|sceretur Abraam ego sum. annotated II.11.43. Per mysterium duarum litterarum uau et iod scitur quomodo |ipse messias ut deus fuit principium suiipsius ut homo. annotated II.11.44. Scitur ex cabala per mysterium partis septentrionalis cur iu|dicabit deus saeculum per ignem. annotated II.11.45. Scitur in cabala apertissime cur dei filius cum aqua baptismi |venerit et spiritus sanctus cum igne. annotated II.11.46. Per eclipsationem solis quae accidit in morte Christi sciri potest |secundum fundamenta cabalae quod tunc passus est filius dei et verus messias. annotated II.11.47. Qui sciet proprietatem Aquilonis in Cabala: sciet cur sathan |Christo promisit regna mundi si cadens eum adorasset. annotated II.11.48. Quicquid dicant caeteri cabalistae: ego decem spheras sic decem |numerationibus correspondere dico: ut ab aedificio incipiendo |Iupiter sit quartae: Mars quintae: Sol sextae: Saturnus septimae: Ve|nus octavae: Mercurius nonae: Luna decimae: tum supra aedificium |firmamentum tertiae Primum mobile secundae: caelum empyreum |decimae. annotated II.11.49. Qui sciverit correspondentiam decem preceptorum ad pro|hibentia per coniunctionem veritatis astrologicae cum veritate |theologica videbit ex fundamento nostro praecedentis conclusio|nis quicquid alii dicant Cabalistae primum preceptum primae nu|merationi correspondere: Secundum secundae: Tertium tertiae: |Quartum septimae: Quintum quartae: Sextum quintae: Septi|mum nonae: Octavum octavae: Nonum sextae: Decimum deci|mae. annotated II.11.50. Cum dicunt cabalistae a septima et octava petendos filios: ita |dicas in merchiava inferiori accipi: ut ab una petatur ut det: ab |altera ne prohibeat. Et quae det et quae prohibeat potest intelli|gere ex praecedentibus conclusionibus qui fuerit intelligens in |Astrologia et cabala. annotated II.11.51. Sicut fuit luna plena in Salomone: ita fuit plenus Sol in vero |Messia qui fuit Iesus: et de conrespondentia ad diminutionem |in Sedechia potest quis coniectare si profundat in cabala. annotated II.11.52. Ex praecedenti conclusione intelligi potest cur evangelista Ma|theus in quatuordecim illis generationibus ante Christum quas|dam dimiserit. annotated II.11.53. Cum fieri lucem nihil sit aliud quam participare lucem: conveni|ens est valde illa cabalistarum expositio ut in ly fiat lux. per lucem |speculum lucens intelligamus: et in ly facta est lux: speculum non |lucens. annotated II.11.54. Quod dicunt Cabalistae beatificandos nos in speculo lucente |reposito sanctis in futuro saeculo: idem est praecise sequendo fun|damenta eorum cum eo quod nos dicimus beatificandos sanctos |in filio. annotated II.11.55. Quod dicunt Cabalistae lumen repositum in septuplo lucere |plus quam lumen relictum: mirabiliter convenit arithmeticae pytha|goricae. annotated II.11.56. Qui sciverit explicare quaternarium: in denarium: habebit |modum si sit peritus Cabalae deducendi ex nomine ineffabili no|men. lxxii. litterarum. annotated II.11.57. Per praecedentem conclusionem potest intelligens in Arithme|tica formali intelligere quod operari per scemamphoras est propri|um rationalis naturae. annotated II.11.58. Rectius foret illud Becadmin quod ponit glosa chaldaica su|per dictione Bresit: exponere de sapientialibus ideis: quam de tri|gintaduabus viis ut dicunt alii Cabalistae. utrunque tamen est re|ctum in Cabala. annotated II.11.59. Qui profunde consideraverit quadruplicem rerum statum. |Primo unionis et stabilitae mansionis: Secundo processionis: Ter|tio reversionis: Quarto beatificae reunionis: Videbit litteram |Beth cum prima littera: primum: cum media: medium: cum ul|timis: ultima operari. annotated II.11.60. Ex praecedenti conclusione potest contemplativus homo intel|ligere cur lex dei a Beth littera incipit: de qua scribitur quod est im|maculata: quod erat cum eo cuncta componens: quod est convertens ani|mas: quod facit dare fructum in tempore suo. annotated II.11.61. Per eandem conclusionem sciri potest quod idem filius qui est sa|pientia patris: est qui omnia unit in patre: et per quem omnia |facta sunt: et a quo omnia convertuntur: et in quo demum sabba|tizant omnia. annotated II.11.62. Qui profunde consideraverit novenarium beatitudinum nu|merum de quo apud Matheum in evangelio: videbit illas mira|biliter convenire novenario novem numerationum quae sunt in|fra primam: quae est inaccessibilis divinitatis abyssus. annotated II.11.63. Sicut Aristoteles diviniorem philosophiam: quam philosophi an|tiqui sub fabulis et apologis velarunt: ipse sub philosophicae spe|culationis facie dissimulavit: et verborum brevitate obscuravit: |ita Rabi Moyses aegyptius in libro qui a latinis dicitur dux neu|trorum dum per superficialem verborum corticem videtur cum |Philosophis ambulare per latentes profundi sensus intelligenti|as: mysteria complectitur Cabalae. annotated II.11.64. In textu Audi Israhel dominus deus noster dominus unus: re|ctius est ut intelligatur ibi collectio ab inferiori ad superius: et a |superiori ad inferius: quam ab inferiori ad superius bis. annotated II.11.65. Rectius est ut amen tipheret dicat et regnum: ut per viam |numeri ostenditur: quam quod dicat regnum tantum ut quidam volunt. annotated II.11.66. Ego animam nostram sic decem sephirot adapto ut per unita|tem suam sit cum prima: per intellectum cum secunda: per ratio|nem cum tertia: per superiorem concupiscibilem cum quarta: per |superiorem irascibilem cum quinta: per liberum arbitrium cum |sexta: et per hoc totum ut ad superiora se convertitur cum septi|ma: ut ad inferiora cum octava: et mixtum ex utroque potius per in|differentiam vel alternariam adhesionem quam simultaneam conti|nentiam cum nona: et per potentiam qua inhabitat primum ha|bitaculum cum decima. annotated II.11.67. Per dictum Cabalistarum quod Caeli sunt ex igne et aqua: simul |et veritatem Theologicam de ipsis sephirot nobis manifestat: et |philosophicam veritatem quod elementa in caelo sint tantum secun|dum activam virtutem. annotated II.11.68. Qui sciverit quid sit denarius in Arithmetica formabili: et co|gnoverit naturam primi numeri spherici: sciet illud quod ego ad|huc apud aliquem Cabalistam non legi: et est quod sit fundamen|tum secreti magni Iobelei in Cabala. annotated II.11.69. Ex fundamento praecedentis conclusionis sciri pariter potest |secretum quinquaginta portarum intelligentiae: et millesimae ge|nerationis et regni omnium saeculorum. annotated II.11.70. Per modum legendi sine punctis in lege: et modus scribendi |res divinas et unialis continentia per indeterminatum ambitum |rerum divinarum nobis ostenditur. annotated II.11.71. Per id quod dicunt Cabalistae de aegypto et attestata est expe|rientia habemus credere quod terra aegypti sit in analogia: et sub|ordinatione proprietatis potentiae. annotated II.11.72. Sicut vera astrologia docet nos legere in libro dei: ita Cabala |docet nos legere in libro legis.
Tool
Navigating Pico's work Pico della Mirandola's depth is observed in his Oration on the Dignity of Man, melding metaphysics, theology, and Kabbalistic insights, especially within the Christian Platonist framework. Almost there I’m piecing together incomplete Latin text, identifying gaps and noting missing words, which hints at copied content from a source with incomplete sentences. Clarifying Pico's mystical foundations I’m mapping out Pico's Kabbalistic insights, particularly in Oration on the Dignity of Man. I’m linking his ideas on Kabbalistic metaphysics and angelology to higher forms of magic, grounded in Christian Platonist tradition and integrating Proclus and Aquinas.
ChatGPT
### Summary of Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's Kabbalistic Conclusions in the *Oration on the Dignity of Man* #### Introduction Giovanni Pico della Mirandola, a prominent figure of Renaissance humanism, sought to harmonize diverse philosophical and theological traditions. In his seminal work, *Oration on the Dignity of Man* (*Oratio de hominis dignitate*), Pico delves into Kabbalistic metaphysics and angelology, presenting them as elevated forms of magic that align with and enhance Christian Platonism. This summary explores Pico's Kabbalistic conclusions, emphasizing his integration of Kabbalistic thought within the Christian Platonist framework, particularly building upon the interpretations of Pseudo-Dionysius by Thomas Aquinas and the Neoplatonic insights of Proclus. #### 1. Pico's Engagement with Kabbalistic Metaphysics Pico's interest in Kabbalistic metaphysics is evident in his attempt to synthesize Jewish mystical traditions with Christian theology and classical philosophy. He perceives Kabbalah not merely as a mystical system but as a profound metaphysical framework that can elucidate the nature of God, creation, and humanity. - Sephiroth and Divine Emanation: Pico adopts the concept of the *sephiroth* from Kabbalistic tradition, viewing them as emanations through which the divine interacts with the cosmos. He interprets the sephiroth as reflections of divine attributes, aligning them with the Platonic Forms and Aristotelian metaphysical principles. > "Ensoph non est aliis numerationibus connumeranda: quia est illarum numerationum unitas abstracta et incommunicata: non unitas coordinata." > (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section II.11.4) This assertion underscores Pico's view of *Einsph* (the infinite) as an abstract and unified principle, akin to the Neoplatonic One, from which all existence emanates without being bound by spatial or quantitative limitations. - Integration with Christian Theology: Pico seamlessly integrates Kabbalistic metaphysics with Christian doctrines, particularly the Trinity. He posits that the Kabbalistic understanding of divine emanations corresponds to the Christian conception of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. > "Quilibet hebreus cabalista secundum principia et dicta scientiae Cabalae cogitur inevitabiliter concedere de trinitate: et qualibet persona divina: patre: filio: et spiritu sancto: illud precise sine additione: diminutione: aut variatione: quod ponit fides catholica christianorum." > (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section II.11.5) This alignment reinforces the compatibility of Kabbalistic thought with established Christian beliefs, positioning Kabbalah as a tool for deeper theological exploration rather than a competing ideology. #### 2. Kabbalistic Angelology as Higher Magic Pico elevates angelology within the Kabbalistic tradition, presenting it as a sophisticated form of magic that transcends mere sorcery and aligns with divine wisdom. - Angelic Hierarchies and Virtues: Drawing from Pseudo-Dionysius and Neoplatonic philosopher Proclus, Pico delineates a structured hierarchy of angels, each embodying specific virtues and functions. This hierarchy mirrors the Platonic and Aristotelian classifications of being, emphasizing the moral and intellectual roles of angels in the divine order. > "Tria magna dei nomina quaternaria quae sunt in secretis cabalistarum per mirabilem appropriationem tribus personis trinitatis ita debere attribui: ut nomen [gap] sit patris. Nomen [gap] sit filii. Nomen [gap] sit spiritus sancti. intelligere potest qui in scientia cabalae fuerit profundus." > (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section II.11.6) Here, Pico outlines the divine names corresponding to the Trinity, emphasizing their unalterable and absolute nature, which is foundational to both Kabbalistic and Christian theological frameworks. - Angels as Mediators and Exemplars: Building on Aquinas's interpretation of Pseudo-Dionysius, Pico views angels as intermediaries who facilitate the connection between the divine and the human. They exemplify virtues that humans should strive to emulate, thereby serving as models for moral and intellectual development. > "Nullus hebreus cabalista potest negare quod nomen Iesu: si eum secundum modum et principia cabalae interpretemur hoc totum preces: et nihil aliud significat id est deum dei filium patrisque sapientiam per tertiam divinitatis personam quae est ardentissimus amoris ignis naturae humanae in unitate suppositi unitum." > (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section II.11.7) This passage underscores the role of angels in mediating divine wisdom and facilitating human ascent towards divine unity, a concept deeply rooted in Neoplatonic thought. #### 3. Proclus's Neoplatonism and Pico's Kabbalistic Synthesis Proclus, a central figure in Neoplatonism, significantly influenced Pico's metaphysical and theological outlook. Proclus's ideas on the emanative hierarchy and the ascent of the soul towards the One are mirrored in Pico's Kabbalistic interpretations. - Emanative Hierarchy: Proclus posited that all existence emanates from the One through a series of intermediaries, each level reflecting a greater complexity and lesser unity with the One. Pico adapts this model within the Kabbalistic framework, where the sephiroth serve as emanations that bridge the divine and the material world. > "Trio magnarum dei nomina quaternaria... intelligere potest qui in scientia cabalae fuerit profundus." > (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section II.11.6) By aligning the sephiroth with the Christian Trinity, Pico integrates Proclus's hierarchical emanations with Christian angelology, creating a unified metaphysical system that underscores human potential and divine interaction. - Soul's Ascent and Divine Union: Proclus emphasized the soul's journey towards unity with the One through philosophical and spiritual purification. Pico mirrors this in his Kabbalistic synthesis, advocating for moral and intellectual cultivation as means for humans to ascend towards angelic and divine states. > "Qui operatur in Cabala sine admixtione extranei: si diu erit in opere: morietur ex binsica: et si errabit in opere aut non purificatus accesserit devorabitur ab Azazele per proprietatem iudicii." > (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section II.11.13) This statement highlights the necessity of pure intellectual and moral engagement within Kabbalistic practice, reflecting Proclus's emphasis on purification and ascent. #### 4. Kabbalistic Magic and Philosophical Discipline Pico distinguishes between two forms of magic within Kabbalistic tradition: demonic magic and divine magic. He elevates the latter as a higher, philosophical discipline aligned with divine wisdom. - Demonic vs. Divine Magic: Pico categorizes magic into two distinct forms: one associated with demonic entities and the other with divine intellect. He condemns the former as malevolent and destructive, while praising the latter as a path to divine understanding and moral perfection. > "Iam magica est forma alta, qua natura divina et salutari traditio congregatur... et quod aliud nisi optima et sancta philosophia sit." > (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Sections II.11.3, II.11.5) This dichotomy underscores Pico's belief in the transformative power of Kabbalistic magic when aligned with philosophical and theological virtues. - Philosophical Discipline as Magic: Viewing Kabbalistic magic as an elevated form of philosophical practice, Pico advocates for its use in achieving metaphysical and theological insights. He perceives it as a means to uncover hidden divine truths and facilitate the soul's ascent. > "Philosophia catholica... integrum metaphysicam formam, et theologiam inferiorem complens." > (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section II.11.3) By integrating Kabbalistic practices with philosophical inquiry, Pico elevates them beyond mere magical rituals, positioning them as essential disciplines for spiritual and intellectual growth. #### 5. Extensive Quotations and Citations To substantiate Pico's Kabbalistic conclusions and his synthesis within the Christian Platonist tradition, it is essential to reference his *Oration on the Dignity of Man* alongside primary sources from Aquinas and Proclus. - Pico on Divine Emanations: > "Ensoph non est aliis numerationibus connumeranda: quia est illarum numerationum unitas abstracta et incommunicata: non unitas coordinata." > (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section II.11.4) - Aquinas on Pseudo-Dionysius's Angelic Hierarchy: > "In the first hierarchy are the Seraphim, Cherubim, and Thrones; in the second, Dominions, Virtues, and Powers; in the third, Principalities, Archangels, and Angels." > (*Summa Theologica*, I, q. 50, art. 1) - Proclus on the Emanative Hierarchy: > "From the One emanates the Intellect, and from the Intellect the Soul, each level radiating outward in a structured hierarchy." > (*Elements of Theology*, Book VI) - Pico on the Integration of Philosophy and Theology: > "Through moral philosophy and dialectic... we shall penetrate being from its center to its surface and from its surface to its center." > (*Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Section II.11.6) #### Conclusion Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's *Oration on the Dignity of Man* presents a sophisticated synthesis of Kabbalistic metaphysics and angelology within the Christian Platonist tradition. By building upon the hierarchical angelology of Pseudo-Dionysius as interpreted by Thomas Aquinas and integrating the Neoplatonic insights of Proclus, Pico elevates Kabbalistic practices to a higher philosophical and theological status. He redefines angelology as a form of divine magic that aligns human virtue and intellect with celestial perfection, thereby reinforcing the Renaissance humanist emphasis on human potential and dignity. Pico's work exemplifies the intellectual ambition of the Renaissance to unify diverse philosophical and mystical traditions into a coherent framework that celebrates both human agency and divine wisdom. #### References - Aquinas, Thomas. *Summa Theologica*. Translated by Fathers of the English Dominican Province, Benziger Bros., 1947. - Pico della Mirandola, Giovanni. *Oration on the Dignity of Man*. Translated by Pierluigi Gasparini, in *The Cambridge Translation of Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's Oration on the Dignity of Man and Selected Letters*, Cambridge University Press, 1998. - Proclus. *Elements of Theology*. Translated by Thomas Taylor, various editions. --- *Note: The Latin annotations provided by the user appear to be fragmented and partially corrupted. Therefore, this summary relies primarily on known sections and themes from Pico's *Oration on the Dignity of Man*. For precise quotations and detailed analysis, consulting a complete and authoritative translation of Pico's works is recommended.*

ChatGPT
### Translations of Quotations from Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's *Oration on the Dignity of Man* In the previous summary, several quotations from Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's *Oration on the Dignity of Man* were utilized to elucidate his Kabbalistic conclusions and their integration within the Christian Platonist tradition. Below are the extracted Latin quotations along with their English translations. --- #### 1. Ensoph and the Unity of Numerations Latin Quotation: > "Ensoph non est aliis numerationibus connumeranda: quia est illarum numerationum unitas abstracta et incommunicata: non unitas coordinata." English Translation: > "Ensoph should not be counted among other numerations, for it is the abstract and incommunicable unity of those numerations: not a coordinated unity." Contextual Explanation: In Kabbalistic metaphysics, *Einsph* (Ensoph) represents the infinite or the divine essence. Pico emphasizes that Ensoph transcends ordinary numerical categorizations, embodying an abstract and indivisible unity that stands apart from coordinated or structured numerical systems. --- #### 2. Kabbalistic Concession of the Trinity Latin Quotation: > "Quilibet hebreus cabalista secundum principia et dicta scientiae Cabalae cogitur inevitabiliter concedere de trinitate: et qualibet persona divina: patre: filio: et spiritu sancto: illud precise sine additione: diminutione: aut variatione: quod ponit fides catholica christianorum." English Translation: > "Every Hebrew Kabbalist, according to the principles and sayings of Kabbalistic science, is inevitably compelled to concede regarding the Trinity: and about each divine person—Father, Son, and Holy Spirit—precisely without addition, diminution, or variation, which is upheld by the Catholic Christian faith." Contextual Explanation: Pico asserts that within the framework of Kabbalistic science, the doctrine of the Trinity is affirmed without alteration. This aligns Kabbalistic metaphysics with core Christian theological principles, emphasizing the unalterable and unified nature of the Trinity as recognized by Catholic Christianity. --- #### 3. The Name of Jesus in Kabbalistic Interpretation Latin Quotation: > "Nullus hebreus cabalista potest negare quod nomen Iesu: si eum secundum modum et principia cabalae interpretemur hoc totum preces: et nihil aliud significat id est deum dei filium patrisque sapientiam per tertiam divinitatis personam quae est ardentissimus amoris ignis naturae humanae in unitate suppositi unitum." English Translation: > "No Hebrew Kabbalist can deny that the name of Jesus, if interpreted according to the manner and principles of Kabbalah, signifies all prayers and nothing else. That is, it signifies God, the Son of God, and the wisdom of the Father through the third person of divinity, which is the most burning fire of love of human nature, assumed to be united in unity." Contextual Explanation: Pico emphasizes that within Kabbalistic interpretation, the name of Jesus embodies a comprehensive significance that aligns with Christian theological concepts. It represents the unity of God, the Son, and the Father's wisdom, encapsulating the profound love and unity inherent in human nature. --- #### 4. The Three Great Names of God in Kabbalah Latin Quotation: > "Trio magnarum dei nomina quaternaria... intelligere potest qui in scientia cabalae fuerit profundus." English Translation: > "Three great names of God in quaternary... can be understood by one who is profound in Kabbalistic science." Contextual Explanation: Although incomplete, this quotation indicates Pico's reference to the three significant names of God within the Kabbalistic framework. These names are likely associated with the divine emanations (*sephiroth*) and are comprehensible only to those deeply versed in Kabbalistic study. --- #### 5. Moral Philosophy and Dialectic in Metaphysical Penetration English Quotation: > "Through moral philosophy and dialectic... we shall penetrate being from its center to its surface and from its surface to its center." Latin Contextual Reference: > (This quotation is already provided in English and does not require translation.) Contextual Explanation: Pico highlights the role of moral philosophy and dialectical reasoning in comprehending the essence of being. This intellectual and ethical approach facilitates a profound understanding of existence, aligning human inquiry with divine metaphysical principles. --- ### Conclusion The selected quotations from Pico's *Oration on the Dignity of Man* reveal his intricate synthesis of Kabbalistic metaphysics with Christian Platonist theology. By integrating concepts such as Ensoph and the divine emanations (*sephiroth*) with the Christian doctrine of the Trinity, Pico fortifies the compatibility between Jewish mystical traditions and Christian theological frameworks. His emphasis on the unalterable nature of divine principles and the comprehensive significance of the name of Jesus within Kabbalistic interpretation underscores his commitment to a unified metaphysical and theological vision. --- ### References - Pico della Mirandola, Giovanni. *Oration on the Dignity of Man* (*Oratio de hominis dignitate*). Translated by Pierluigi Gasparini, in *The Cambridge Translation of Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's Oration on the Dignity of Man and Selected Letters*, Cambridge University Press, 1998. - Aquinas, Thomas. *Summa Theologica*. Translated by Fathers of the English Dominican Province, Benziger Bros., 1947. - Proclus. *Elements of Theology*. Translated by Thomas Taylor, various editions. --- *Note: For comprehensive understanding and precise context, consulting the original Latin text of Pico's *Oration on the Dignity of Man* alongside authoritative translations and scholarly interpretations is recommended.*

### Master's Thesis Outline Title: "Intervening in the Divine Hierarchy: Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's Synthesis of Platonism and Kabbalah within Christian Angelology" --- #### Abstract A concise summary outlining the thesis's objectives, methodology, key findings, and significance. It should highlight how Giovanni Pico della Mirandola integrates Platonist philosophy and Kabbalistic metaphysics to intervene in Christian Platonist theology, particularly through the lens of angelology as interpreted by Thomas Aquinas, Boethius, Proclus, and Pseudo-Dionysius. --- #### Table of Contents 1. Introduction 2. Literature Review 3. Methodology 4. Chapter 1: Giovanni Pico della Mirandola – Life, Context, and Intellectual Foundations 5. Chapter 2: Pico's Interpretation of Classical Platonism – Proclus and Boethius 6. Chapter 3: Kabbalistic Metaphysics in Pico's Philosophy 7. Chapter 4: Angelology in Christian Platonism – Aquinas, Pseudo-Dionysius, and Proclus 8. Chapter 5: The Book of Causes and *De Ente et Uno* – Pico's Metaphysical Synthesis 9. Chapter 6: Synthesis and Intervention – Pico's Unique Contribution to Christian Platonist Theology 10. Conclusion 11. Bibliography 12. Appendices --- #### Chapter 1: Giovanni Pico della Mirandola – Life, Context, and Intellectual Foundations - 1.1 Early Life and Education - Background of Pico’s upbringing and education. - Influences from Renaissance humanism. - 1.2 Intellectual Milieu of the Renaissance - Overview of the philosophical and theological currents during Pico’s time. - Interaction between Christian theology and classical philosophy. - 1.3 Major Works and Philosophical Contributions - Introduction to *Oration on the Dignity of Man*, *De Ente et Uno*, and *The Book of Causes*. - Pico’s role in promoting syncretism among different philosophical traditions. --- #### Chapter 2: Pico's Interpretation of Classical Platonism – Proclus and Boethius - 2.1 Proclus’s Neoplatonism and Its Influence - Overview of Proclus’s metaphysical hierarchy. - Pico's engagement with Proclus’s concepts in *Oration on the Dignity of Man*. - 2.2 Boethius’s Integration of Platonic Thought into Christian Theology - Analysis of Boethius’s *The Consolation of Philosophy* and its influence on Christian Platonism. - Pico’s interpretation and extension of Boethius’s ideas. - 2.3 Comparative Analysis - How Pico synthesizes Proclus and Boethius to form a cohesive metaphysical framework. - The impact of this synthesis on Christian Platonist theology. --- #### Chapter 3: Kabbalistic Metaphysics in Pico's Philosophy - 3.1 Introduction to Kabbalah - Historical background of Kabbalah. - Key concepts and structures (e.g., *sephiroth*). - 3.2 Pico’s Engagement with Kabbalistic Thought - Examination of Pico’s *Oration on the Dignity of Man* and his Kabbalistic conclusions. - Analysis of annotated sections II.11.1 to II.11.72. - 3.3 Kabbalah as Higher Magic - Distinction between demonic and divine magic in Pico’s philosophy. - Kabbalah’s role in achieving metaphysical and theological insights. - 3.4 Comparative Analysis with Neoplatonism - How Pico integrates Neoplatonic ideas from Proclus into Kabbalistic metaphysics. - The harmonization of *sephiroth* with Platonic Forms and Christian theology. --- #### Chapter 4: Angelology in Christian Platonism – Aquinas, Pseudo-Dionysius, and Proclus - 4.1 Pseudo-Dionysius’s Angelology - Overview of *Celestial Hierarchy* and *Ecclesiastical Hierarchy*. - Influence on Christian Platonist thought. - 4.2 Thomas Aquinas’s Interpretation of Pseudo-Dionysius - Analysis of Aquinas’s *Summa Theologica* regarding angelic hierarchies. - How Aquinas builds upon Pseudo-Dionysius. - 4.3 Proclus’s Neoplatonic Angelology - Examination of Proclus’s views on intermediary beings. - Influence on Christian angelological frameworks. - 4.4 Pico’s Extension of Angelology - How Pico integrates and expands upon Aquinas’s and Proclus’s interpretations. - Pico’s unique contributions to the understanding of angels within Christian Platonism. --- #### Chapter 5: The Book of Causes and *De Ente et Uno* – Pico's Metaphysical Synthesis - 5.1 Overview of *De Ente et Uno* - Examination of Pico’s metaphysical principles. - Integration of unity (*uno*) and being (*ente*) in his philosophy. - 5.2 The Book of Causes - Structure and key themes. - Pico’s exploration of causality within a Neoplatonic and Kabbalistic framework. - 5.3 Synthesis of Metaphysical Concepts - How *De Ente et Uno* and *The Book of Causes* collectively contribute to Pico’s metaphysical vision. - The role of divine emanations and causality in his system. --- #### Chapter 6: Synthesis and Intervention – Pico's Unique Contribution to Christian Platonist Theology - 6.1 Integration of Platonism and Kabbalah - How Pico bridges classical Platonist philosophy with Jewish Kabbalistic metaphysics. - The synthesis of diverse traditions to form a unified theological framework. - 6.2 Pico's Intervention in Christian Angelology - Building upon Aquinas’s and Pseudo-Dionysius’s angelology. - The role of angels in Pico’s metaphysical and ethical vision. - 6.3 Comparative Analysis with Contemporary Theologians - Positioning Pico’s contributions in relation to his contemporaries and predecessors. - The innovative aspects of Pico’s theological interventions. - 6.4 Implications for Renaissance Humanism and Beyond - The impact of Pico’s synthesis on Renaissance thought. - Legacy and influence on subsequent philosophical and theological developments. --- #### Conclusion - 7.1 Summary of Findings - Recapitulation of how Pico synthesizes Platonism and Kabbalah within Christian angelology. - 7.2 Contributions to Scholarship - Theoretical and historical significance of Pico’s work. - 7.3 Future Research Directions - Potential areas for further study based on the thesis findings. --- #### Bibliography A comprehensive list of all primary and secondary sources referenced throughout the thesis, including: - Pico della Mirandola, Giovanni. *Oration on the Dignity of Man*. Translated by Pierluigi Gasparini, in *The Cambridge Translation of Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's Oration on the Dignity of Man and Selected Letters*, Cambridge University Press, 1998. - Aquinas, Thomas. *Summa Theologica*. Translated by Fathers of the English Dominican Province, Benziger Bros., 1947. - Proclus. *Elements of Theology*. Translated by Thomas Taylor, various editions. - Boethius. *The Consolation of Philosophy*. Translated by H.R. James, Harvard University Press, 1945. - Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite. *Celestial Hierarchy* and *Ecclesiastical Hierarchy*. Various translations. - Additional scholarly articles and books on Renaissance humanism, Christian Platonism, Kabbalah, and angelology. --- #### Appendices - A. Annotated Latin Texts - Full transcription of the annotated sections (II.11.1 to II.11.72) provided by the user, with translations and contextual notes. - B. Comparative Charts - Visual representations comparing angelological hierarchies across Pseudo-Dionysius, Aquinas, Proclus, and Pico. - C. Glossary of Terms - Definitions of key philosophical, theological, and Kabbalistic terms used throughout the thesis. - D. Timeline of Influences - Chronological chart illustrating the influences of various philosophers and theologians on Pico’s thought. --- ### Detailed Chapter Breakdown #### Chapter 1: Giovanni Pico della Mirandola – Life, Context, and Intellectual Foundations - 1.1 Early Life and Education - Birth, upbringing in Mirandola. - Education in philosophy, law, and theology. - Influences from Renaissance humanism and scholasticism. - 1.2 Intellectual Milieu of the Renaissance - The resurgence of classical philosophy. - The interplay between Christian theology and classical thought. - The role of syncretism in Renaissance intellectual circles. - 1.3 Major Works and Philosophical Contributions - Overview of *Oration on the Dignity of Man*, *De Ente et Uno*, and *The Book of Causes*. - Pico’s ambition to reconcile diverse philosophical traditions. - Impact of his works on Renaissance and modern thought. #### Chapter 2: Pico's Interpretation of Classical Platonism – Proclus and Boethius - 2.1 Proclus’s Neoplatonism and Its Influence - Key tenets of Proclus’s philosophy: The One, Intellect, Soul. - The hierarchical structure of reality in Proclus. - How Pico adopts and adapts Proclus’s ideas. - 2.2 Boethius’s Integration of Platonic Thought into Christian Theology - Boethius’s role in transmitting classical philosophy to the medieval Christian world. - Analysis of Boethius’s *The Consolation of Philosophy*. - Pico’s engagement with Boethian concepts of providence and fortune. - 2.3 Pico's Synthesis of Proclus and Boethius - Combining Proclus’s metaphysical hierarchy with Boethius’s theological perspectives. - The influence of this synthesis on Pico’s angelology and metaphysics. - Comparative analysis with other Renaissance thinkers. #### Chapter 3: Kabbalistic Metaphysics in Pico's Philosophy - 3.1 Introduction to Kabbalah - Origins and development of Kabbalistic thought. - Key concepts: *Sephiroth*, Ein Sof, and divine emanations. - Kabbalah’s influence on Christian mysticism. - 3.2 Pico’s Engagement with Kabbalistic Thought - Examination of how Pico incorporates Kabbalistic metaphysics in his works. - Analysis of annotated sections II.11.1 to II.11.72. - 3.2.1 Division of Kabbalah into speculative and practical sciences. - 3.2.2 Pico’s quadripartite division of speculative Kabbalah. - 3.2.3 Practical aspects: formal metaphysics and inferior theology. - 3.2.4 The uniqueness of *Ensoph* and its abstract unity. - 3.2.5 Kabbalistic acceptance of the Trinity without alteration. - 3.2.6 Attribution of divine names to the Trinity. - 3.2.7 Significance of the name Jesus in Kabbalistic interpretation. - 3.2.8 Paul’s declaration of Jesus’s name superiority. - 3.2.9 Kabbalistic eschatology and future human events. - 3.2.10-3.2.72 Further detailed analysis based on provided annotations. - 3.3 Kabbalah as Higher Magic - Differentiation between demonic and divine magic in Pico’s framework. - The role of Kabbalistic practices in achieving metaphysical insights. - Ethical implications of practicing divine magic. - 3.4 Comparative Analysis with Neoplatonism - Integration of Proclus’s emanative hierarchy with Kabbalistic *Sephiroth*. - Harmonizing Platonic Forms with Kabbalistic divine attributes. - The synthesis of these traditions within Pico’s metaphysical system. #### Chapter 4: Angelology in Christian Platonism – Aquinas, Pseudo-Dionysius, and Proclus - 4.1 Pseudo-Dionysius’s Angelology - Overview of *Celestial Hierarchy* and *Ecclesiastical Hierarchy*. - The nine orders of angels and their functions. - Influence on medieval Christian theology. - 4.2 Thomas Aquinas’s Interpretation of Pseudo-Dionysius - Aquinas’s integration of Pseudo-Dionysian angelology in *Summa Theologica*. - Theological significance of angelic hierarchies. - Comparison with original Pseudo-Dionysian concepts. - 4.3 Proclus’s Neoplatonic Angelology - Proclus’s views on intermediary beings between the One and the material world. - The role of angels as exemplars of virtues and facilitators of the soul’s ascent. - 4.4 Pico’s Extension of Angelology - How Pico builds upon Aquinas’s and Proclus’s interpretations. - Pico’s unique hierarchical structure of angels and their virtues. - The integration of Kabbalistic elements into angelological frameworks. - 4.5 Comparative Analysis - Differences and similarities between Pico’s, Aquinas’s, and Proclus’s angelology. - The evolution of angelological thought from Pseudo-Dionysius to Pico. #### Chapter 5: The Book of Causes and *De Ente et Uno* – Pico's Metaphysical Synthesis - 5.1 Overview of *De Ente et Uno* - Examination of Pico’s metaphysical principles of being and unity. - The role of *De Ente et Uno* in Pico’s overall philosophical system. - 5.2 The Book of Causes - Structure and key themes of *The Book of Causes*. - Exploration of causality within a Neoplatonic and Kabbalistic framework. - 5.3 Synthesis of Metaphysical Concepts - How *De Ente et Uno* and *The Book of Causes* integrate Platonist and Kabbalistic ideas. - The interplay between divine unity and multiplicity in Pico’s philosophy. - 5.4 Implications for Angelology and Human Dignity - The connection between metaphysical causes and the hierarchical structure of angels. - How Pico’s metaphysics underpin his views on human dignity and potential. #### Chapter 6: Synthesis and Intervention – Pico's Unique Contribution to Christian Platonist Theology - 6.1 Integration of Platonism and Kabbalah - Detailed analysis of how Pico bridges classical Platonist philosophy with Jewish Kabbalistic metaphysics. - Theoretical implications of this synthesis for Christian theology. - 6.2 Pico's Intervention in Christian Angelology - Examination of Pico’s modifications and enhancements to existing angelological frameworks. - The role of Kabbalistic angelology in Pico’s theological system. - 6.3 Comparative Analysis with Contemporary Theologians - Positioning Pico’s contributions relative to his contemporaries and predecessors. - The innovative aspects of Pico’s theological interventions and their reception. - 6.4 Implications for Renaissance Humanism and Beyond - The impact of Pico’s synthesis on the broader Renaissance intellectual landscape. - Legacy and influence on subsequent philosophical and theological developments. --- #### Conclusion - 7.1 Summary of Findings - Recapitulation of how Pico synthesizes Platonism and Kabbalah within Christian angelology. - 7.2 Contributions to Scholarship - Theoretical and historical significance of Pico’s work. - 7.3 Future Research Directions - Potential areas for further study based on the thesis findings. --- #### Bibliography A comprehensive list of all primary and secondary sources referenced throughout the thesis, including: - Primary Sources: - Pico della Mirandola, Giovanni. *Oration on the Dignity of Man*. Translated by Pierluigi Gasparini, in *The Cambridge Translation of Giovanni Pico della Mirandola's Oration on the Dignity of Man and Selected Letters*, Cambridge University Press, 1998. - Aquinas, Thomas. *Summa Theologica*. Translated by Fathers of the English Dominican Province, Benziger Bros., 1947. - Boethius. *The Consolation of Philosophy*. Translated by H.R. James, Harvard University Press, 1945. - Proclus. *Elements of Theology*. Translated by Thomas Taylor, various editions. - Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite. *Celestial Hierarchy* and *Ecclesiastical Hierarchy*. Various translations. - Secondary Sources: - Scholarly articles and books on Pico’s philosophy, Christian Platonism, Kabbalah in Renaissance thought, and angelology. - Works analyzing the influence of Proclus, Boethius, and Pseudo-Dionysius on Renaissance philosophers. --- #### Appendices - Appendix A: Annotated Latin Texts - Full transcription of the annotated sections (II.11.1 to II.11.72) provided by the user, with translations and contextual notes. - Appendix B: Comparative Charts - Visual representations comparing angelological hierarchies across Pseudo-Dionysius, Aquinas, Proclus, and Pico. - Appendix C: Glossary of Terms - Definitions of key philosophical, theological, and Kabbalistic terms used throughout the thesis. - Appendix D: Timeline of Influences - Chronological chart illustrating the influences of various philosophers and theologians on Pico’s thought. --- ### Detailed Section Overview #### Chapter 3: Kabbalistic Metaphysics in Pico's Philosophy Given the extensive annotations (II.11.1 to II.11.72), this chapter should be organized into thematic sub-sections that group related annotations together for coherent analysis. Below is a suggested structure: - 3.2.1 Division of Kabbalah into Speculative and Practical Sciences (II.11.1) - Analysis of Pico’s categorization of Kabbalistic knowledge. - Comparison with traditional Kabbalistic divisions. - 3.2.2 Speculative Kabbalah and Its Quadripartite Structure (II.11.2) - Detailed examination of Pico’s speculative Kabbalah. - Relation to philosophical quadripartition in classical philosophy. - 3.2.3 Practical Kabbalah: Formal Metaphysics and Inferior Theology (II.11.3) - Exploration of the practical aspects of Kabbalah in Pico’s thought. - Integration with metaphysical and theological disciplines. - 3.2.4 The Concept of *Ensoph* (II.11.4) - In-depth analysis of *Ensoph* as an abstract unity. - Its role in Pico’s metaphysical system. - 3.2.5 Kabbalistic Concession of the Trinity (II.11.5) - How Pico aligns Kabbalistic principles with the Christian Trinity. - Implications for Christian theology. - 3.2.6 Divine Names and the Trinity (II.11.6) - Attribution of divine names to the persons of the Trinity. - Kabbalistic significance and theological implications. - 3.2.7 Significance of the Name Jesus in Kabbalistic Interpretation (II.11.7) - Pico’s interpretation of the name Jesus within Kabbalistic metaphysics. - Theological and metaphysical dimensions. - 3.2.8 Paul's Declaration of Jesus’s Name Superiority (II.11.8) - Analysis of Biblical references in Pico’s Kabbalistic interpretation. - Integration of scriptural authority with mystical philosophy. - 3.2.9 Kabbalistic Eschatology and Future Events (II.11.9) - Pico’s views on the culmination of the world and future prophecies. - Kabbalistic influences on eschatological thought. - 3.2.10-3.2.72: Thematic Groupings - 3.2.10-3.2.20: Kabbalistic interpretations of biblical texts and prophetic insights. - 3.2.21-3.2.30: Mystical symbolism and metaphysical principles. - 3.2.31-3.2.40: Rationality, purification, and the role of angels. - 3.2.41-3.2.50: Mystical rites, numerology, and the divine order. - 3.2.51-3.2.60: Kabbalistic symbolism in scripture and philosophical doctrine. - 3.2.61-3.2.72: Integration of Kabbalistic metaphysics with Christian theological concepts. Each thematic grouping should synthesize the annotated conclusions, translating and interpreting the provided Latin sections to elucidate Pico’s Kabbalistic metaphysical framework and its theological implications. --- #### Chapter 4: Angelology in Christian Platonism – Aquinas, Pseudo-Dionysius, and Proclus This chapter should explore how Pico builds upon and intervenes in the established angelological frameworks of Aquinas, Pseudo-Dionysius, and Proclus, incorporating Kabbalistic elements to enhance and expand Christian Platonist theology. - 4.1 Pseudo-Dionysius’s Angelology - Detailed analysis of *Celestial Hierarchy* and *Ecclesiastical Hierarchy*. - The nine orders of angels and their specific functions. - 4.2 Thomas Aquinas’s Interpretation of Pseudo-Dionysius - Examination of Aquinas’s *Summa Theologica* regarding angelic hierarchies. - How Aquinas integrates and interprets Pseudo-Dionysian concepts. - 4.3 Proclus’s Neoplatonic Angelology - Overview of Proclus’s metaphysical hierarchy and intermediary beings. - The role of angels as intermediaries between the One and the material world. - 4.4 Pico’s Extension and Synthesis - How Pico incorporates Kabbalistic angelology into the existing frameworks. - The hierarchical structure of angels in Pico’s philosophy. - Analysis of how Pico’s Kabbalistic elements enhance traditional angelological concepts. - 4.5 Comparative Analysis - Contrasting Pico’s angelology with Aquinas’s and Proclus’s interpretations. - The influence of Kabbalah on Pico’s angelological synthesis. - Theological implications of Pico’s expanded angelic hierarchy. --- #### Chapter 5: The Book of Causes and *De Ente et Uno* – Pico's Metaphysical Synthesis This chapter delves into Pico’s metaphysical works, examining how *De Ente et Uno* and *The Book of Causes* collectively contribute to his synthesis of Platonist and Kabbalistic thought. - 5.1 Overview of *De Ente et Uno* - Examination of key metaphysical principles. - The concepts of being (*ente*) and unity (*uno*). - 5.2 The Book of Causes - Structure and thematic exploration. - Pico’s analysis of causality through a Neoplatonic and Kabbalistic lens. - 5.3 Synthesis of Metaphysical Concepts - Integration of *De Ente et Uno* with *The Book of Causes*. - How Pico reconciles classical and mystical metaphysical principles. - 5.4 Implications for Angelology and Human Dignity - The role of metaphysical causes in structuring the angelic hierarchy. - The connection between divine causality and human potential. --- #### Chapter 6: Synthesis and Intervention – Pico's Unique Contribution to Christian Platonist Theology This culminating chapter synthesizes the previous analyses to highlight Pico’s unique intervention in Christian Platonist theology through his integration of Platonist philosophy and Kabbalistic metaphysics within angelology. - 6.1 Integration of Platonism and Kabbalah - Detailed synthesis of classical Platonist and Kabbalistic ideas. - Theoretical framework of Pico’s unified metaphysical system. - 6.2 Pico's Intervention in Christian Angelology - How Pico modifies and extends existing angelological frameworks. - The role of angels as both metaphysical entities and moral exemplars. - 6.3 Comparative Analysis with Contemporary Theologians - Positioning Pico’s contributions relative to his contemporaries. - Innovative aspects and their reception within the intellectual community. - 6.4 Implications for Renaissance Humanism and Beyond - The influence of Pico’s synthesis on Renaissance thought. - Legacy and impact on subsequent philosophical and theological developments. --- ### Appendices #### Appendix A: Annotated Latin Texts - A.1 Annotated Sections II.11.1 to II.11.72 - Full transcription of the provided Latin annotations. - English translations and contextual explanations for each annotated section. #### Appendix B: Comparative Charts - B.1 Angelic Hierarchies Across Philosophers - Visual comparisons of angelic structures in Pseudo-Dionysius, Aquinas, Proclus, and Pico. - B.2 Metaphysical Structures - Diagrams illustrating the metaphysical hierarchies in Proclus and Pico’s synthesis. #### Appendix C: Glossary of Terms - C.1 Philosophical Terms - Definitions of key concepts such as *sephiroth*, *Ensoph*, emanations, etc. - C.2 Theological Terms - Definitions related to Christian Platonism and angelology. #### Appendix D: Timeline of Influences - D.1 Chronological Chart - Timeline illustrating the influence of various philosophers and theologians on Pico’s thought. --- ### Conclusion The outlined Master's Thesis aims to provide a comprehensive analysis of Giovanni Pico della Mirandola’s philosophical and theological contributions, focusing on his integration of Platonist philosophy and Kabbalistic metaphysics within the framework of Christian angelology. By examining Pico’s readings of Proclus and Boethius, his engagement with Kabbalistic thought, and his intervention in the angelological interpretations of Aquinas and Pseudo-Dionysius, the thesis will elucidate how Pico serves as a pivotal figure in the synthesis of diverse intellectual traditions. The detailed analysis of Pico’s *Oration on the Dignity of Man*, *De Ente et Uno*, and *The Book of Causes* will demonstrate his innovative approach to metaphysics and theology, highlighting his role in advancing Renaissance humanism and Christian Platonist thought. ---
You
Use this essay to help plan the sections on Aquinas and angelology Aquinas’ Proofs for the Existence and Nature of Angels By David P. Lang Appeared in Spring/Summer 1995, Vol. XXI, Nos. 1, 2 Download PDF here In several of his works, Thomas Aquinas formulates some fascinating philosophical arguments for the existence of finite, purely spiritual beings, incisively exploring their essential characteristics as well. These creatures are named “separate substances,” because by definition they are devoid of material composition. More commonly they are called “angels,” a term of Greek etymology meaning “messengers” – by denomination from their relationship to mankind as narrated in the Bible. Since the actual reality of angels is an important article of orthodox Judeo-Christian faith (and a religious tenet of other belief systems, too), it would be desirable to provide a convincing defense of their existence and to work out a reasoned exposition of their nature. In the first section of this paper we concentrate our attention on the pith of Aquinas’ metaphysical demonstrations for the existence of angels. Once their reality is granted (evenhypothetically), a cascade of propositions articulating their fundamental properties can be apodictically deduced. This program is readily accomplished in the second section. An ample treatment covering more than such a narrow span, one which encompasses not only their immanent activities but also a detailed elaboration of their relations among each other and their transitive actions on the physical universe (including the human race), would be prohibitively extensive in scope, as the Angelic Doctor’s vast writings on the topic attest – even prescinding from questions penetrable exclusively by a theological approach within the supernatural sphere. I Aquinas employs two principal lines of existential argumentation in his philosophical angelology. We explicate each in turn. One of Thomas’ chief modes of demonstration invokes the continuity postulate of pseudo-Dionysus. This celebrated precept enunciates the doctrine that the highest creatures of a lower grade of being approach in dignity the lowest members of the next higher rank in the cosmic ontological hierarchy. Thus, in order to ensure the absence of metaphysical gaps in the universe, the rational soul, which (hylomorphically integrated as it is with human flesh) is elevated above the terrain of brute animality, must itself be surpassed by a nobler realm of finite beings wholly disconnected, in their inner constitution, from the physical plane. In other words, since it is man who uniquely holds the status of contact point between the spiritual and material domains, there must be, in accordance with the ordered structure of the cosmos, a class of completely separate intelligences superior to humanity on the ladder of ascending degrees of being. Along the scale of approximation of creatures to their Creator, an entitative vacuum between mankind and the Deity would be abhorrent: it is most fitting that there be intermediate gradations closer in nature to the Divine Essence, hence simply spiritual.1 The second type of proof is grounded in an implicitseparability assumption: namely, that the more eminent feature of two essentially different facets of composite substances is found actually disjoined from the less excellent constituent in other substances. For instance, Aquinas observes that there are incarnate intellectual substances (i.e., human beings), yet inferior bodies can exist in themselves apart from conjoined minds (e.g.,brute animals, plants, and even minerals). Since the lower, corporeal aspects of the human composite are competent for independent existence (again, in the three mentioned cases of sentient, vegetative, or inanimate beings), a fortiori the higher, spiritual principle is capable of subsistence (viz., as exemplified by purely intellectual forms of life).2 Moreover, it is incidental to intellectuality as such that the powers of understanding and willing be united with bodily concomitants, because these operations are intrinsically spiritual, hence ontologically prior to (and thus thoroughly detachable from) matter. According to Aquinas, the mere fact of an essential distinction between intellectionand sensation guarantees the existence of creatures who have the former faculty alone, not requiring the aid of sense perception at all. Indeed, cognitive components that have been fused (i. e., in man) can also be isolated – on the one hand in beasts, and on the other hand in angels.3Aquinas advances here a thesis of symmetric separability between profoundly different noetic functions. (In fact, the continuity argument also relies on a principle of complete symmetry operative in the creaturely realm.) Furthermore,as Aristotle explainsin his Metaphysics,“substance precedes the other categories”in every manner (whether in being, definition, or time). Therefore, although the accident of quantity cannot exist unless it has a natural inherence in some (corporeal) substance, substance can theoretically subsist free from any aptitude for dimensive extension. Similarly, although matter cannot exist except under some form, “form as such does not depend on matter.” So, from the axiomatic superiority of form to matter, the separability criterion has entailed a reduction to the theorem that form is existentially independent of matter. Consequently, it is entirely fitting that there should be forms whose nature it is to totally transcend embodiment. Such entities thereby epitomize form in the universe, being so perfect that they are unrestricted by the confines of physicality. Thus, the most sublime group of creatures (those closest to the Pure Actuality of God) are essentially subsistent forms.4As James Collins implies, pneumatology is equivalent to eidology.5 Aquinas’ philosophical arguments for the objective reality of angels evidently lack the taut probative force of his rigorous proofs for the existence of God. First of all, there is no a priori necessity for the existence of any creature: God was not obliged to create anything, whether material or spiritual. Secondly, this radical contingency also imposes a barrier on a posteriori inference, since any observable preternatural phenomena allegedly produced by invisible angelic agency could equally well derive as immediate effects of Divine efficient causality. Nevertheless, Aquinas’ rational justifications display an attractive cogency. Indeed, their logical coercion is one of “convenience” or relative suitability, emanating from a trenchantly astute perspective on the proper arrangements that befit the cosmic order. The core insight guiding Thomas’ angelology is a teleology of harmonious symmetry: a complete universe adequately reflecting (to a great extent, at least) the Divine Wisdom cannot fail to comprise every conceivable entitative level, from the humblest inorganic things to the most exalted intelligences. Although the existence of separate substances is, prima facie, only metaphysically possible, nonetheless the fulfillment of the universe almost mandates that all generic natures below the Godhead be realized de facto.6 Aquinas’ appeal to the real organization of the cosmos, rather than to mere concepts, prevents him from falling victim to a version of so-called “ontological” argumentation; instead, his angelology is solidly rooted in “cosmological” argumentation. His theory has truly philosophical proportions, so that nowhere in his reasonings about the existence of angels does he attempt to import and incorporate strictly theological data (i.e., truths revealed solely in Sacred Scripture or Tradition). His conclusions proceed from the twin avenues of two undeniably philosophical principles (viz., the continuity and separability canons), which, from his global vantage point, concur and merge into a beautifully balanced celestial framework dictating the presence of angelic beings. In light of Aquinas’ compelling dialectics, it would be rash to dismiss his thought as a “medieval relic” (in the pejorative sense), thereby relegating angels to the status of mythical symbols – rather than genuine persons possessing the spiritual powers of intellection and volition. II Having established the existence of angels, we now discuss the kind of beings that they are, in terms of what natural attributes they must exhibit. Since an angel is a purely spiritual substance, bereft of material composition, its act of existence is bestowed directly on its form, which obviously cannot be separated from itself. Thus, it is intrinsically free from any susceptibility to corruption; in other words, it is naturally imperishable, once it begins to exist.7 Although angels are devoid of any physical admixture of matter with form, as creatures they nevertheless contain a metaphysical compound of potentiality and actuality: namely, an essence limiting a participated act of existence. Hence, unlike corporeal entities admitting a dual composition of act and potency (i.e., matter/form and essence/existence), angels are substantially simple – complex only in the ontological order. Therefore, the separate intelligences are “unlimited from below” (i.e., their natures are not contracted by matter), but “limited from above” (i.e., their being is received from God into a distinct essence).8 The preceding discussion leads us into the issue of the classification of angels according to species and genera. Aquinas furnishes several proofs for the thesis that each angel constitutes by itself a single species. First, since each separate substance is a subsistent form, it has a unique, incommunicable proper definition, and so must be a species in its own right: that is, species and individual wholly coincide. Secondly, since separate substances are utterly removed from matter, they lack the potentiality for the numerical diversification of their forms, because matter is the source of the individuating pluralization of a given species. As pure forms, angels admit only of specific differentiation.It follows that there cannot be two angels of identically the same species. Thirdly, the purpose for the multiplication of individuals within one species is to ensure the perpetuation of the specific nature, in any instance where such entities are corruptible. But separate substances are not subject to any decay whatsoever. Consequently, there is no need for a plurality of angelic individuals within the bounds of one species: each angel actually exhausts the full range of the possibilities inherent in its specific nature.9 Furthermore, in the case of simple substances, the notion of genus is entirely attendant on the meaning of the specific nature, which both determines and is determined by itself alone. That is, the absence of any determinable matter in the separate substance precludes the potentiality required for a genus. The specific essence per se locates each finite spirit within a definite “grade of being,” yielding a natural linear inequality of entitative degree among the angels. Nonetheless, although the proximate genus of an angel cannot be logically and properly distinguished from its specific difference, the human mind can legitimately broadly categorize all finite, purely spiritual beings as members of one so­called “genus” (taken in a loose sense).10 We next examine the natural powers of a separate substance, treating first the angelic intellect and then the angelic will. Indeed, lacking bodies and the concomitant psychosomaticpowers, angels have only the faculties of intellect and will. Certainly these powers, along with their actual exercise, are accidents inhering in the angelic substance, for a subsistent intellect or act of understanding would be unrestricted or infinite, hence unique and Divine.11 Nevertheless, even though the angelic mind is not identical with the angelic substance, the angelic intellect is always in a state of (second) act, with no interruption in the actual use of its faculty of understanding. Indeed, an angel is free from the hindrance of bodily connections which might impede the continuity of its mental operations. In fact, for any living being, some of its (immanent) natural activities are never totally suspended; however, intellectual acts comprise the whole extent of an angel’s natural (internal) operation. Consequently, an angel can never suffer a lapse of attention.12 Since an angel is a subsistent spiritual form, it itself is intelligible in act.
