continue
ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico’s Synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic Thought (Continued) ### 6. Conclusion I.18.3: Nullam diffinitionem etiam naturalem ex Aristotelis sententia ingreditur materia. *(No definition, even in natural philosophy, according to Aristotle's view, includes matter.)* This *Conclusion* touches on the Aristotelian distinction between form and matter, a central tenet of his metaphysical system. For Aristotle, while form gives things their identity and intelligibility, matter is merely the substrate in which form is instantiated. Thus, when defining a substance, one refers to its form rather than its matter, as form provides the essence or nature of the thing. In contrast, Neoplatonism emphasizes the primacy of the immaterial over the material, with higher realities being defined by their separation from matter. Pico aligns this Aristotelian principle with the Neoplatonic view by asserting that definitions, even those concerned with natural philosophy, do not include matter. For Pico, the essence of a thing is found in its intelligible form, which is ultimately rooted in the divine intellect, a concept that mirrors the Neoplatonic idea of forms as existing in the realm of the intelligible. By synthesizing these ideas, Pico affirms that true knowledge and understanding involve focusing on the immaterial aspects of reality rather than its material components. ### 7. Conclusion I.18.4: Deus nec mala: nec privationes intelligit. *(God does not understand evils or privations.)* This *Conclusion* speaks to the theological issue of how God, who is omniscient, relates to evil and privation. In Aristotle’s metaphysics, God, as the Prime Mover, is purely actual and entirely good. As such, God only contemplates the good and the true; evil, as a privation of good, is not an entity in itself and is thus outside of God’s direct cognition. Similarly, Neoplatonism views evil as the absence of being, a privation that occurs as entities descend from the One into the multiplicity of the material world. Pico’s synthesis here builds on both traditions by asserting that God does not "understand" evil, as evil is not a positive entity but a lack of good or being. This reflects both Aristotle's and Neoplatonism's positions on the nature of evil. For Pico, God’s understanding is directed toward the realm of the good and the intelligible; anything outside of that, including privations and defects, does not fall within God’s comprehension. By blending Aristotelian metaphysical concepts with Neoplatonic emanation theory, Pico offers a theological synthesis that emphasizes God’s perfection and the ontological deficiency of evil. ### 8. Conclusion I.18.6: Cum dicit Aristoteles nono Methaphysicae separata et divina: aut totaliter sciri a nobis: aut totaliter ignorari: intelligen|dum est de ea cognitione quae his contingit qui iam ad summam intellectus actuationem pervenerunt. *(When Aristotle says in *Metaphysics* IX that separate and divine things are either totally known by us or totally unknown, this must be understood of that cognition which comes to those who have reached the highest actualization of the intellect.)* In this *Conclusion*, Pico refers to Aristotle's *Metaphysics*, where he distinguishes between human knowledge and divine knowledge. Aristotle argues that divine things are either completely knowable or entirely beyond human comprehension, depending on the intellectual state of the knower. Only those who have achieved the highest level of intellectual activity—what Aristotle calls *nous poietikos* (the active intellect)—can truly grasp these separate and divine entities. Pico’s interpretation of this passage shows his engagement with both Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought. The notion of reaching "the highest actualization of the intellect" echoes the Neoplatonic theme of intellectual ascent. For Pico, the highest form of knowledge involves a mystical union with the divine, where the soul transcends the limitations of human cognition and partakes in divine understanding. While Aristotle's focus is on intellectual actualization through philosophical contemplation, Pico extends this into the Neoplatonic realm of mystical ascent, where the highest knowledge is not just intellectual but also metaphysical and spiritual. Thus, Pico harmonizes Aristotle's theory of knowledge with the Neoplatonic emphasis on the soul’s ascent toward unity with the divine. ### 9. Conclusion I.18.7: Sicut primus intellectus inter omnes intellectus primo se intelligit: alia secundario: ita ultimus intellectus inter omnes intellectus primo alia a se: et seipsum secundario intelligit. *(Just as the first intellect among all intellects first understands itself and other things secondarily, so the last intellect among all intellects first understands other things and itself secondarily.)* This *Conclusion* draws on the hierarchical structure of intellects in both Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought. In Aristotle’s system, the highest intellect—God—contemplates itself perfectly, while lower intellects focus on external things. In Neoplatonism, the hierarchy of being and knowing culminates in the One, which is fully self-sufficient and self-contemplating, while lower beings are preoccupied with multiplicity and external objects. Pico synthesizes these views by asserting that the first intellect (the divine) contemplates itself first, while the last intellect (human or material intellect) begins by contemplating external things. This reflects the Aristotelian notion that God, as the highest intellect, is self-sufficient in his self-knowledge, while human intellects are bound by the limitations of sensory knowledge and external reality. However, Pico's Neoplatonic influence is evident in his suggestion that the goal of the soul is to ascend from the contemplation of external things to the higher knowledge of itself and, ultimately, to the divine intellect. Here, Pico integrates the Aristotelian structure of intellectual hierarchy with the Neoplatonic emphasis on the soul’s progression toward self-knowledge and unity with the divine. ### 10. Conclusion I.18.8: Methaphysicus et Dialecticus aeque de omnibus disputant: Sed ille demonstrative hic probabiliter. *(The metaphysician and the dialectician dispute equally about all things, but the former does so demonstratively, the latter probabilistically.)* In this *Conclusion*, Pico differentiates between two methods of reasoning: metaphysical and dialectical. Aristotle himself makes this distinction, noting that metaphysics seeks to demonstrate the fundamental principles of reality with certainty, whereas dialectic operates on probable reasoning, dealing with contingent matters and opinions. Pico’s synthesis involves framing metaphysical inquiry not just as a search for certainty, but also as a means of achieving higher knowledge that leads to divine truth. For Pico, metaphysics is the gateway to the Neoplatonic ascent of the soul, while dialectic is limited to the realm of human reasoning and probability. This distinction mirrors the Neoplatonic divide between intellectual knowledge (which can lead to union with the divine) and the more limited, discursive reasoning found in dialectical or rhetorical practices. In doing so, Pico reinforces his integration of Aristotelian logic and Neoplatonic mysticism, presenting metaphysics as the path to divine union and ultimate truth. ### Conclusion In these *Conclusions*, Pico della Mirandola demonstrates his profound synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought. By weaving together the logical rigor and empirical focus of Aristotle with the metaphysical ascent and spiritual focus of Neoplatonism, Pico constructs a philosophical framework that integrates both systems into a cohesive whole. Whether discussing the immortality of the soul, the nature of divine knowledge, or the hierarchy of intellects, Pico consistently blends Aristotelian clarity with Neoplatonic mysticism, illustrating how these two traditions can coexist and complement each other in the search for truth. This synthesis underscores Pico’s broader project of harmonizing philosophical traditions to reveal the underlying unity of all knowledge and the ultimate goal of the soul’s union with the divine.

conclusiones secundum alber|tum numero .xvi. annotated I.1.1. Species intelligibiles non sunt necessariae: et eas ponere non |est bonis peripateticis consentaneum. annotated I.1.2. Corruptis omnibus individuis speciei humanae est vera. |homo est animal. annotated I.1.3. Haec est in quarto modo dicendi per se. homo est homo. annotated I.1.4. In quolibet puncto materiae sunt per habitum inchoationis |potestativum essentiae omnium formarum naturalium materiae |coeternae secundum philosophos concreate secundum fidem. annotated I.1.5. Forma in intensione et remissione non variatur secundum essentiam |sed secundum esse. annotated I.1.6. Anima separata intelligit per species sibi a principio sui esse con|creatas: quibus dum est in corpore aut nunquam aut raro utitur. annotated I.1.7. Sonus fertur secundum esse reale usque ad principium nervi auditivi. annotated I.1.8. Lumen non habet in medio nisi esse intentionale. annotated I.1.9. Organum auditus est nervus expansus ad concavum auris. annotated I.1.10. Obiectum per se et proprie sensus communis est magnitudo |ut bene dixit Avicenna. annotated I.1.11. Stat speciem cuius dicimur reminisci esse totaliter deperditam |et abolitam. annotated I.1.12. Non introducitur vegetalis anima ante sensualem: nec sensu|alis ante rationalem sed tota simul. annotated I.1.13. Licet ad receptionem speciei concurrat sensus passive ad iudi|candum tamen de sensibili active concurrit. annotated I.1.14. Corpus mobile est subiectum scientiae naturalis. annotated I.1.15. Corporis in eo quod corpus consideratio ad Methaphysicum spectat. annotated I.1.16. Potentia respectiva materiae non addit supra materiam rem |sed rationem.
ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico’s *Conclusiones* According to Albert the Great (Secundum Albertum) ### 1. Conclusion I.1.1: Species intelligibiles non sunt necessariae: et eas ponere non est bonis peripateticis consentaneum. *(Intelligible species are not necessary, and positing them is not consistent with true Peripatetics.)* This conclusion directly challenges a central tenet of Aristotelian epistemology as interpreted by many medieval commentators, including Thomas Aquinas. According to Aristotelian tradition, intelligible species (*species intelligibiles*) are abstract representations of the forms of objects in the intellect, necessary for understanding and cognition. Pico here draws on Albert the Great’s critique, suggesting that such species are not necessary for cognition. This argument aligns more closely with a Neoplatonic view that knowledge can be obtained through direct intellectual apprehension without intermediary forms. Pico’s conclusion reflects a tension between Aristotelian realism (which emphasizes the necessity of intelligible species for cognition) and the Neoplatonic emphasis on the soul’s ability to access intelligible realities directly. By stating that “positing them is not consistent with true Peripatetics,” Pico likely refers to the notion that a more refined Aristotelianism—closer to Albert’s interpretation—should reject unnecessary intermediaries between the intellect and the object of knowledge, thereby aligning with Platonic immediacy. ### 2. Conclusion I.1.2: Corruptis omnibus individuis speciei humanae est vera. Homo est animal. *(Even if all individuals of the human species are destroyed, it is still true that 'man is an animal.')* This conclusion touches on the issue of universals and their existence independent of particular instances. Pico, following Albert, seems to adopt a position that upholds the truth of universal propositions (such as *homo est animal*—“man is an animal”) even if no individual humans exist. This reflects an Aristotelian stance on the persistence of universals as valid propositions even in the absence of their particular instantiations. However, there is also a subtle Neoplatonic influence in this conclusion. The idea that universal truths persist beyond the physical world of individual beings hints at the Platonic notion of forms existing independently of their manifestations in the material world. Pico synthesizes these traditions by suggesting that universal truths, such as “man is an animal,” belong to the realm of the intellect, which transcends the material world and the existence of particular individuals. ### 3. Conclusion I.1.3: Haec est in quarto modo dicendi per se. homo est homo. *(This is in the fourth mode of per se predication: man is man.)* This conclusion refers to the Aristotelian concept of *per se* predication, where something is predicated of itself. In the fourth mode, a thing is predicated of itself because of its essence. Thus, “man is man” is a necessary truth because “man” is defined by the essence of being human. This is a purely Aristotelian concept rooted in the logic of essence and definition. Pico’s reference to this mode of predication shows his engagement with Aristotelian logic, but his broader project of harmonizing Aristotelianism with Neoplatonism is evident here as well. For Neoplatonists, understanding a thing’s essence also involves understanding its connection to higher, intelligible realities. By invoking this form of predication, Pico hints at the deeper metaphysical truth that underlies the essence of being human—a truth that, for him, ultimately connects to the divine and the intelligible realm of the One. ### 4. Conclusion I.1.4: In quolibet puncto materiae sunt per habitum inchoationis potestativum essentiae omnium formarum naturalium materiae coeternae secundum philosophos concreate secundum fidem. *(In every point of matter, there is the habitual potential for the essence of all natural forms: according to the philosophers, this is co-created with matter, but according to faith, it is eternal.)* Here, Pico engages with a metaphysical question concerning the nature of matter and form. According to this conclusion, every point of matter contains the potential for all natural forms, suggesting a dynamic and potent view of matter as imbued with the potentiality for various forms. The distinction between the philosophers’ view and that of faith mirrors the distinction between an Aristotelian understanding of matter and form, where form actualizes the potential in matter, and a Christian view of creation, where matter and form are created by God and thus bear a divine imprint. Pico’s synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought is evident here. From an Aristotelian perspective, matter is pure potentiality that requires form to become actual. However, Pico introduces a Neoplatonic interpretation, suggesting that matter itself is imbued with a kind of divine potentiality—a creative force that emanates from the divine source. By referring to the philosophers and to faith, Pico hints at a dual understanding of creation: one grounded in natural philosophy and the other in theology. ### 5. Conclusion I.1.5: Forma in intensione et remissione non variatur secundum essentiam sed secundum esse. *(Form, in its intensification and diminution, does not vary in essence but in being.)* This conclusion addresses the distinction between form and existence, a key issue in both Aristotelian and Neoplatonic metaphysics. For Aristotle, form is the essence of a thing, while *esse* (being) refers to the actual existence of that thing in the world. Pico adopts this distinction, arguing that a form does not change in its essence but only in its being. In other words, a form can be more or less instantiated in the material world, but its essence remains unchanged. Pico’s synthesis becomes apparent when we consider the Neoplatonic view of forms as emanating from the divine. In Neoplatonism, forms exist in the intelligible realm and emanate into the material world. As they descend, their instantiation in matter can vary in intensity (as they are more or less realized), but their essence remains unchanged in the intelligible realm. Pico integrates this Neoplatonic idea with Aristotelian metaphysics, suggesting that while forms may vary in their manifestation in the material world, their essence remains constant and rooted in the divine. ### Conclusion These first five *Conclusiones* *secundum Albertum* illustrate Pico’s attempt to harmonize Aristotelian and Neoplatonic metaphysical concepts. He draws on Aristotelian notions of form, matter, and predication while simultaneously integrating Neoplatonic ideas of intellectual ascent, divine emanation, and the persistence of universals beyond the material world. This synthesis allows Pico to engage with both traditions in a way that seeks to reveal the deeper metaphysical unity underlying their apparent differences. As we continue to examine Pico’s *Conclusiones*, this project of harmonization between the two great schools of thought will continue to unfold.

conclusiones secundum fran|ciscum numeru .viii. annotated I.3.1. Ideo haec est falsa. Essentia generat: quia essentia est ultimate |abstracta et generat formaliter praedicatur. annotated I.3.2. Potest videri essentia sine personis: et una persona sine alia. annotated I.3.3. Voluntas potest non frui ostenso obiecto fruibili. annotated I.3.4. Ens denominative dicitur de deo. annotated I.3.5. Quiditates habent ab aeterno suum esse formale a se non ab |extrinseco. annotated I.3.6. Nulla diffinitio adaequat diffinitum. annotated I.3.7. Pluralitas formalitatum stat cum idemptitate reali. annotated I.3.8. Esse non est de quiditate dei: Sed dicitur de eo in secundo modo.
ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico’s *Conclusiones* According to Francis of Meyronnes (Secundum Franciscum) ### 1. Conclusion I.3.1: Ideo haec est falsa. Essentia generat: quia essentia est ultimate abstracta et generat formaliter praedicatur. *(Thus, this is false: "Essence generates" because essence is ultimately abstract and generates formally through predication.)* This conclusion takes aim at a theological and metaphysical issue concerning the role of essence in generation. According to Francis of Meyronnes, a Franciscan theologian and philosopher, essence itself does not generate. Rather, essence is something abstract, which means it does not engage in the act of generation. Generation is typically a function of existence or actualization, and the essence, being abstract, serves as the formal aspect of a being, not its generative cause. Pico, following Meyronnes, critiques the idea that essence could be a productive force. This aligns with an Aristotelian view, where essence is distinct from *esse* (being) or existence. The essence of a thing defines what it is but does not, by itself, cause the thing to exist or generate other beings. In contrast to Neoplatonism, where the One or the Good generates multiplicity through emanation, this Franciscan critique limits essence to a more passive, formal role in the metaphysical structure of beings. ### 2. Conclusion I.3.2: Potest videri essentia sine personis: et una persona sine alia. *(Essence can be seen without the persons, and one person can be seen without the other.)* This conclusion discusses the theological concept of the Trinity, a key area in Christian metaphysics. According to Christian doctrine, God is one essence (ousia) but exists in three distinct persons (Father, Son, and Holy Spirit). Here, Meyronnes holds that it is possible to understand or “see” the divine essence without necessarily engaging with the individual persons of the Trinity. Additionally, it is possible to understand one person of the Trinity without the other two. Pico’s engagement with this conclusion reflects his broader project of integrating scholastic theology with Neoplatonic thought. The notion that essence can be abstracted from the persons in this conclusion emphasizes a metaphysical distinction similar to the distinction between the One and the Many in Neoplatonism. In both cases, the essence (or One) is beyond any particular manifestation (or person), suggesting that God’s essence, like the Neoplatonic One, transcends its particular expressions. ### 3. Conclusion I.3.3: Voluntas potest non frui ostenso obiecto fruibili. *(The will can choose not to enjoy a presented enjoyable object.)* This conclusion addresses free will and the capacity for moral choice. Meyronnes, in this conclusion, suggests that the human will can choose not to take pleasure in or “enjoy” an object that is presented as desirable or enjoyable. This reflects the voluntarist emphasis in Franciscan thought, which holds that the will is the ultimate determiner of action, even when the intellect presents an object as good or desirable. For Pico, this is significant in the context of his broader interest in human freedom and the dignity of choice. In the *Oration*, Pico famously asserts that humans are capable of determining their own nature, and this conclusion reflects that same voluntarist ethos. The will’s ability to choose contrary to the intellect’s presentation of a good object echoes Pico’s view that human beings have a unique freedom to transcend both reason and desire, aiming for a higher form of existence. ### 4. Conclusion I.3.4: Ens denominative dicitur de deo. *(Being is predicated of God denominatively.)* This conclusion touches on the relationship between God and being, a central theme in medieval metaphysics. To say that “being” is predicated of God denominatively means that God is not being in a straightforward, univocal sense but that being is attributed to God in a way that is qualitatively different from how it is predicated of creatures. This aligns with the scholastic understanding of *analogia entis* (the analogy of being), where God’s being is understood to be of a fundamentally different order than that of created beings. Pico’s acceptance of this conclusion indicates his willingness to work within the framework of scholastic metaphysics, while also synthesizing it with Neoplatonic ideas about the transcendent nature of the One or the Good, which stands above being. For both traditions, God (or the One) is beyond being as we understand it, and being can only be predicated of God in a qualified, analogical sense. ### 5. Conclusion I.3.5: Quiditates habent ab aeterno suum esse formale a se non ab extrinseco. *(Quiddities have their formal being from eternity, from themselves and not from something external.)* In this conclusion, Pico follows Meyronnes in asserting that quiddities (the essential whatness of things) possess their formal being from eternity. This means that the essence of a thing—its defining nature—exists eternally and is not derived from something external. This reflects a Platonic view of forms or essences, where they are eternal and self-subsistent, existing independently of the material world. However, there is also an Aristotelian influence here, particularly in the distinction between formal and actual being. While the essence of a thing may be eternal and intrinsic to itself, its actual existence in the world depends on external factors (such as matter or an efficient cause). Pico’s synthesis of these two traditions is evident in this conclusion: the eternal, self-subsistent nature of essences aligns with Platonism, while the distinction between formal and actual being reflects an Aristotelian emphasis on the importance of material instantiation. ### Conclusion These first five *Conclusiones* *secundum Franciscum* illustrate Pico’s engagement with and synthesis of both Aristotelian and Platonic traditions, particularly as mediated through the thought of Francis of Meyronnes. Pico engages with complex theological and metaphysical issues, including the nature of essence and being, the will’s freedom, and the distinction between God’s essence and created beings. Throughout these conclusions, Pico seeks to harmonize scholastic theology and metaphysics with Neoplatonic ideas, revealing the underlying unity of these seemingly disparate traditions. This synthesis allows Pico to explore both the intellectual structure of the universe and the moral freedom of human beings in a way that is deeply rooted in both traditions, but also original in its combination of them.

conclusiones secundum ioha|nem scotum numero .xxii. annotated I.4.1. Charitas non est distinctus habitus ab habitu gratiae quo me|diante spiritus sanctus animam inhabitat. annotated I.4.2. Idea lapidis non est aliud quam lapis productus a divino intellectu |in esse intelligibili quod est esse secundum quid existens in mente divi|na sicut cognitum in cognoscente. annotated I.4.3. Qui dixerit personas in divinis absolutis proprietatibus di|stingui: catholicae veritati non repugnabit. annotated I.4.4. In Christo fuerunt duo esse. annotated I.4.5. Praxis est operatio alterius potentiae ab intellectu apta nata |conformiter elici rationi rectae ad hoc ut sit recta. annotated I.4.6. Unumquodque individuum est individuum per propriam diffe|rentiam individualem quae dicitur hecheitas. annotated I.4.7. Ens dicitur de deo et creatura univoce in quid. annotated I.4.8. Ens de suis passionibus et ultimis differentiis quiditative non |praedicatur. annotated I.4.9. In Christo non fuit scientia acquisita. annotated I.4.10. In appetitu superiore ponende sunt virtutes. annotated I.4.11. Gratia est subiective in voluntate non in essentia animae. annotated I.4.12. Corpus Christi ex se fuit inpassibile. annotated I.4.13. De potentia dei absoluta possibile est culpam originalem de|leri sine infusione gratiae. annotated I.4.14. Post passionem Christi potuerunt cerimonialia veteris legis |sine peccato observari. annotated I.4.15. Per haec verba precise (Hoc est corpus meum) non expressis |verbis precedentibus. scilicet pridie quam pateretur: non potest conse|crari. annotated I.4.16. Relatio creaturae ad deum est idem realiter fundamento: di|stincta formaliter et ex natura rei. annotated I.4.17. Quaelibet alia relatio a fundamento realiter distinguitur. annotated I.4.18. Aliquid potest movere seipsum de actu virtuali ad actum for|malem. annotated I.4.19. Actus intelligendi ab obiecto et intellectu tanquam duobus agen|tibus partialibus: ut quod causatur. annotated I.4.20. Actus intelligendi nobiliori modo causatur ab intellectu quam ab |obiecto quodcunque sit obiectum: modo non sit beatificum. annotated I.4.21. Substantia non cognoscitur per speciem propriam. annotated I.4.22. Habitus actum producit ut causa partialis effectiva.
ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico’s *Conclusiones* According to John Duns Scotus (Secundum Ioannem Scotum) ### 1. Conclusion I.4.1: Charitas non est distinctus habitus ab habitu gratiae quo mediante spiritus sanctus animam inhabitat. *(Charity is not a distinct habit from the habit of grace through which the Holy Spirit inhabits the soul.)* In this conclusion, Pico follows Duns Scotus in addressing the nature of *charitas* (charity) and its relationship to *gratia* (grace). Scotus argues that charity is not a separate, distinct habit but rather the same as the habit of grace. The Holy Spirit inhabits the soul through grace, and charity is simply the way this grace is expressed in action. This distinction reflects a key aspect of Scotist theology, which focuses on the unity of virtues under the influence of grace. For Pico, this unity has implications for his broader metaphysical synthesis, as it points toward the unity of divine action and the relationship between the human soul and divine influence. In Neoplatonic terms, this unity of grace and charity could be seen as reflecting the One’s emanation of all virtues, in which distinctions between virtues are less important than their shared source. ### 2. Conclusion I.4.2: Idea lapidis non est aliud quam lapis productus a divino intellectu in esse intelligibili quod est esse secundum quid existens in mente divina sicut cognitum in cognoscente. *(The idea of a stone is nothing other than the stone produced by the divine intellect in intelligible being, which is a kind of being existing in the divine mind, as known by the knower.)* This conclusion touches on a key metaphysical issue concerning the nature of ideas and their existence in the divine intellect. Scotus holds that the idea of a stone (or any object) is not something distinct from the stone itself but is the stone as it exists in the divine intellect. The stone, as a created being, exists first in the divine mind in an intelligible way, and this intelligible being is what constitutes its essence. Pico’s embrace of this conclusion aligns with his broader synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought. In Aristotelian terms, the form of the stone is what gives it intelligibility, while in Neoplatonism, the stone’s existence in the divine intellect reflects the emanation of all forms from the One. This conclusion helps to bridge the gap between the two traditions by emphasizing that the forms of things exist primarily in the divine intellect and are actualized in the material world. ### 3. Conclusion I.4.3: Qui dixerit personas in divinis absolutis proprietatibus distingui: catholicae veritati non repugnabit. *(Whoever says that the persons in the divine are distinguished by absolute properties does not contradict Catholic truth.)* This conclusion deals with the theological concept of the Trinity and the distinction between the persons of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. According to Scotus, the persons of the Trinity can be distinguished by absolute properties, such as the Father’s unbegottenness, the Son’s begottenness, and the Holy Spirit’s procession. This does not contradict Catholic truth, as these distinctions are necessary to maintain the doctrine of the Trinity without collapsing the persons into one. Pico’s acceptance of this conclusion reflects his effort to integrate scholastic theology with a more metaphysical approach. The distinction between persons in the divine, for Pico, mirrors the way that Neoplatonists distinguish between the One and the many. The divine persons are distinct yet unified, just as all multiplicity in the cosmos is unified in the One. This synthesis allows Pico to preserve the distinctions within the Trinity while also maintaining the overarching unity of divine being. ### 4. Conclusion I.4.4: In Christo fuerunt duo esse. *(In Christ, there were two beings.)* This conclusion deals with Christology, specifically the nature of Christ as both fully divine and fully human. Scotus held that in Christ, there are two distinct modes of being: one divine and one human. This is necessary to preserve the doctrine of the Incarnation, in which Christ is both true God and true man. These two natures are united in the person of Christ, but they retain their distinct modes of being. Pico’s engagement with this conclusion illustrates his attempt to reconcile the theological and metaphysical implications of Christology. In a Neoplatonic framework, the dual being of Christ can be understood as reflecting the tension between unity and multiplicity. Christ, as the Logos, mediates between the One and the material world, embodying both divine unity and the multiplicity of creation. ### 5. Conclusion I.4.5: Praxis est operatio alterius potentiae ab intellectu apta nata conformiter elici rationi rectae ad hoc ut sit recta. *(Practice is an operation of a power other than the intellect, conforming to right reason in order to be just.)* This conclusion concerns the relationship between intellect and action. Scotus argues that practice or action is the operation of a power distinct from the intellect, but it must conform to right reason in order to be just or correct. This reflects a voluntarist view in Scotist thought, where the will plays a crucial role in determining action, guided by the intellect but not identical with it. For Pico, this conclusion speaks to the broader issue of human freedom and the relationship between reason and will. In his *Oration on the Dignity of Man*, Pico emphasizes the importance of human freedom in shaping one’s own nature, and this conclusion reflects the same idea. Action, while guided by reason, is ultimately a function of the will, and it is through right action that humans can ascend toward the divine. ### Conclusion These five *Conclusiones* *secundum Ioannem Scotum* illustrate Pico’s engagement with key aspects of Scotist theology, including the nature of grace and charity, the existence of ideas in the divine intellect, the distinction between the persons of the Trinity, the dual nature of Christ, and the relationship between intellect and action. Pico’s synthesis of Aristotelian, Neoplatonic, and scholastic thought is evident in his approach to these conclusions, as he seeks to harmonize the distinctions and unities found in each tradition. By drawing on Scotus’s theology, Pico is able to explore the metaphysical and theological implications of Christian doctrine in a way that is both deeply traditional and highly original.

Continuing the analysis I’m tasked with completing the close reading of annotated conclusions by John Duns Scotus, ensuring accuracy and quality throughout the process. Piecing together I’m gathering the remaining conclusions, each one dissecting theological concepts like charity, divine ideas, and the dual nature of Christ. This points to a structured theological discussion unfolding. Examining theological concepts I’m analyzing Thomistic theology, focusing on the essence of individuality, divine attributes, and the role of grace in the human will, particularly regarding Christ's nature and sacramental theology. Analyzing the process I’m examining the method of how a habit produces an act as a partial effective cause. This expands our understanding of causal relations. Connecting concepts I’m mapping out Duns Scotus's idea of *haecceity*, which identifies the unique individuality of each entity without any conceptual reference. This builds upon the foundation of individuation. Piecing together individuation Pico integrates Scotist metaphysics, highlighting individuation through *haecceity* for immaterial beings like angels, surpassing Aristotle's matter-based individuation. Charting the conceptual terrain I’m working through the Neoplatonic hierarchy, considering how individualities, material and immaterial, each occupy a unique cosmic space. Examining metaphysical insights I’m delving into how the concept of 'being' bridges finite and infinite realms, aligning with Neoplatonic ideas. Connecting metaphysics Interestingly, Scotus's metaphysics highlights how being transcends its properties, reflecting Neoplatonic ideas about the ineffability of the One beyond all definitions. Connecting virtue and intellect Pico’s alignment with Christ’s divine and human nature highlights his belief in the human soul’s potential. He finds virtues in the rational will, bridging divine truths and human moral intention. Placing grace Pico’s conclusion highlights that grace specifically resides within the will, emphasizing moral and spiritual growth through the rational will. Connecting divine principles I'm working through Pico's viewpoint on the soul's ascent via harmonizing the will with the divine, emphasizing the interplay between human freedom and divine grace in achieving spiritual perfection. Examining God's absolute power Scotus explores God's absolute power—the ability to remove original sin without grace infusion. This showcases his belief in God's omnipotence beyond the usual order. Reflecting on divine power Pico's acceptance explores divine omnipotence, sparking theological questions about salvation and grace, especially in post-Christ Passion ceremonial observances. This transition from Old to New Covenant is particularly intriguing. Ensuring validity Pico's work aims to synthesize religious traditions, highlighting a valid Eucharistic consecration with a textual narrative context, showing progress in his overarching divine truth framework. Connecting ritual to spirituality Pico highlights ritual's central role in achieving spiritual effects, which seems to align with Neoplatonic and Hermetic traditions. Clarifying divine-creation relationship Scotus uniquely emphasizes the divine creation relationship, distinguishing it from other relations, which are genuinely distinct from their foundations. This underscores the unique nature of the divine-creation connection. Charting self-movement Scotus asserts that beings can shift from potentiality to actuality, mirroring views on the soul and free will. This aligns with both Aristotelian and Neoplatonic ideas. Understanding and interaction Scotus views cognition as stemming from the interplay between the object and the intellect, suggesting a dynamic relation between Aristotelian epistemology and Neoplatonic metaphysics. Highlighting the intellect's prime role Reiterating that understanding occurs nobly through the intellect, except in the beatific vision, which uniquely bestows intuitive knowledge of God to the blessed. Grasping knowledge limits Pico engages with the idea that understanding substance essence is indirect, aligning with human knowledge limitations and the necessity of divine grace for the highest knowledge. Examining clarity Pico suggests that reason and perception can't fully grasp things, advocating for mystical insight to achieve deeper understanding. Understanding Pico della Mirandola's conclusions I’m working through how Pico della Mirandola incorporates John Duns Scotus's metaphysical and theological ideas, like *haecceity* and the univocity of being, into his synthesis with Aristotelian and Neoplatonic traditions.
ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico’s *Conclusiones* According to John Duns Scotus (Secundum Ioannem Scotum) - Continued ### 6. Conclusion I.4.6: Unumquodque individuum est individuum per propriam differentiam individualem quae dicitur hecheitas. *(Each individual is an individual through its own individual difference, which is called 'haecceity.')* This conclusion addresses Scotus's doctrine of *haecceitas*, or "thisness," a key feature in his metaphysical framework. Scotus posited that each individual entity is distinct from every other not merely by its form or matter but by its unique *haecceitas*, a specific property that makes an individual "this" particular thing and not another. In the context of beings, this *haecceitas* accounts for individuality in a metaphysical sense, distinct from common natures shared by a species. Pico’s agreement with this conclusion reflects his attempt to reconcile Aristotelian and Platonic metaphysics with Christian thought. While Aristotelian thought focuses on the general forms or species of things, the Scotist notion of *haecceitas* emphasizes the particularity and uniqueness of each being. In a Platonic sense, Pico might see *haecceitas* as reflecting the uniqueness of each soul's journey toward the divine, distinguishing the individual ascent within the broader structure of emanation from the One. ### 7. Conclusion I.4.7: Ens dicitur de deo et creatura univoce in quid. *(Being is said of God and creature univocally in regard to essence.)* This is a cornerstone of Scotus’s metaphysics, known as the doctrine of the univocity of being. Scotus argued that the concept of being applies in the same sense to both God and creatures, though God’s being is infinite and creatures’ being is finite. In contrast to the Thomistic view, where being is said analogously between God and creatures, Scotus’s view allows for a more direct relation between divine and created being. Pico’s acceptance of this conclusion underscores his broader project of finding harmony between Aristotelian and Neoplatonic metaphysics. In Neoplatonism, all beings emanate from the One, and the univocity of being allows for a continuity between divine and created being without collapsing the two into an indistinct unity. For Pico, this conclusion aligns with his vision of the ascent of the soul, where creatures, through intellectual and spiritual effort, can ascend toward the divine while maintaining their distinct essence. ### 8. Conclusion I.4.8: Ens de suis passionibus et ultimis differentiis quiditative non praedicatur. *(Being is not predicated of its attributes and ultimate differences in a quidditative sense.)* This conclusion delves into the relationship between being and its attributes or accidents. Scotus holds that being itself cannot be predicated in a strict quidditative (definitional or essential) sense of its attributes, such as existence, duration, or location. Instead, these are secondary to being and do not constitute its essence. Pico’s engagement with this conclusion points to his nuanced understanding of metaphysical distinctions. By separating being from its accidents, Pico preserves the transcendence and purity of the concept of being. In a Neoplatonic framework, this allows for the existence of multiple layers of reality—intelligible and sensible—where being is manifest in various ways, but its essence remains untouched by its contingent attributes. This ties into Pico’s broader project of exploring the relationship between finite beings and the divine, emphasizing the metaphysical separation even within apparent unity. ### 9. Conclusion I.4.9: In Christo non fuit scientia acquisita. *(In Christ, there was no acquired knowledge.)* This conclusion is a Christological statement that reflects Scotus’s belief that Christ, being divine, did not possess acquired knowledge in the way human beings do. Since Christ was fully united with the divine intellect, his knowledge was infused, meaning that he did not learn through experience but already possessed perfect knowledge. For Pico, this conclusion has significant implications for his synthesis of theology and metaphysics. The distinction between acquired knowledge and infused knowledge parallels the Neoplatonic distinction between lower, discursive knowledge and higher, intuitive knowledge that is received directly from the divine. In Pico’s vision, the soul, in its ascent toward God, moves from discursive reasoning (acquired knowledge) to a higher, more direct form of understanding, akin to the divine knowledge that Christ possesses. ### 10. Conclusion I.4.10: In appetitu superiore ponende sunt virtutes. *(In the higher appetite, virtues are to be placed.)* This conclusion pertains to the location of virtues within the human faculties. Scotus argues that virtues are located in the higher appetite, meaning the rational will. This follows the traditional view that virtues are habits of the will, which guide action in accordance with reason. Pico’s embrace of this conclusion ties into his broader concern with human moral and intellectual perfection. For Pico, the rational will, guided by virtue, is the means by which the soul ascends to the divine. In Neoplatonic thought, the virtues represent stages along the ascent of the soul, with higher virtues reflecting a greater alignment with the divine will. By placing virtues in the higher appetite, Pico emphasizes the role of rational and moral discipline in the soul’s journey toward God. ### Conclusion In these additional *Conclusiones* *secundum Ioannem Scotum*, Pico continues to engage with Scotist theology in a way that supports his larger metaphysical synthesis. The concepts of *haecceitas*, the univocity of being, the distinction between being and its attributes, and the Christological doctrine of infused knowledge all serve to illuminate Pico’s vision of a harmonious metaphysical and theological system. By drawing on Scotus, Pico deepens his exploration of the relationship between individual beings and the divine, the nature of knowledge, and the role of virtues in human perfection. This synthesis, which integrates Aristotelian, Neoplatonic, and Christian thought, remains central to Pico’s broader philosophical project.

ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico’s *Conclusiones* According to John Duns Scotus (Secundum Ioannem Scotum) - Continued ### 11. Conclusion I.4.11: Gratia est subiective in voluntate non in essentia animae. *(Grace is subjectively in the will, not in the essence of the soul.)* This conclusion draws on Scotus’s understanding of the nature of grace and its interaction with human faculties. For Scotus, grace operates within the will rather than within the essence of the soul itself. This distinction is important in maintaining the autonomy of the human will while allowing divine grace to influence it directly. The will remains the locus of moral decision-making, and grace strengthens the will to choose the good without overriding its freedom. Pico’s acceptance of this conclusion fits neatly within his synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought. The focus on the will as the seat of grace aligns with Pico’s broader project of emphasizing human moral agency and the capacity for self-transformation through the exercise of free will. In the Neoplatonic ascent to God, the soul must exert effort through the will to purify itself and ascend toward the divine. Grace, in this context, aids in this ascent but does not eliminate the need for human participation in the process. ### 12. Conclusion I.4.12: Corpus Christi ex se fuit inpassibile. *(The body of Christ, by itself, was impassible.)* This conclusion pertains to the Christological doctrine of the impassibility of Christ’s body. Scotus maintained that, by nature, Christ’s body was not subject to suffering or decay, due to its union with the divine. However, Christ could suffer through the voluntary acceptance of human limitations and the conditions of his earthly existence, particularly in the context of the Passion. Pico’s engagement with this conclusion highlights his commitment to preserving the dual nature of Christ—both fully human and fully divine. In the context of his broader metaphysical synthesis, the impassibility of Christ’s body can be understood as reflecting the Neoplatonic idea of the divine being beyond the reach of material corruption or suffering. Christ’s ability to voluntarily assume suffering points to the idea that the divine can descend into the material world without being diminished, much like how the One in Neoplatonism can give rise to multiplicity without losing its unity or purity. ### 13. Conclusion I.4.13: De potentia dei absoluta possibile est culpam originalem deleri sine infusione gratiae. *(By the absolute power of God, it is possible for original sin to be removed without the infusion of grace.)* This conclusion reflects a subtle aspect of Scotus’s theology, where he posits that, theoretically, God’s absolute power could have removed original sin without the infusion of grace. However, in practice, God has chosen to work through grace as the means of redemption. This idea preserves the omnipotence of God while also respecting the established theological order of salvation. Pico’s acceptance of this conclusion fits into his larger framework of exploring divine freedom and the relationship between divine action and the created order. The hypothetical scenario of original sin being removed without grace speaks to Pico’s interest in the ways God could operate beyond the constraints of established theological norms. In a Neoplatonic context, this reflects the tension between the divine as utterly transcendent and the divine’s interaction with the world of matter and imperfection. Pico uses this concept to explore the idea that divine intervention can manifest in ways beyond human understanding or expectation. ### 14. Conclusion I.4.14: Post passionem Christi potuerunt cerimonialia veteris legis sine peccato observari. *(After the Passion of Christ, the ceremonial laws of the Old Testament could be observed without sin.)* This conclusion addresses the relationship between the Old Covenant and the New Covenant after the Passion of Christ. Scotus maintained that, following Christ’s fulfillment of the Law, it was theoretically possible for the ceremonial practices of the Old Testament to continue without constituting sin. However, they were no longer necessary for salvation, as Christ’s sacrifice had superseded the need for the old rites. Pico’s agreement with this conclusion reflects his broader engagement with the continuity and discontinuity between the Jewish and Christian traditions. In his synthesis of Christian Platonism and Kabbalistic thought, Pico often sought to highlight the ways in which pre-Christian religious practices contained hidden truths that were fulfilled and clarified in Christianity. This conclusion supports Pico’s view that the Old Testament laws had value in their time but were ultimately transcended by the higher spiritual truths revealed in Christ. The ceremonial laws can be seen as lower rungs on the Neoplatonic ladder of ascent, which are surpassed but not necessarily invalidated by higher stages of spiritual development. ### 15. Conclusion I.4.15: Per haec verba precise (Hoc est corpus meum) non expressis verbis precedentibus. scilicet pridie quam pateretur: non potest consecrari. *(By these words alone (This is my body), without the words that precede it (On the night before He suffered), the consecration cannot take place.)* This conclusion deals with the sacrament of the Eucharist and the specific formula required for consecration. According to Scotus, the words “This is my body” must be preceded by the full context of the institution of the Eucharist, as given by Christ at the Last Supper. The formula is essential for the sacrament’s validity, ensuring that it follows the tradition established by Christ. Pico’s engagement with this conclusion reveals his interest in the precise nature of sacramental theology and its relationship to divine power. In a broader metaphysical sense, the ritual words of consecration can be seen as akin to the Neoplatonic process of emanation, where specific actions or words participate in the unfolding of divine power into the material world. The consecration of the Eucharist mirrors the way that divine essence can be made manifest in the material realm, a key theme in Pico’s synthesis of theology and metaphysics. ### Conclusion These additional *Conclusiones* *secundum Ioannem Scotum* further illustrate Pico’s deep engagement with Scotist theology and his broader metaphysical project. The discussions of grace, Christ’s nature, the ceremonial laws, and sacramental theology provide Pico with a framework for exploring the relationship between divine action, human participation in the divine, and the metaphysical structure of reality. By drawing on Scotus, Pico is able to integrate a nuanced understanding of individuality, divine omnipotence, and the role of ritual in his synthesis of Christian Platonism, Kabbalistic mysticism, and Aristotelian thought. This synthesis, which harmonizes diverse traditions while preserving their distinct insights, remains at the core of Pico’s intellectual enterprise.
You
continue
ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico’s *Conclusiones* According to John Duns Scotus (Secundum Ioannem Scotum) - Continued ### 16. Conclusion I.4.16: Relatio creaturae ad deum est idem realiter fundamento: distincta formaliter et ex natura rei. *(The relation of the creature to God is really the same as its foundation, but formally distinct and by the nature of things.)* This conclusion touches on Scotus’s doctrine of formal distinction, which allows for real distinctions within a being that are not separable in essence. Here, the relation of the creature to God is identified as being really the same as its foundation, meaning that the creature’s existence depends fundamentally on God. However, it is formally distinct from the divine essence. This allows for a metaphysical connection between creation and Creator while preserving the transcendence and immutability of God. Pico’s engagement with this conclusion fits into his broader synthesis of Aristotelian metaphysics and Neoplatonic emanation. For Pico, the relationship between God and creation reflects a dynamic of emanation and return. Creation is dependent on God as its source, yet it maintains a formal distinction to allow for multiplicity within the unity of the divine. The conclusion supports Pico’s idea that all creatures, though distinct from God, reflect the divine essence and participate in the unfolding of divine will. ### 17. Conclusion I.4.17: Quaelibet alia relatio a fundamento realiter distinguitur. *(Any other relation is really distinct from its foundation.)* Building on the previous conclusion, this statement reinforces the Scotist idea that relations within creatures are really distinct from their foundations. While relations to God may have a metaphysical unity with their foundation, other relations within the realm of creation are more strictly distinct. This distinction is crucial in maintaining the particularity of individuals and their interactions without collapsing them into a single metaphysical entity. Pico’s acceptance of this conclusion reflects his commitment to maintaining the individuality of beings within the Neoplatonic framework of emanation. In his system, the many levels of reality—angels, humans, and the material world—each have their own internal distinctions while remaining part of the greater whole that emanates from the One. This conclusion helps to explain how Pico can accommodate individuality within his broader metaphysical synthesis, respecting both the unity and diversity of creation. ### 18. Conclusion I.4.18: Aliquid potest movere seipsum de actu virtuali ad actum formalem. *(Something can move itself from virtual act to formal act.)* This conclusion speaks to Scotus’s understanding of potentiality and actuality, particularly regarding the self-motion of beings. In this case, a being can move from a state of virtuality (potential) to actuality (formal act) by its own power. This affirms the inherent dynamism of created beings, especially human beings, who have the capacity to actualize their potential through their own actions. Pico’s embrace of this conclusion aligns with his strong emphasis on human dignity and freedom. In his Oration, Pico celebrates the human capacity for self-transformation, a process by which individuals can ascend the ladder of being and reach divine union. This self-motion from potentiality to actuality mirrors the spiritual ascent that Pico advocates, where the soul moves from the material world toward higher levels of being through philosophical and mystical contemplation. ### 19. Conclusion I.4.19: Actus intelligendi ab obiecto et intellectu tanquam duobus agentibus partialibus: ut quod causatur. *(The act of understanding is caused by the object and the intellect as two partial agents.)* In this conclusion, Scotus addresses the interaction between the intellect and the object of understanding, proposing that both contribute as partial agents in the act of cognition. This is part of a broader discussion in medieval philosophy about how knowledge is generated—whether the intellect actively grasps the object, or whether the object imposes itself on the intellect. Pico’s interest in this conclusion reflects his concern with the relationship between the knower and the known, especially in the context of divine knowledge. For Pico, human intellect plays an active role in the apprehension of higher truths, yet those truths themselves (the objects of knowledge) also have a real and independent existence. This mirrors the relationship between the divine mind and creation: while creation exists independently, it is also known and sustained by the divine intellect. ### 20. Conclusion I.4.20: Actus intelligendi nobiliori modo causatur ab intellectu quam ab obiecto quodcunque sit obiectum: modo non sit beatificum. *(The act of understanding is caused in a nobler way by the intellect than by the object, whatever the object may be, so long as it is not the beatific vision.)* This conclusion refines the previous one, asserting that while both the intellect and the object contribute to the act of understanding, the intellect plays the nobler role, except in the case of the beatific vision, where divine grace supersedes human cognitive effort. Scotus here emphasizes the primacy of the intellect in ordinary acts of knowledge, while reserving a special place for divine intervention in the highest form of understanding. Pico’s acceptance of this conclusion underscores his belief in the transformative power of the intellect in the pursuit of divine knowledge. The intellect, for Pico, is the primary tool through which humans can ascend toward God, but he also acknowledges that the ultimate vision of God (the beatific vision) is beyond the power of human intellect alone and requires divine grace. This dual emphasis on the intellect and divine intervention fits within his broader synthesis of Platonism and Christian mysticism. ### Conclusion These additional *Conclusiones* according to John Duns Scotus further illuminate Pico’s synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought. Through these conclusions, Pico explores crucial themes such as the nature of divine and creaturely relations, the process of self-actualization, and the role of intellect in knowledge acquisition. Scotus’s influence allows Pico to articulate a metaphysical system that harmonizes the independence and distinction of individual beings with their ultimate grounding in the divine. Furthermore, Pico’s commitment to the transformative power of human intellect and will reflects both the Aristotelian emphasis on self-actualization and the Neoplatonic vision of ascent to divine unity. These themes remain central to Pico’s philosophical project, as he seeks to reconcile diverse intellectual traditions into a unified vision of human potential and divine reality.

ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico’s *Conclusiones* According to John Duns Scotus (Secundum Ioannem Scotum) - Continued ### 21. Conclusion I.4.21: Substantia non cognoscitur per speciem propriam. *(Substance is not known through its own species.)* In this conclusion, Scotus denies that a substance can be known through its own specific form or species. Instead, it is understood through a more abstract and mediated process. This is in line with his broader epistemology, where direct cognition of individual substances is limited. Instead, the mind apprehends universal principles or forms and from there, discerns the particular. For Pico, this reflects a key tension in metaphysical knowledge: the distinction between knowing things as they are in themselves (which is ultimately impossible for created intellects) versus knowing them through mediating forms or abstractions. This plays into Pico's broader attempt to harmonize Aristotelian and Platonic approaches to knowledge. The Platonic tradition emphasizes that true knowledge comes from abstract forms, whereas the Aristotelian approach starts from particulars. By aligning with Scotus here, Pico signals that while humans strive to know particulars, their knowledge is inherently mediated, reflecting the Neoplatonic idea of emanation and ascent. ### 22. Conclusion I.4.22: Habitus actum producit ut causa partialis effectiva. *(Habit produces action as a partial efficient cause.)* This conclusion involves the Scholastic discussion of *habitus*, which refers to the disposition or habit that shapes how an individual acts. Scotus holds that habit is a partial cause of action, not the full cause, because the agent still retains an active role in deciding to act. Habits dispose one toward certain actions but do not determine them entirely. Pico’s acceptance of this conclusion ties into his broader ethical and metaphysical concerns with human freedom and intellectual ascent. In his *Oration*, Pico places great emphasis on human freedom and the capacity for self-transformation. This conclusion supports that view by affirming that while habits (such as intellectual virtues or moral dispositions) shape and incline the will, they do not remove human agency. Thus, Pico reinforces his belief that individuals can actively participate in their ascent to divine knowledge by cultivating intellectual and moral virtues, but they remain free agents in this process. ### Interpretation of Pico’s Synthesis Through these last *Conclusiones* from John Duns Scotus, Pico further develops his philosophical synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic ideas: 1. Intellect and Knowledge: The discussion of how the intellect understands substance (without knowing it directly) reflects a synthesis of Aristotelian realism, where particular things exist and are knowable, with Neoplatonic abstraction, where higher realities (forms, ideas) can only be grasped through intellectual ascent. Scotus provides Pico with a model where knowledge of individual substances is indirect, mediated by forms or species. For Pico, this reflects the limits of human intellect in its quest for the divine, echoing the Neoplatonic ascent from the material to the intellectual world. 2. Human Freedom and Virtue: The conclusion on habits as partial efficient causes aligns with Pico’s broader humanistic philosophy, especially in his *Oration*, where he emphasizes human dignity and freedom. While the development of intellectual habits is important for Pico (as seen in his emphasis on intellectual ascent), these habits do not determine human action entirely. Instead, they prepare the will for higher actions, but the ultimate ascent to divine knowledge or mystical union remains within the agent’s control. This reflects an Aristotelian focus on virtue ethics combined with a Neoplatonic vision of spiritual progress. 3. Integration of Scotus’s Metaphysics: Pico's engagement with Scotus’s metaphysics, particularly the formal distinction and the role of habits in action, allows him to construct a metaphysical and ethical framework that balances the independence of individual substances with their ultimate grounding in the divine. This synthesis of Aristotelian metaphysics and Neoplatonic ascent reflects Pico’s goal of uniting the major philosophical traditions into a harmonious whole. ### Conclusion Pico’s close reading of Scotus provides essential elements for his synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought. The Scotist doctrines of formal distinction, the nature of knowledge, and the role of habits in action all contribute to Pico’s broader vision of human intellectual and spiritual ascent. By integrating these insights, Pico constructs a philosophical system that emphasizes both the freedom and dignity of the human intellect while acknowledging the limitations imposed by material existence. This system not only draws from Aristotelian and Neoplatonic traditions but also brings them into dialogue with Scholastic developments, demonstrating Pico’s unique ability to synthesize diverse philosophical schools.
