Irascibilis et concupiscibilis ita distinguuntur in appetitu supe|riori sicut in inferiori. annotated I.5.9. Habere aliquiditativam et diffinibilem realitatem commune |est figmentis et non figmentis. annotated I.5.10. Amicitia est virtus. annotated I.5.11. Ratitudo formaliter cuiuslibet creati est respectus. annotated I.5.12. Ad hoc ut sit mutuitas realis relationis requiritur quod fundamen|tum ex sua natura ordinetur ad aliud tanquam ad suam perfe|ctionem. annotated I.5.13. Relatio non distinguitur a fundamento realiter.
ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico’s *Conclusiones* According to Henry of Ghent (Secundum Henricum Gandavensem) ### 1. Conclusion I.5.1: Datur lumen superius lumine fidei: in quo Theologi vident veritates theologicae scientiae. *(There is a light higher than the light of faith, in which theologians see the truths of theological science.)* This conclusion suggests the existence of a higher form of intellectual illumination beyond the light of faith. Henry of Ghent proposes that this superior light allows theologians to discern theological truths with greater clarity than what is possible through faith alone. Faith provides an initial understanding, but this higher illumination reveals deeper metaphysical realities. For Pico, this conclusion aligns with his vision of the *concordia* of philosophy and theology. It echoes his belief in the ability of the human intellect to ascend beyond simple faith through higher levels of knowledge and understanding. In his *Oration*, Pico describes the soul’s ascent to divine knowledge, which transcends ordinary faith and approaches the divine through theurgy, magic, and philosophical inquiry. By accepting this idea from Henry of Ghent, Pico affirms that theological science, when pursued correctly, can lead to an even greater vision of divine truths. ### 2. Conclusion I.5.2: Paternitas est principium generandi in patre. *(Fatherhood is the principle of generating in the Father.)* This conclusion reflects the metaphysical principle in Christian theology that the Father, as the first person of the Trinity, generates the Son through the relationship of fatherhood. It speaks to the unique property of the Father within Trinitarian theology. Pico’s interest in such metaphysical distinctions in the Trinity reflects his synthesis of Christian thought with Neoplatonism. In Neoplatonic metaphysics, emanation is a central principle, and here Pico draws upon Henry’s articulation of divine generation to show the harmonious relationship between Christian Trinitarian theology and the Neoplatonic concept of emanation. The act of generation mirrors the process by which the One emanates the intelligible world in Neoplatonism, which resonates with Pico’s metaphysical vision in his *Conclusiones*. ### 3. Conclusion I.5.3: Processiones distinguuntur in divinis penes intellectum et voluntatem. *(The processions in God are distinguished by intellect and will.)* Here, Henry of Ghent explains that the processions within the Trinity (i.e., the generation of the Son and the procession of the Holy Spirit) are distinguished by their relationship to the divine intellect and the divine will. The Son proceeds from the Father by way of intellect (as the Word), and the Holy Spirit proceeds by way of will (as the Love between the Father and the Son). For Pico, this theological conclusion is significant because it reflects the synthesis of divine intellect and will as two key metaphysical principles in both Christian and Neoplatonic thought. Pico’s Neoplatonic framework, which emphasizes emanation and return, finds resonance in this conclusion. The intellectual procession (the generation of the Son) mirrors the Neoplatonic idea of emanation from the One, while the will (the procession of the Spirit) aligns with the Neoplatonic notion of return or reversion to the divine. ### 4. Conclusion I.5.4: Ista propositio non est concedenda: essentia est pater filii. *(This proposition is not to be conceded: the essence is the Father of the Son.)* Henry of Ghent rejects the proposition that the divine essence is the Father of the Son, clarifying that it is the person of the Father, not the essence, that generates the Son. This is an important distinction in Trinitarian theology, where essence refers to the shared divine nature of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, while "Father" refers to the specific person who generates the Son. Pico’s engagement with this conclusion shows his commitment to theological precision. While he often sought to harmonize different philosophical traditions, he also recognized the importance of maintaining orthodox distinctions within Christian theology. This conclusion emphasizes the personal relationships within the Trinity, distinct from the shared divine essence, allowing Pico to navigate the delicate balance between Neoplatonic metaphysics (with its focus on the One and its emanations) and Christian theology. ### 5. Conclusion I.5.5: Demones et animae peccatrices patiuntur ab igne in quantum calidus est afflictione eiusdem rationis cum ea qua affliguntur corpora. *(Demons and sinful souls suffer from fire insofar as it is hot, by an affliction of the same kind as that which afflicts bodies.)* In this conclusion, Henry of Ghent posits that demons and sinful souls experience suffering in hellfire in a manner analogous to physical bodies. The fire that afflicts them is of the same nature as the fire that causes physical pain to corporeal beings. This raises theological questions about the nature of spiritual suffering and the interaction between corporeal and incorporeal entities. For Pico, this conclusion might be interpreted through the lens of Neoplatonic metaphysics, where the material and immaterial worlds are closely related through processes of emanation and return. The idea that spiritual entities such as demons and souls can suffer in a manner akin to physical beings suggests a deep interconnection between the material and spiritual realms. In Pico’s metaphysical synthesis, this could be understood as a reflection of the hierarchical structure of being, where lower spiritual entities (such as demons) are closer to the material world and therefore experience suffering in ways analogous to material beings. ### Conclusion These conclusions of Henry of Ghent reflect Pico’s ongoing project of synthesizing Aristotelian, Platonic, and Christian theological thought. Pico draws upon Henry’s careful distinctions within theology and metaphysics to support his broader project of uniting disparate philosophical traditions. In particular, Pico’s synthesis reflects his desire to reconcile the metaphysical principles of Neoplatonism with the theological doctrines of Christianity, especially concerning the Trinity, divine illumination, and the relationship between the material and spiritual worlds.
You
continue
ChatGPT
### 6. Conclusion I.5.6: Operationes angelorum mensurantur tempore discreto. *(The operations of angels are measured by discrete time.)* In this conclusion, Henry of Ghent suggests that angels, although not bound by physical time as humans are, perform actions that can still be measured by discrete, quantifiable moments. This notion challenges the view that angels operate in a purely eternal or timeless state. For Pico, this conclusion about the temporal operations of angels fits within his broader metaphysical synthesis. In Neoplatonic thought, angels (or *intelligences*) are often understood as intermediaries between the purely eternal realm and the temporal, material world. By affirming that angelic actions are measured in discrete time, Pico seems to support the idea that angels serve as a bridge between the eternal and the temporal. This allows him to synthesize Aristotelian views of causality and temporality with the more metaphysical, transcendent perspectives of Platonism, in which angels play a crucial intermediary role in the hierarchical cosmos. ### 7. Conclusion I.5.7: Angeli intelligunt per habitum scientialem sibi connaturalem. *(Angels understand through a scientific habit that is connatural to them.)* Here, Henry of Ghent proposes that angels possess an innate, habitual form of knowledge that is inherent to their nature. Unlike humans, who acquire knowledge discursively and through learning, angels have direct and immediate access to knowledge. For Pico, this conclusion reinforces the hierarchical nature of beings in his synthesis of Christian Neoplatonism. In his *Oration*, Pico speaks of the potential for humans to ascend through intellectual and spiritual exercises, ultimately approaching the divine nature of angels. The idea that angels possess a form of knowledge that is natural to their being illustrates the perfection of angelic intellect and serves as a model for human intellectual striving. Pico uses such conclusions to argue for the possibility of human ascent toward the divine, emphasizing the transformative potential of philosophy, magic, and theurgy in achieving this angelic state of knowledge. ### 8. Conclusion I.5.8: Irascibilis et concupiscibilis ita distinguuntur in appetitu superiori sicut in inferiori. *(The irascible and concupiscible faculties are distinguished in the higher appetite as in the lower appetite.)* In this conclusion, Henry of Ghent distinguishes between the irascible (anger-related) and concupiscible (desire-related) faculties of the soul. These faculties operate not only in the lower, bodily appetites but also in the higher, spiritual appetites. Pico’s engagement with this conclusion reflects his interest in the complex interactions between the body, the soul, and the intellect. In both Aristotelian and Platonic frameworks, the soul is understood to possess various faculties or powers that correspond to different aspects of human experience. By affirming the presence of irascible and concupiscible faculties in both the lower and higher appetites, Pico bridges the gap between bodily and spiritual desires, showing that the entire human person is involved in the struggle toward virtue and perfection. This conclusion aligns with his broader metaphysical project, which seeks to integrate the physical and spiritual dimensions of the self in the pursuit of wisdom and divine ascent. ### 9. Conclusion I.5.9: Habere aliquiditativam et diffinibilem realitatem commune est figmentis et non figmentis. *(To have a quidditative and definable reality is common to both figments and non-figments.)* This conclusion touches upon metaphysical and epistemological issues, suggesting that both real entities and imaginary entities (figments) can be said to have a definable reality. While real entities have an actual existence, figments of the imagination can also be said to possess a certain kind of intellectual or conceptual reality. Pico’s interest in this conclusion can be understood in light of his synthesis of Aristotelian and Platonic thought. In Aristotelian metaphysics, the distinction between actual and potential being is central, while in Platonic thought, even abstract forms or ideas possess a form of reality. By accepting this conclusion from Henry of Ghent, Pico blurs the line between intellectual concepts and actual beings, allowing him to explore the role of abstract, non-physical entities—such as angels, divine forms, and even magical symbols—in shaping human understanding of reality. This reflects his broader interest in the metaphysical role of ideas and symbols in the ascent of the soul. ### 10. Conclusion I.5.10: Amicitia est virtus. *(Friendship is a virtue.)* In this simple yet profound conclusion, Henry of Ghent affirms that friendship is not merely a social relationship but a virtue, a moral excellence that is central to ethical life. Pico’s acceptance of this conclusion speaks to his broader philosophical project of *concordia*, or harmony. In both his *Conclusions* and *Oration*, Pico emphasizes the importance of unity, harmony, and concord between different philosophical traditions, as well as within the human soul. Friendship, as a virtue, represents a microcosm of this larger harmony. It is a bond that unites individuals in mutual respect and shared pursuit of the good. For Pico, friendship is not only a personal virtue but also an intellectual and metaphysical ideal, reflecting the harmonious relationships that exist between different levels of reality—from human beings to angels to the divine itself. ### Conclusion These additional conclusions from Henry of Ghent illustrate how Pico drew upon a wide range of metaphysical, theological, and ethical ideas to develop his synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought. By engaging with these specific conclusions, Pico was able to integrate Christian theology, philosophical anthropology, and metaphysical hierarchies into a coherent system that sought to harmonize faith, reason, and mystical ascent. Through his engagement with thinkers like Henry of Ghent, Pico affirmed the possibility of uniting diverse philosophical traditions in the pursuit of divine wisdom.
You
continue
ChatGPT
### 11. Conclusion I.5.11: Ratitudo formaliter cuiuslibet creati est respectus. *(The formal order of any created thing is relational.)* This conclusion proposes that the essence or order of created things is fundamentally defined by their relationships to other things. It highlights the relational aspect of metaphysical order, where the existence and nature of entities depend on their relationships with other beings and the broader cosmic hierarchy. For Pico, this conclusion resonates with the Neoplatonic worldview, where all created beings are understood within a chain of emanation from the One. In this framework, everything is interconnected through a web of relations that ultimately point back to the divine source. By integrating this idea into his synthesis, Pico affirms that understanding the nature of any entity requires seeing it in its context—its relation to other beings, both higher and lower. This relational view is essential for Pico's larger project of harmonizing Aristotelian and Platonic traditions, where metaphysical order is not isolated but woven together through the relations between intellects, souls, angels, and God. ### 12. Conclusion I.5.12: Ad hoc ut sit mutuitas realis relationis requiritur quod fundamentum ex sua natura ordinetur ad aliud tanquam ad suam perfectionem. *(For there to be a real relation of reciprocity, the foundation must by its nature be ordered toward another as its perfection.)* This conclusion delves deeper into the nature of relations, suggesting that a real reciprocal relationship requires that one entity be naturally oriented toward another for its perfection. It highlights the idea of interdependence in the metaphysical order. Pico's embrace of this idea reflects his metaphysical vision of ascent and return. In Neoplatonism, all beings seek to return to the One, the source of all perfection, and their perfection is realized in their alignment with the higher realities. Similarly, Pico’s synthesis sees the human soul as striving for union with the divine, and this reciprocal relationship between the created being and its divine source is central to his metaphysical framework. This conclusion, then, reinforces the notion that true knowledge, ethical life, and metaphysical perfection are all achieved through relational engagement with higher realities, particularly through the soul's ascent toward God. ### 13. Conclusion I.5.13: Relatio non distinguitur a fundamento realiter. *(A relation is not really distinct from its foundation.)* In this conclusion, Henry of Ghent suggests that a relation is not something added on to the entities involved but is instead inseparable from the very nature of those entities. The relation between two beings is part of their essence, not something extrinsic. For Pico, this conclusion underscores his metaphysical commitment to unity and coherence in the cosmos. In his *Oration* and *Conclusions*, Pico often speaks of the interconnectedness of all things and the importance of understanding the divine order as a unified whole. This idea that relations are integral to the essence of things fits well with his Neoplatonic view of the cosmos, where all beings are bound together in a web of relationships that ultimately converge in the One. Pico’s synthesis sees no radical separation between beings and their relations; instead, he views the entire cosmos as a harmonious whole, where each part is defined by its connections to others, leading ultimately to the divine source. ### 14. Conclusion I.5.5: Demones et animae peccatrices patiuntur ab igne in quantum calidus est afflictione eiusdem rationis cum ea qua affliguntur corpora. *(Demons and sinful souls suffer from fire insofar as it is hot, with the same kind of affliction as that which torments bodies.)* This conclusion touches upon the nature of spiritual punishment, suggesting that demons and sinful souls suffer from fire in a way analogous to how bodies experience heat. It suggests that even non-physical beings can experience affliction through physical elements, pointing to a metaphysical connection between the spiritual and material worlds. For Pico, this conclusion speaks to the integration of Aristotelian and Platonic metaphysical frameworks. In Aristotelian natural philosophy, material elements like fire are part of the physical cosmos, while in Platonic metaphysics, the spiritual and material worlds are intertwined through a chain of being. By affirming that spiritual beings can experience physical suffering, Pico bridges the gap between these two frameworks, suggesting that even in the spiritual realm, physical elements can have metaphysical significance. This fits within his broader view that the material world and the spiritual world are interconnected, and that metaphysical realities can manifest through physical means, whether in the form of divine ascent or in spiritual punishment. ### 15. Conclusion I.5.4: Ista propositio non est concedenda: essentia est pater filii. *(This proposition should not be conceded: essence is the Father of the Son.)* In this theological conclusion, Henry of Ghent rejects the proposition that the essence of God is the Father of the Son. This distinction between essence and the persons of the Trinity is important in maintaining the orthodoxy of Trinitarian theology, where the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are distinct persons but share a common divine essence. Pico’s engagement with this conclusion highlights his interest in harmonizing different theological and metaphysical traditions. While affirming orthodox Christian doctrine, Pico also draws upon Neoplatonic metaphysics, where the One is the ultimate source of all being. By rejecting the idea that the divine essence itself generates the Son, Pico upholds the distinction between the persons of the Trinity while maintaining the unity of the divine essence. This delicate balance between unity and distinction in the divine nature is central to his synthesis of Christian theology and Neoplatonic metaphysics, where both the multiplicity of divine emanations and the unity of the divine source must be upheld. ### Conclusion In these further conclusions from Henry of Ghent, Pico continues to develop his synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought. Through his engagement with issues of relationality, metaphysical order, and theological distinctions, Pico demonstrates his commitment to a vision of the cosmos where all things are interconnected in a harmonious web of relations, leading ultimately to the divine. By drawing on both Aristotelian concepts of causality and Neoplatonic ideas of ascent and emanation, Pico offers a metaphysical framework that integrates reason, faith, and mystical experience, culminating in the soul's journey toward union with the divine.

conclusiones secundum egidi|um romanum numero .xi. annotated I.6.1. Potentia generandi in divinis: nec est essentia divina precise |et absolute sumpta: nec relatio vel proprietas: nec constitutum |ex ambobus: nec alterum istorum cum inclusione alterius: Sed |est essentia cum modo relativo. annotated I.6.2. Theologia nec est practica nec speculativa: Sed affectiva. annotated I.6.3. Deus sub ratione glorificatoris est subiectum in Theologia. annotated I.6.4. Pater et filius non solum duo spirantes: Sed etiam duo spira|tores dici possunt. annotated I.6.5. Angeli non fuerunt creati in gratia. annotated I.6.6. Ideo angelus est obstinatus et inpenitens: quia subtracti sunt |ei divini impetus speciales. annotated I.6.7. Superior angelus illuminat inferiorem non quia ei vel obie|ctum presentet luminosum: vel quod in se est unitum illi particu|lariset et dividat: Sed quia inferioris intellectum confortat et for|tificat. annotated I.6.8. Sensus gustus ut gustus est: non solum saporabile: Sed humi|dum percipit annotated I.6.9. Calor si sit etiam separatus ignem generare poterit. annotated I.6.10. Ad hoc quod aliqua scientia alteri non subalternetur sufficit quod fa|ciat reductionem ad per se nota in suo genere abstractionis. annotated I.6.11. Dato vacuo si aliquid in eo moveatur: in instanti movebitur.
ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico’s Conclusions According to Giles of Rome (Egidius Romanus) ### 1. Conclusion I.6.1: Potentia generandi in divinis: nec est essentia divina precise et absolute sumpta: nec relatio vel proprietas: nec constitutum ex ambobus: nec alterum istorum cum inclusione alterius: Sed est essentia cum modo relativo. *(The power of generating in the divine is not simply and absolutely the divine essence, nor is it a relation or property, nor a combination of both, nor one of these including the other, but it is the essence with a relative mode.)* This conclusion speaks to the complex nature of the generative power within the divine, particularly with reference to the relationship between the Father and the Son in Trinitarian theology. Giles of Rome argues that the generative power cannot be reduced to the divine essence alone nor to a mere relation or property. Instead, it involves the essence with a certain relative mode. For Pico, this highlights his synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic metaphysics with Christian theology. The notion of "essence with a relative mode" echoes the idea of the One or the divine emanating through various levels of reality, a common theme in Neoplatonism. Yet, in this case, Pico is careful to preserve the Christian understanding of the Trinity, where the persons of the Godhead (Father, Son, and Holy Spirit) are distinct yet united. This conclusion emphasizes the complexity of divine generation, a process that is neither purely abstract nor purely relational, but involves a unique mode of existence tied to the divine essence itself. ### 2. Conclusion I.6.2: Theologia nec est practica nec speculativa: Sed affectiva. *(Theology is neither practical nor speculative, but affective.)* This statement proposes that theology is fundamentally affective, meaning that it is concerned with love, devotion, and the orientation of the soul toward God, rather than with practical ethical action or abstract speculative knowledge. This is a significant shift from both Aristotelian ethics, which emphasize the practical, and traditional scholastic theology, which often focuses on speculative knowledge. Pico’s agreement with this position reflects his broader metaphysical and mystical approach, where the goal of theology is not merely intellectual understanding but a transformative relationship with the divine. The affective nature of theology points to a higher spiritual goal—union with God—through love and devotion, which transcends mere speculation or ethical behavior. This aligns with Pico’s Neoplatonic influences, particularly the idea of the soul’s ascent to God, where the intellect is ultimately surpassed by a direct, affective encounter with the divine. ### 3. Conclusion I.6.3: Deus sub ratione glorificatoris est subiectum in Theologia. *(God as glorifier is the subject of theology.)* In this conclusion, Giles of Rome asserts that the proper subject of theology is God, specifically in His role as glorifier. Theology, then, is not merely the study of God in an abstract sense, but the study of God in His action of glorifying His creation and being glorified by it. For Pico, this idea reinforces the relational aspect of theology that we have seen in other conclusions. God’s glorification of creation, and the glorification of God by creation, is a dynamic relationship, emphasizing the mutual interaction between God and the world. In Pico’s synthesis of Christian Platonism, this reflects the notion of divine emanation and return—God pours out His glory into creation, and creation returns that glory to God through contemplation and ascent. This mirrors the Neoplatonic idea of the One emanating into the multiplicity of beings, who then seek to return to their source. ### 4. Conclusion I.6.4: Pater et filius non solum duo spirantes: Sed etiam duo spiratores dici possunt. *(The Father and the Son are not only two who breathe [the Spirit], but also two who are called breathers.)* This conclusion addresses a nuanced point in Trinitarian theology. Giles of Rome is arguing that both the Father and the Son can be understood as not only participating in the procession of the Holy Spirit but also as active agents in that procession. They are not merely "breathers" of the Spirit; they are both involved in the act of breathing forth the Spirit. Pico’s inclusion of this conclusion reflects his engagement with subtle theological distinctions within the Christian doctrine of the Trinity. His synthesis seeks to integrate the rich metaphysical heritage of Neoplatonism with Christian dogma, and here he does so by exploring the relational dynamics within the Trinity itself. The procession of the Spirit from both the Father and the Son can be seen as an echo of the Neoplatonic process of emanation, where distinct hypostases (levels of divine reality) emerge from the One yet remain fundamentally unified. In Christian Platonism, this theological point helps to bridge the gap between metaphysical speculation about the divine and the lived, relational reality of God’s interaction with the world. ### 5. Conclusion I.6.5: Angeli non fuerunt creati in gratia. *(Angels were not created in grace.)* This conclusion asserts that angels, unlike human beings, were not created with grace, meaning that their relationship with God and their spiritual status differs fundamentally from that of humans. This has implications for how angels are understood within the Christian cosmological and soteriological frameworks. For Pico, this distinction between angels and humans is significant for understanding the different roles that each plays in the cosmic hierarchy. Angels, being pure intellects, were created in a state of perfection but without the need for grace in the way that fallen human beings require it. In Pico’s synthesis of Christian and Neoplatonic thought, angels represent an intermediary stage between God and humanity, reflecting the hierarchy of being in Neoplatonic cosmology. The lack of grace in their creation implies that their perfection is inherent, not acquired, which further supports their role as mediators between the divine and the human, guiding the soul’s ascent toward God. ### Conclusion In these conclusions from Giles of Rome, we see Pico continuing his project of synthesizing Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought with Christian theology. Each conclusion demonstrates a careful balance between metaphysical speculation and theological doctrine, with an emphasis on the relational and affective aspects of theology and metaphysics. By integrating concepts of divine generation, the affective nature of theology, and the role of angels and the Trinity, Pico presents a vision of Christian Platonism that is deeply mystical, relational, and oriented toward the ascent of the soul to God.
ChatGPT
### 6. Conclusion I.6.6: Ideo angelus est obstinatus et inpenitens: quia subtracti sunt ei divini impetus speciales. *(An angel is obstinate and unrepentant because the special divine impulses have been withdrawn from him.)* This conclusion deals with the nature of fallen angels, explaining their obstinacy and inability to repent as a consequence of losing access to divine grace or "special divine impulses." In contrast to human beings, who may receive divine grace to overcome sin and seek repentance, angels—specifically those who fell from grace, like Lucifer and his followers—are locked into their fallen state. Pico’s synthesis here draws from a combination of theological and Neoplatonic ideas. In Christian thought, angels are often seen as purely intellectual beings, closer to the divine than humans, and thus more definitive in their moral choices. This idea is consistent with the Neoplatonic notion that beings closer to the One, or God, possess a clearer and more immutable connection to truth and moral order. For Pico, fallen angels are unable to return to God because their higher nature means that their choice to rebel was definitive, and the divine impulse or grace that could restore them has been withdrawn. This highlights a key contrast between angelic and human nature, reflecting Pico’s broader interest in the hierarchical structure of the cosmos and the different roles and destinies assigned to angels and humans. ### 7. Conclusion I.6.7: Superior angelus illuminat inferiorem non quia ei vel obiectum presentet luminosum: vel quod in se est unitum illi particulariset et dividat: Sed quia inferioris intellectum confortat et fortificat. *(A superior angel illuminates an inferior one, not by presenting to it a luminous object or by uniting with it in some particular and divided way, but by strengthening and fortifying the intellect of the inferior angel.)* This conclusion touches upon the hierarchical structure of the angelic orders. According to this view, superior angels do not simply impart knowledge by revealing luminous truths or directly uniting with inferior angels. Rather, they strengthen and fortify the intellect of the lower angels, allowing them to understand divine realities more fully. Pico’s interpretation of this reflects his commitment to the Neoplatonic notion of a cosmic hierarchy, where higher beings impart knowledge and strength to lower ones. This also ties into his Christian metaphysics, where angels are seen as intermediaries who help bridge the gap between God and creation. In this case, superior angels serve as guides or intellectual fortifiers for those lower in the hierarchy, facilitating their understanding of divine truths. This aligns with the broader theme in Pico’s thought of the interconnectedness of all levels of reality, with higher beings, such as angels, playing a crucial role in the cosmic ascent toward God. ### 8. Conclusion I.6.8: Sensus gustus ut gustus est: non solum saporabile: Sed humidum percipit. *(The sense of taste, as taste, perceives not only flavors but also moisture.)* This conclusion presents a more physiological or natural philosophical insight, claiming that the sense of taste is not limited to the perception of flavor but also involves the perception of moisture. While seemingly unrelated to the metaphysical or theological ideas of the previous conclusions, this reflects Pico’s engagement with Aristotelian natural philosophy. By including such conclusions, Pico demonstrates the breadth of his intellectual scope, incorporating Aristotelian natural philosophy into his broader metaphysical system. The attention to the sensory faculties also serves to remind readers of the interconnectedness of the physical and metaphysical worlds in Pico’s thought, where sensory knowledge can serve as a stepping stone to higher intellectual and spiritual knowledge. ### 9. Conclusion I.6.9: Calor si sit etiam separatus ignem generare poterit. *(Heat, even when separated, can generate fire.)* This conclusion also belongs to the realm of natural philosophy, specifically dealing with the properties of heat and fire. It asserts that heat, as a distinct property or force, has the capacity to generate fire, even when it is separated from its original source. Pico’s inclusion of this idea reflects his interest in the Aristotelian theory of the elements and their interactions. It also hints at a metaphysical parallel, where certain forces or properties (such as divine grace or the intellect) can operate independently from their original source. This idea of "separated forces" could be aligned with Neoplatonic concepts of emanation, where properties like light or heat can exist and act separately from their original source, while still retaining a connection to that source. ### 10. Conclusion I.6.10: Ad hoc quod aliqua scientia alteri non subalternetur sufficit quod faciat reductionem ad per se nota in suo genere abstractionis. *(For a science not to be subordinated to another, it is sufficient that it makes a reduction to self-evident principles within its own kind of abstraction.)* This conclusion addresses the independence of scientific disciplines. Pico is arguing that a science does not need to be subordinated to another science, provided that it is capable of reducing its principles to self-evident truths appropriate to its own domain of abstraction. This fits into Pico’s broader intellectual project of harmonizing different fields of knowledge—such as theology, philosophy, and natural science—without subordinating one to the other. Each field has its own methodology and domain, and it can stand independently as long as it is grounded in self-evident principles appropriate to its subject matter. This reflects a Renaissance approach to knowledge that seeks unity and coherence across disciplines while respecting the particularities of each. --- ### Conclusion In this set of conclusions, Pico continues to demonstrate his wide-ranging intellectual interests, from metaphysical discussions about the nature of angels and divine emanation, to more natural philosophical reflections on sensory perception and the elements. His synthesis of Aristotelian, Neoplatonic, and Christian ideas remains at the forefront, as he weaves together metaphysical, theological, and natural philosophical insights into a cohesive vision of the cosmos. In this vision, beings and forces operate within a divinely ordered hierarchy, where higher beings (such as superior angels) guide and strengthen those lower in the hierarchy, reflecting a Neoplatonic framework of ascent and emanation. Through these conclusions, Pico offers a glimpse into the intricate relationships between different realms of knowledge and reality, ultimately pointing toward a unified understanding of God, nature, and the human soul’s place within the cosmic order.

Foelicitas ultima hominis est cum continuatur intellectus agens |possibili: ut forma: quam continuationem et latini alii quos le|gi et maxime Iohanes de Gandago perverse et erronee intelle|xit: qui non solum in hoc: Sed ferme in omnibus quaesitis Phi|losophiae: doctrinam Avenrois corrupit omnino et depravavit. annotated I.7.4. Possibile est tenendo unitatem intellectus: animam meam ita |particulariter meam ut non sit mihi communis cum omnibus re|manere post mortem. annotated I.7.5. Quodlibet abstractum dependet a primo abstracto in tripli|ci genere causae: formalis: finalis: et efficientis. annotated I.7.6. Impossibile est eandem speciem ex propagatione et ex putrefa|ctione generari. annotated I.7.7. Deus primum mobile non solum ut finis: sed ut verum effici|ens et proprius motor movet. annotated I.7.8. Quilibet motor coeli est anima sui orbis faciens cum eo ma|gis unum substantialiter: quam fiat ex anima bovis et sua materia. Correlarium. Anima coeli prius dat suo orbi esse nobile et per|fectum quam ei det motum. annotated I.7.9. Coelum est corpus simplex: non compositum ex materia et forma. annotated I.7.10. Tres modi per se sunt ad demonstrationem utiles. Primus. Se|cundus et Quartus. annotated I.7.11. In omni demonstratione praeterquam in demonstratione simplici|ter fieri potest circulatio. annotated I.7.12. Gravia et levia movent se per accidens movendo medium per se. annotated I.7.13. Coeli non sunt idem in genere: diversi in specie ut credidit Avi|cenna. annotated I.7.14. Nulla scientia probat suum subiectum esse: nec partem princi|palem sui subiecti. annotated I.7.15. Universalia sunt ex parte rei in potentia tantum actu autem |per operationem animae. annotated I.7.16. Dimensiones interminate sunt coeternae materiae praecedentes |in ea quamlibet formam substantialem. annotated I.7.17. Quaelibet intelligentia praeter primam non intelligit nisi primam. annotated I.7.18. Nulla est via ad probandum simpliciter abstractum esse prae|ter viam aeternitatis motus. annotated I.7.19. Quicquid est in genere: est corruptibile. annotated I.7.20. Subiectum Methaphysicae est ens in eo quod ens. annotated I.7.21. Diffinitiones substantiarum naturalium: materiam non dicunt |nisi consequtive. annotated I.7.22. Demonstratio septimi Physicorum: quod omne quod movetur: |movetur ab alio: est demonstratio signi et nullo modo causae. annotated I.7.23. Nulla potentia activa quae sit mere neutra et indifferens ad age|re vel non agere potest ex se determinari ad alterum agendum. annotated I.7.24. Unum relativorum convenientissime per reliquum definitur. annotated I.7.25. Exemplum Aristotelis in secundo Methaphysicae de nicticora|ce respectu solis: non denotat impossibilitatem: sed difficultatem |alioquin natura aliquid ociose egisset. annotated I.7.26. Propositio necessaria quae ab Aristotele in libro priorum con|tra possibilem et inventam distinguitur: est illa quae est ex termi|nis necessariis. annotated I.7.27. Ad dispositionem termini necessarii: requiritur ut sit termi|nus per se unus. annotated I.7.28. Cum Aristoteles dixit ex maiori necessaria et minore inventa |concludi conclusionem necessariam: intelligendum est de mino|re quae est inventa per se: necessaria per accidens. annotated I.7.29. Sub aequinoctiali non potest esse habitatio naturalis viventibus. annotated I.7.30. In coelo est naturaliter dextrum: et illud non mutatur quamvis |partes orbis mutentur. annotated I.7.31. Qui ponit animam formam complexionalem: negat causam agentem. annotated I.7.32. Unum methaphysicum: dicit privationem divisibilitatis: non |actu: sed aptitudine. annotated I.7.33. Unum methaphysicum est fundamentum unius Arithmetici. annotated I.7.34. Numerus precise ita reperitur in abstractis sicut in materialibus. annotated I.7.35. Essentia uniuscuiusque rei et suum existere: idem sunt realiter. annotated I.7.36. Quiditas et essentia diversificantur in quolibet praeter primum. annotated I.7.37. Substantia est prior accidente non solum natura sed tempore. annotated I.7.38. De materia ut materia est considerat Physicus. annotated I.7.39. Essentia cuiuslibet intelligentiae est substantialiter ad aliquid. annotated I.7.40. Dato per impossibile quod daretur materia quae corruptionis prin|cipium non esset adhuc si coelum ex tali materia et forma esset ve|re compositum aeternum esse non posset. annotated I.7.41. Finis non causat finaliter secundum suum esse conceptum: sed secundum su|um esse reale. Annotations
ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico's Conclusions According to Averroes (I.7.1 - I.7.10) ### 1. Conclusion I.7.1: Possibilis est prophetia in somnis per illustrationem intellectus agentis super animam nostram. *(Prophecy in dreams is possible through the illumination of the active intellect over our soul.)* This conclusion asserts the possibility of prophetic visions through dreams, which occurs when the active intellect illuminates the human soul. In Averroist thought, the active intellect is a universal principle that interacts with individual human intellects. Pico, following this tradition, suggests that prophetic insight comes not from the individual’s imagination or internal faculties, but through an external, higher intellect. This reflects his synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic metaphysics, where prophecy can be understood as the mind's connection to divine or intellectual truths, facilitated by an intermediary intellect. ### 2. Conclusion I.7.2: Una est anima intellectiva in omnibus hominibus. *(The intellectual soul is one in all human beings.)* Here, Pico invokes the controversial Averroist doctrine of the unity of the intellect, which claims that all humans share a single intellectual soul. This view diverges from the Christian tradition, which typically holds that each person has their own distinct intellect. Pico’s inclusion of this idea suggests his willingness to engage with and incorporate even the more radical ideas of Averroism into his broader philosophical system. This concept reflects his belief in the shared participation of all humans in a higher, universal intellect, resonating with Neoplatonic notions of unity and the emanation of intellect from a single source. ### 3. Conclusion I.7.3: Foelicitas ultima hominis est cum continuatur intellectus agens possibili: ut forma: quam continuationem et latini alii quos legi et maxime Iohanes de Gandago perverse et erronee intellexit: qui non solum in hoc: Sed ferme in omnibus quaesitis Philosophiae: doctrinam Avenrois corrupit omnino et depravavit. *(The ultimate happiness of man is when the active intellect is united with the possible intellect as form, which understanding many Latins, particularly John of Jandun, have perverted and misunderstood, corrupting the doctrine of Averroes in nearly all philosophical matters.)* Pico critiques the misinterpretation of Averroes' doctrine of the unification of the possible and active intellect, particularly targeting John of Jandun. According to Averroes, ultimate happiness (foelicitas) comes from the union of the individual intellect with the universal active intellect. This union allows humans to attain intellectual perfection. Pico’s defense of Averroes here illustrates his commitment to preserving the integrity of this doctrine, despite its challenges to mainstream Christian thought. This also ties into his broader project of achieving human transcendence through intellectual ascent, a theme closely related to Neoplatonic metaphysics. ### 4. Conclusion I.7.4: Possibile est tenendo unitatem intellectus: animam meam ita particulariter meam ut non sit mihi communis cum omnibus remanere post mortem. *(It is possible, while holding to the unity of the intellect, that my soul, so particularly mine, remains after death without being common to all.)* This conclusion reconciles Averroes' controversial doctrine of the unity of intellect with the notion of personal immortality. While Averroes argued for a shared intellect, Pico suggests that an individual soul can retain its particularity and persist after death, even within the framework of a universal intellect. This conclusion reflects Pico’s effort to harmonize divergent philosophical traditions—here integrating Averroist unity with the Christian belief in personal immortality. The synthesis suggests a more complex metaphysical framework, where unity at the level of intellect does not negate individual continuity in the afterlife. ### 5. Conclusion I.7.5: Quodlibet abstractum dependet a primo abstracto in triplici genere causae: formalis: finalis: et efficientis. *(Every abstraction depends on the first abstraction in three kinds of causes: formal, final, and efficient.)* In this conclusion, Pico asserts that all abstract entities are dependent on the "first abstraction" (likely the divine intellect or the One) through formal, final, and efficient causality. This reflects Neoplatonic metaphysics, where everything emanates from a first cause or principle (the One), and all subsequent levels of reality—whether material or abstract—are dependent on it. The formal cause refers to the abstract structure, the final cause to the purpose or goal, and the efficient cause to the means by which it comes into being. This reinforces Pico’s view of the interconnection between metaphysical principles and the material world, and the way all things trace their origins back to a single divine source. ### 6. Conclusion I.7.6: Impossibile est eandem speciem ex propagatione et ex putrefactione generari. *(It is impossible for the same species to be generated by both propagation and decay.)* This conclusion addresses a natural philosophical issue regarding the generation of species, suggesting that the same species cannot arise from both natural propagation (e.g., reproduction) and spontaneous generation (from decay or putrefaction). Pico’s concern here is with maintaining a clear distinction between the processes that produce life. This view aligns with Aristotelian natural philosophy, where distinct causes lead to distinct kinds of generation. The metaphysical implications may relate to Pico's broader views on causality and order in the natural world, emphasizing that natural processes follow consistent, intelligible principles. ### 7. Conclusion I.7.7: Deus primum mobile non solum ut finis: sed ut verum efficiens et proprius motor movet. *(God moves the first mobile not only as an end, but as a true efficient cause and proper mover.)* Pico engages here with Aristotelian cosmology, which describes God as the unmoved mover, the ultimate cause of all motion in the universe. In this conclusion, he emphasizes that God acts not only as the final cause (the goal toward which everything moves) but also as an efficient cause (actively initiating motion). This is a key point of synthesis between Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought, where God is both the source and the end of all being. For Pico, this idea reinforces the notion of God as intimately involved in the workings of the cosmos, moving it through both purpose and action. ### 8. Conclusion I.7.8: Quilibet motor coeli est anima sui orbis faciens cum eo magis unum substantialiter: quam fiat ex anima bovis et sua materia. *(Each mover of the heavens is the soul of its orb, making with it a more substantial unity than that which exists between the soul of an ox and its matter.)* This conclusion continues the exploration of cosmology, asserting that the movers of the celestial spheres are souls, and that the unity between these souls and their orbs is greater than the unity between a soul and a physical body (such as an ox). This reflects Neoplatonic cosmology, where celestial bodies are animated by intelligences or souls that move them in accordance with divine order. Pico elevates the connection between soul and celestial body above that of material beings, suggesting a hierarchy of being where celestial souls hold a more perfect unity with their orbs than earthly beings do with their bodies. ### 9. Correlarium: Anima coeli prius dat suo orbi esse nobile et perfectum quam ei det motum. *(Corollary: The soul of the heavens first gives its orb noble and perfect being before giving it motion.)* This corollary builds on the previous conclusion by asserting that the soul of a celestial orb first bestows upon it a noble and perfect existence, and only then imparts motion. This suggests that existence and perfection are prior to action or motion, aligning with both Aristotelian and Neoplatonic principles, where being precedes becoming, and perfection is inherent in the higher realms of existence. The motion of the celestial bodies, then, is a consequence of their perfection, driven by the soul’s unity with the divine. ### 10. Conclusion I.7.9: Coelum est corpus simplex: non compositum ex materia et forma. *(The heavens are a simple body, not composed of matter and form.)* In this conclusion, Pico asserts the simplicity of the heavens, distinguishing them from earthly bodies, which are composed of both matter and form. This reflects a key aspect of Aristotelian cosmology, where the heavens are seen as fundamentally different from the sublunary realm. The simplicity of the heavens implies that they are not subject to the same processes of generation and corruption as material bodies, reinforcing their status as perfect and immutable.

ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico's Conclusions According to Averroes (I.7.10 - I.7.19) ### 11. Conclusion I.7.10: Tres modi per se sunt ad demonstrationem utiles. Primus. Secundus et Quartus. *(Three modes are useful for demonstration: the first, the second, and the fourth.)* Pico here refers to different modes of syllogistic demonstration as developed in Aristotelian logic. The first, second, and fourth modes likely refer to specific structures of logical demonstration that involve premises leading to a conclusion in different ways. Averroes, like Aristotle, held the structure of logical demonstrations to be key for philosophical reasoning. This is a reflection of Pico’s broader project of harmonizing Aristotelian logic with other forms of philosophical knowledge, integrating precise forms of reasoning into his own metaphysical framework. ### 12. Conclusion I.7.11: In omni demonstratione praeterquam in demonstratione simpliciter fieri potest circulatio. *(In every demonstration except for a simple demonstration, circularity can occur.)* This conclusion suggests that most types of logical demonstration can involve circular reasoning except for simple, or direct, demonstration. Circularity in logic refers to a fallacy where the conclusion is assumed in the premises, which is generally considered a flaw in reasoning. However, Pico may be acknowledging that more complex demonstrations sometimes involve this kind of circularity, possibly referring to philosophical systems that depend on internal coherence rather than purely linear logic. This aligns with his Neoplatonic metaphysics, where the One or the Divine may be both the cause and the end of philosophical inquiry. ### 13. Conclusion I.7.12: Gravia et levia movent se per accidens movendo medium per se. *(Heavy and light things move themselves by accident, moving the medium by themselves.)* This statement refers to the natural philosophy of motion as described by Aristotle and interpreted by Averroes. Heavy and light bodies, such as earth and fire, move naturally toward their proper place, but they do so by interacting with the medium (such as air or water) through which they travel. Pico’s conclusion reflects the Aristotelian understanding of natural motion, where objects are moved according to their nature, but the actual motion occurs through the medium they displace. The phrase "per accidens" indicates that while the medium is moved by the object, the essential nature of the object's motion remains self-contained. ### 14. Conclusion I.7.13: Coeli non sunt idem in genere: diversi in specie ut credidit Avicenna. *(The heavens are not the same in genus; they are different in species, as Avicenna believed.)* Pico here acknowledges Avicenna's view that the celestial bodies differ from one another not just as individual entities but as different species, each with its own unique form. This is significant within Aristotelian cosmology, where the heavens are typically seen as distinct from earthly objects but share certain metaphysical characteristics. Avicenna’s interpretation introduces the idea of a more nuanced differentiation among the celestial bodies. Pico adopts this view to emphasize the diversity and richness of the celestial realm, which, though unified in purpose and function, contains distinct forms and intelligences. ### 15. Conclusion I.7.14: Nulla scientia probat suum subiectum esse: nec partem principalem sui subiecti. *(No science proves its subject to exist, nor does it prove the principal part of its subject.)* This conclusion reflects a key aspect of Aristotelian epistemology, where the existence of the subject matter of a science is assumed rather than proven within the framework of that science. For example, the existence of nature is not proven by natural philosophy but is presupposed. Pico highlights the limitations of specific sciences in proving the fundamental existence of their subjects. This suggests a recognition of the boundaries between different forms of knowledge, with metaphysics or theology providing the groundwork for understanding being itself, beyond the reach of specialized disciplines. ### 16. Conclusion I.7.15: Universalia sunt ex parte rei in potentia tantum actu autem per operationem animae. *(Universals exist in potentiality on the part of the thing, but in actuality through the operation of the soul.)* Pico here discusses the nature of universals, a central issue in medieval metaphysics. Averroes held that universals exist in the intellect and not as concrete entities. Pico modifies this by suggesting that universals exist in potentiality in the external world, but it is only through the intellect, or the soul’s operation, that they become actual. This reflects his attempt to synthesize Aristotelian realism (universals as tied to particulars) with Neoplatonic idealism (the soul’s role in apprehending universals). The soul actualizes the potential universality present in individual things, which aligns with the idea that knowledge involves the participation of both intellect and the object known. ### 17. Conclusion I.7.16: Dimensiones interminatae sunt coeternae materiae praecedentes in ea quamlibet formam substantialem. *(Infinite dimensions are coeternal with matter, preceding in it any substantial form.)* This conclusion deals with the metaphysical nature of matter and form. Pico, drawing from Averroes, suggests that infinite dimensions (perhaps referring to spatial or potential extension) are inherent in matter and exist coeternally with it, before any specific substantial form is imposed. This reflects a metaphysical hierarchy where matter exists as pure potentiality, containing infinite possibilities for form. Pico incorporates this into his broader metaphysical system, where the preexistence of potentiality aligns with Neoplatonic ideas of emanation, where all forms emerge from a higher, undifferentiated source. ### 18. Conclusion I.7.17: Quaelibet intelligentia praeter primam non intelligit nisi primam. *(Every intelligence, except the first, only understands the first.)* In Neoplatonic cosmology, intelligences are the intermediary beings or levels of mind between the divine One and the material world. Pico asserts that all intelligences (except the first, which is likely the One or the Divine Mind itself) are focused on contemplating the first intelligence. This reflects the Neoplatonic idea of emanation, where lower levels of being continually refer back to the source of all, the One. The intellectual hierarchy Pico describes mirrors the idea that all knowledge and existence depend on a higher principle, with each level of intelligence striving to comprehend the first cause. ### 19. Conclusion I.7.18: Nulla est via ad probandum simpliciter abstractum esse praeter viam aeternitatis motus. *(There is no way to prove the existence of something simply abstract except through the eternity of motion.)* This conclusion addresses the problem of demonstrating the existence of abstract entities. Pico suggests that only through the understanding of eternal motion—likely referring to the continuous movement of the heavens or the eternal flow of time—can one grasp the existence of purely abstract forms. This reflects a cosmological and metaphysical perspective where motion and time are key to understanding higher realities. The connection between motion and abstract being suggests a synthesis of Aristotelian physics with Neoplatonic metaphysics, where eternal motion becomes a pathway to understanding abstract and transcendent realities. ### 20. Conclusion I.7.19: Quicquid est in genere: est corruptibile. *(Whatever is in a genus is corruptible.)* This conclusion reflects the Aristotelian distinction between the eternal and the corruptible. Anything that can be classified within a genus—meaning it has a particular form and is part of the created, material world—is subject to generation and corruption. Only the divine or purely intellectual beings, which exist outside of genus and species, are incorruptible. This statement reinforces Pico’s hierarchical view of the cosmos, where material beings are inherently impermanent, while higher intelligible or divine realities transcend corruption and change.
You
continue
ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico's Conclusions According to Averroes (I.7.20 - I.7.29) ### 21. Conclusion I.7.20: Subiectum Methaphysicae est ens in eo quod ens. *(The subject of metaphysics is being insofar as it is being.)* In this conclusion, Pico refers to the Aristotelian understanding of metaphysics, as articulated by Averroes, where the central subject is "being qua being"—that is, being in the most universal and fundamental sense. Metaphysics does not concern itself with particular beings or individual substances but rather with the nature of being itself. This reflects Pico’s desire to delve into the deepest questions of existence, echoing the Aristotelian tradition but also incorporating Neoplatonic ideas where metaphysics becomes a study of the transcendent and the unity of all existence. ### 22. Conclusion I.7.21: Diffinitiones substantiarum naturalium: materiam non dicunt nisi consequtive. *(The definitions of natural substances do not mention matter except as a consequence.)* Here, Pico highlights a key aspect of Aristotelian natural philosophy as interpreted by Averroes. The essence of a natural substance is typically defined by its form, while matter is considered only consequentially, as the substrate that receives the form. In Pico's synthesis of Aristotelianism and Neoplatonism, this reflects the idea that form (the intelligible aspect) takes precedence over matter (the potential or physical aspect). This aligns with Pico’s metaphysical hierarchy, where form (and ultimately the divine intellect) is what gives structure and meaning to the material world. ### 23. Conclusion I.7.22: Demonstratio septimi Physicorum: quod omne quod movetur: movetur ab alio: est demonstratio signi et nullo modo causae. *(The demonstration in the seventh book of the Physics, that everything that is moved is moved by another, is a demonstration of a sign and not in any way of a cause.)* This conclusion critiques the Aristotelian argument from Physics that all motion must be caused by something external to the moving object. Pico, drawing from Averroes, points out that this demonstration is only a "sign" or indication, not a true causal explanation. In metaphysical terms, this suggests that while external causes may be evident in the movement of objects, the deeper causes (such as divine or intellectual causes) remain concealed. This reflects Pico’s interest in moving beyond surface-level explanations to explore the ultimate metaphysical causes of motion and change. ### 24. Conclusion I.7.23: Nulla potentia activa quae sit mere neutra et indifferens ad agere vel non agere potest ex se determinari ad alterum agendum. *(No active power that is merely neutral and indifferent toward acting or not acting can determine itself to either act.)* This conclusion refers to the nature of active powers in metaphysics and physics. Pico suggests that an active power, if it is entirely neutral, cannot initiate action on its own without some external determination. This aligns with the Aristotelian idea that potentiality requires an external agent to actualize it. In the context of Pico’s broader metaphysics, this may also allude to the necessity of a higher cause or intellect to set things into motion, which fits into his overall scheme of a hierarchical, emanationist cosmos where higher intelligences direct the actions of lower beings. ### 25. Conclusion I.7.24: Unum relativorum convenientissime per reliquum definitur. *(One of the relatives is most suitably defined by the other.)* This conclusion deals with the concept of relational properties, where one term in a relationship is defined by the other. For example, a father is defined in relation to his child, and vice versa. This reflects an Aristotelian understanding of how relative terms operate within philosophical discourse. In the context of Pico’s metaphysics, this could be applied to various dualities in the universe, such as form and matter or intellect and soul, where each gains its meaning in relation to the other. This also aligns with Neoplatonic ideas of emanation, where higher and lower realms of being are understood in relational terms. ### 26. Conclusion I.7.25: Exemplum Aristotelis in secundo Methaphysicae de nicticorace respectu solis: non denotat impossibilitatem: sed difficultatem alioquin natura aliquid ociose egisset. *(Aristotle's example in the second book of the Metaphysics concerning the owl with respect to the sun does not indicate impossibility but difficulty; otherwise, nature would have acted in vain.)* Pico refers to a famous metaphor from Aristotle, where the owl, whose vision is attuned to darkness, struggles to see in the bright light of the sun. This metaphor is used to illustrate the difficulty of understanding the highest truths (such as metaphysical or divine truths). Pico’s interpretation emphasizes that the metaphor indicates difficulty, not impossibility, suggesting that even though human understanding struggles to grasp higher truths, it is still possible through diligent philosophical inquiry. This conclusion reflects Pico’s optimistic view of human potential, particularly the capacity to ascend intellectually and spiritually. ### 27. Conclusion I.7.26: Propositio necessaria quae ab Aristotele in libro priorum contra possibilem et inventam distinguitur: est illa quae est ex terminis necessariis. *(The necessary proposition, which Aristotle distinguishes in the Prior Analytics from the possible and the discovered, is the one that is made from necessary terms.)* In this conclusion, Pico refers to Aristotle's distinction between different types of propositions in logic. A necessary proposition is one where the terms are necessarily linked, as opposed to contingent or possible propositions. This reflects Pico’s interest in grounding metaphysical and logical truths in necessary principles, as opposed to contingent or empirical facts. This distinction is important for his synthesis of Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought, where necessary truths (rooted in the nature of being itself) are seen as reflecting the deeper structure of reality. ### 28. Conclusion I.7.27: Ad dispositionem termini necessarii: requiritur ut sit terminus per se unus. *(For the disposition of a necessary term, it is required that the term be one in itself.)* Here, Pico emphasizes the importance of unity in necessary propositions. For a term to function in a necessary proposition, it must have a clear and unified meaning in itself. This reflects the Aristotelian concern with the precision and clarity of logical terms, but it also hints at Pico’s broader metaphysical concerns with unity and multiplicity. In Neoplatonism, unity is often seen as the highest principle, with multiplicity arising as a derivative of the One. This conclusion thus serves as a bridge between Aristotelian logic and Neoplatonic metaphysics, where the clarity and unity of terms mirror the unity of being. ### 29. Conclusion I.7.28: Cum Aristoteles dixit ex maiori necessaria et minore inventa concludi conclusionem necessariam: intelligendum est de minore quae est inventa per se: necessaria per accidens. *(When Aristotle said that a necessary conclusion is drawn from a necessary major premise and a discovered minor premise, it must be understood that the minor premise is discovered in itself and is necessary by accident.)* Pico is here unpacking a complex logical structure from Aristotle’s *Prior Analytics*. He explains that when a conclusion is necessary, it can be based on a major premise that is necessarily true, but the minor premise (which may be discovered empirically) is only accidentally necessary—meaning it happens to be true in this case, but is not necessarily so in all cases. This reflects Pico’s deep engagement with Aristotelian logic, and his desire to reconcile necessary and contingent truths within a single philosophical system. The idea of accidental necessity also mirrors the way Neoplatonists often describe the relationship between the One and the multiplicity of the world: the One is necessarily true, while the world is contingent but derived from the One. ### 30. Conclusion I.7.29: Sub aequinoctiali non potest esse habitatio naturalis viventibus. *(Under the equator, there cannot be natural habitation for living beings.)* This conclusion reflects an Aristotelian cosmological belief, prevalent in the Middle Ages, that the equator was too hot and inhospitable for life. Pico’s engagement with this view shows his adherence to the natural philosophy of his time, even as he seeks to integrate it with metaphysical and spiritual concerns. Although Pico’s metaphysical project seeks to transcend the material world, conclusions like this show that he remains rooted in the physical and natural sciences as part of his broader intellectual synthesis.

continue
ChatGPT
### Close Reading of Pico's Conclusions According to Averroes (I.7.30 - I.7.39) ### 31. Conclusion I.7.30: In coelo est naturaliter dextrum: et illud non mutatur quamvis partes orbis mutentur. *(There is naturally a right-hand side in the heavens, and this does not change even though the parts of the orb move.)* In this conclusion, Pico is dealing with the Aristotelian concept of the cosmos and its motion. The idea that the heavens have a natural "right-hand side" refers to the cosmological structure where directionality plays a role in the natural order of celestial bodies. Pico’s reference to the fixed nature of this "right" direction suggests an immutable aspect of the cosmos, despite the constant motion of celestial spheres. This aligns with Pico's broader metaphysical view, influenced by Neoplatonism, where the material and celestial worlds are structured and ordered according to unchanging principles. ### 32. Conclusion I.7.31: Qui ponit animam formam complexionalem: negat causam agentem. *(He who posits the soul as a form derived from complexion denies the existence of an efficient cause.)* This conclusion tackles the debate over the nature of the soul. Pico, drawing from Averroes, critiques the idea that the soul is merely a result of the physical and humoral makeup (the "complexion") of the body. To claim that the soul is a product of physical composition denies the existence of an efficient, external cause—such as the divine or the intellect—which brings the soul into being. Pico's view resonates with the Aristotelian and Neoplatonic understanding that the soul is an immaterial substance, not reducible to bodily processes, and has a higher, intellectual cause. ### 33. Conclusion I.7.32: Unum methaphysicum: dicit privationem divisibilitatis: non actu: sed aptitudine. *(A metaphysical unity indicates the absence of divisibility, not in actuality, but in aptitude.)* Pico here delves into the metaphysical nature of unity, a central concern in both Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought. The conclusion distinguishes between actual indivisibility and potential or aptitudinal indivisibility. In other words, something can be metaphysically one, not because it is indivisible in practice, but because it lacks the capacity or potential to be divided. This reflects a key Neoplatonic idea where the One, the highest principle, is entirely indivisible, while lower forms of being may have a potential for division. This distinction underlines the metaphysical hierarchy Pico seeks to synthesize, where the One is at the top of the ontological chain. ### 34. Conclusion I.7.33: Unum methaphysicum est fundamentum unius Arithmetici. *(A metaphysical unity is the foundation of arithmetical unity.)* Pico argues that metaphysical unity is the basis for numerical unity, reflecting the idea that metaphysical principles underpin mathematical realities. In Neoplatonic thought, the One is the source of all multiplicity, including numbers. Thus, the numerical concept of "one" derives from the deeper metaphysical reality of unity. This conclusion emphasizes the correspondence between the metaphysical and mathematical orders, a key aspect of Pico’s philosophy, where higher realities give rise to lower, more tangible manifestations such as numbers. ### 35. Conclusion I.7.34: Numerus precise ita reperitur in abstractis sicut in materialibus. *(Number is found precisely in abstract entities just as it is in material entities.)* Here, Pico asserts that numbers are present both in abstract forms (like Platonic ideas) and in material entities. This reflects the Aristotelian and Averroist notion that abstract entities have a real existence, as well as the Neoplatonic idea that material entities are reflections or manifestations of higher, abstract principles. Pico’s view is a synthesis of these traditions, arguing that the same principles governing material reality—such as numbers—also govern the realm of abstract, intellectual entities. This underscores Pico’s commitment to bridging the gap between the material and immaterial worlds. ### 36. Conclusion I.7.35: Essentia uniuscuiusque rei et suum existere: idem sunt realiter. *(The essence of each thing and its existence are the same in reality.)* In this conclusion, Pico reflects on the relationship between essence and existence. While Aristotelian philosophy traditionally distinguishes between essence (what a thing is) and existence (that a thing is), Pico, following Averroes, suggests that in reality, these two are the same for each individual being. This is a significant metaphysical claim, as it points to the unity of a thing’s being and its essence, suggesting that existence is not something added to essence but is inherent in it. This conclusion may also be read in light of Neoplatonism, where the existence of things is seen as a direct emanation from the One, and therefore essence and existence are intertwined. ### 37. Conclusion I.7.36: Quiditas et essentia diversificantur in quolibet praeter primum. *(Quiddity and essence are distinct in everything except the first principle.)* Pico asserts that in all beings except the First Principle (God or the One), quiddity (what something is) and essence are distinct. This conclusion draws from both Aristotelian and Neoplatonic traditions, where God or the One is understood as the only being in which essence and quiddity are identical, while in all other beings, they are distinct. This distinction is crucial in Pico’s metaphysical hierarchy, where only the First Principle has perfect unity, while all other beings are composites of various elements, including quiddity and essence. ### 38. Conclusion I.7.37: Substantia est prior accidente non solum natura sed tempore. *(Substance is prior to accidents not only in nature but also in time.)* In this conclusion, Pico reinforces the Aristotelian idea that substance—what a thing fundamentally is—has ontological and temporal priority over accidents, which are qualities or properties that do not define a thing’s essence. This distinction is foundational in Aristotelian metaphysics, where substance is what persists through change, while accidents are contingent. Pico’s agreement with this point signals his alignment with Aristotelian thought in maintaining the primacy of substance in the structure of reality. ### 39. Conclusion I.7.38: De materia ut materia est considerat Physicus. *(The physicist considers matter as it is in itself.)* This conclusion reflects the Aristotelian distinction between physics and metaphysics. While metaphysics deals with being in general and higher principles like form and essence, physics is concerned specifically with matter and the material world. Pico’s acknowledgment of this distinction shows his respect for the different domains of knowledge and inquiry. By recognizing that the physicist’s role is to study matter in itself, Pico maintains the Aristotelian division of labor between disciplines, even as he seeks to integrate them into a broader metaphysical framework. ### 40. Conclusion I.7.39: Essentia cuiuslibet intelligentiae est substantialiter ad aliquid. *(The essence of every intelligence is essentially related to something else.)* In this conclusion, Pico addresses the nature of intelligences (angels or intellects) in Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought. He asserts that the essence of each intelligence is relational, meaning that these beings are not self-contained but are defined by their relationship to higher and lower beings in the cosmic hierarchy. This reflects a key Neoplatonic principle where all beings, including intellects, are part of an interconnected chain of being, with each level dependent on and related to the others. This relational nature of intelligences also echoes the Aristotelian notion that intellects are defined by their act of knowing and their objects of knowledge.
