translate and close read conclusiones philosophice secun|dum propriam opinionem numero |lxxx. que licet a communi philo|sophia dissentiant: a communi ta|men philosophandi modo non mul|tum abhorrent. annotated II.2.1. Potest a specie in sensu exteriori existente immediate abstra|hi species universalis. annotated II.2.2. Intentio secunda est ens rationis habens se per modum formae |qualitative ab operatione intellectus proveniens consequutive |non effective. annotated II.2.3. Nec prima intentio: nec secunda intentio alicubi sunt subie|ctive. annotated II.2.4. Est devenire in corporibus ad aliquid quod ita corporaliter lo|cat quod corporaliter non locatur: et illud est ultima sphera sicut in |intelligibilibus est devenire ad aliquid quod ita intelligibiliter |locat: quod nullo modo locatur: et illud est deus. Correlarium. Non est quaerendum quomodo ultima sphera |locatur: Sed absolute concedendum quod non locatur. annotated II.2.5. Singulare non intelligitur ab intellectu: nec secundum veritatem: nec |secundum etiam opinionem Aristotelis Commentatoris et Thommae. annotated II.2.6. Licet intellectus non intelligat singulariter: ab ipso tamen est |quod perfecte cognoscatur singulare. annotated II.2.7. Quaelibet res quaecunque sit illa in puritate sui esse constituta est |intelligens: intellectus: et intellectum. annotated II.2.8. Ex praedicta conclusione habetur quare materia sit principium |incognoscibilitatis et intellectus agens cognoscibilitatis: annotated II.2.9. Illa dicitur actio immanens quae non est subiective in illo quod |passive per eam denominatur: et per hoc distinguitur a transe|unte. annotated II.2.10. Omnis alius modus praeter eum quem dixit praecedens conclusio est |insufficiens ad distinguendum actionem immanentem a transe- |unte. annotated II.2.11. Cum dicit Avenrois non esse aliud medium ad probandum |abstractum praeter aeternitatem motus: non intelligit de quocunque |abstracto: Sed de eo quod ultimato gradu abstractionis est ab|stractum a corpore. annotated II.2.12. Esse corporeum non habet res ab aliqua forma substantiali |vel gradu formae substantialis. annotated II.2.13. Sex transcendentia quae ponit communis doctrina: a iuniori|bus latinis sunt efficta: ea et graeci peripatetici: et princeps eorum |Aristoteles nescit. annotated II.2.14. Necessarium est apud Aristotelem primam causam movere de |necessitate. annotated II.2.15. Impossibile est: et omnino irrationale apud Aristotelem om|nia evenire de necessitate respectu cuiuscunque causae illa necessi|tas accipiatur. annotated II.2.16. Tractatus suppositionum ad logicum non pertinet. annotated II.2.17. Non potuit mundus esse a deo ab aeterno efficienter efficien|tia vera quae est reductio de potentia ad actum. annotated II.2.18. Potuit produci et fuit de facto secundum Aristotelem et Commenta|torem productus ab aeterno mundus a deo efficientia quae est na|turalis fluxus et effectualis consequtio. annotated II.2.19. Qui negat coelum esse animatum: ita ut motor eius non sit |forma eius non solum Aristoteli repugnat: Sed totius Philoso|phiae fundamenta destruit. annotated II.2.20. In actibus nostri intellectus non est successio ratione potentia|rum sensitivarum et deservientium ut credunt moderni: Sed eo |quia rationalis est. annotated II.2.21. Notitia de novo acquisita fit ex praecedenti cognitione tanquam |ex termino a quo: et tanquam ex causa effectiva partiali: formali: di|rectiva: et tanquam ex causa praedisponente materiali. annotated II.2.22. Ille habitus est practicus qui est formaliter regulativus alicu|ius operationis habituati. annotated II.2.23. Habitus habet esse practicum et speculativum ab obiecto rela|to ad subiectum in quo est: Intellectus autem dicitur practicus vel |speculativus a fine quem sibi proponit habituatus. annotated II.2.¶24. Habitus practicus a speculativo finibus distinguitur. annotated II.2.25. Praxis est operatio quae non est formaliter cognitio: et potest |esse recta: et non recta: rectificabilis per habitum ut per partiale |rectificationis effectivum quo practicans habituatur. annotated II.2.26. Practicum et speculativum sunt differentie accidentalis habitus. annotated II.2.27. Theologia viatoris ut viatoris est: simpliciter practica dicen|da est. annotated II.2.28. Totam medicinam practicam esse: et ut verum asserimus: et ut |consonum dictis ac sententiae Avenrois. annotated II.2.29. Logica est practica. annotated II.2.30. Sensus communis non est distinctus a sensu visus: auditus: odo|ratus: gustus: et tactus. annotated II.2.31. Non dari species intelligibiles a phantasmatibus abstractas et |ut veram: et commentatoris et Alberti sententiam asserimus. annotated II.2.32. In omni quaestione per demonstrationem scibili oportet prae|cognoscere quid subiecti et passionis: non intelligendo per quid |quid nominis ut intelligunt expositores: Sed quid rei. annotated II.2.33. Possibilis est regressus a causa ad effectum absque negatione quam |somniat Burleus. annotated II.2.34. Tenentes minima naturalia in qualitatibus: non propterea ha|bent negare motum alterationis fieri in tempore successive. annotated II.2.35. Necessarium est tenere secundum Avenroem quod forma generis sit rea|liter alia a forma speciei nec oppositum stat cum principiis do|ctrinae suae. annotated II.2.36. Demonstratio Aristotelis in .vii. Physicorum quod omne quod |movetur: movetur ab alio nihil probat eorum quae vel Thom|mas: vel Scotus: vel Egidius quem sequitur Iohanes de Ganda|vo: vel Gratiadeus: vel Burleus: vel alii quos ego legerim inten|dunt: Sed tantum: quod optime dixit Commentator a latinis |omnibus expositoribus male intellectus: et est quod in quolibet mo|to motor est alius a mobili vel secundum naturam vel secundum subiectum. annotated II.2.37. Demonstratio .vii. Physicorum probat evidenter quod coelum non |movetur a se: datis principiis Avenrois veris utique et firmissimis. annotated II.2.38. Ordo librorum naturalis philosophiae ab Aristotele est iste. Li|ber Physicorum: coeli et mundi: de generatione: metheororum: |mineralium: de plantis: de generatione animalium: de partibus |animalium: de progressu animalium: de anima: tum libri qui di|cuntur parvi naturales. Correlarium. Qui librum de anima sextum naturalium vo|cant: ab Aristotelis mente omnino discordant. annotated II.2.39. Omnis via salvans dictum Aristotelis quod venti orientalis sint |calidiores occidentalibus: praeter viam animationis coeli est fri|vola et nulla. annotated II.2.40. Nec ab Aristotele nec ab expositoribus adducte rationes de |salsedine maris sunt sufficientes: nec potest ulla maxime stante |mosaica veritate sufficientior assignari quam causalitas eiusdem uni|versalis providentiae quae et in terra discooperitionem operata est. annotated II.2.41. Nulla pars coeli differt ab alia secundum lucidum et non lucidum: sed |secundum magis et minus lucidum. annotated II.2.42. Modus ab Aristotele datus quomodo calefiant inferiora a su|perioribus nullo modo rectus apparet. annotated II.2.43. Haec duo stant simul et ambo credo simul esse vera: et quod ratio |Avenrois in commento ultimo primi Physicorum contra Avi|cennam concludat et quod cum hoc rationes Avicennae ad proban|dum primum principium sunt bonae et efficaces. annotated II.2.44. Si intelligentias esse in genere secundum Aristotelem dixerit Thom|mas: non minus sibi quam Aristoteli repugnabit. annotated II.2.45. Si unitas generis non est solum ex parte concipientis: Sed eti|am ex parte concepti: necesse est quaecunque sunt in eodem gene|re logico: esse in eodem genere Physico. annotated II.2.46. Scientia est realiter relativa: et scibile ad eam per accidens re|fertur. annotated II.2.47. Tenendo communem modum doctorum: quod scilicet de deo ali|quid formaliter praedicetur: dico duas conclusiones proximas: |quarum haec est prima quod solus deus ita est substantia quod nullo mo|do est non substantia. annotated II.2.48. Secunda: Deus ideo non est in genere quia est substantialiter |substantia. annotated II.2.49. Ponere differentiam inter simitatem et albedinem aut consi|milia accidentia per hoc quod illud separabile sit: illud inseparabile |a certo subiecto fictitium est. annotated II.2.50. Differentia quae inter suprascripta accidentia apparet ex sola |voluntate nominum impositione originatur. annotated II.2.51. Necessarium est dicere secundum Avenroem quod substantia est de in|trinseca quiditate accidentis: et est opinio et Aristoteli et philo|sophiae maxime consona. annotated II.2.52. In definitione substantiarum naturalium non esse ponendam |materiam et Avenroi et Alberto consentanea sententia est. annotated II.2.53. Si Thommas dixerit in intelligentiis secundum Aristotelem esse acci|dentia: non Aristoteli modo: Sed sibiipsi contradicet. annotated II.2.54. Iste propositiones sunt concedende ut omnino vere. Materia |prima fit asinus: bos: et similia. annotated II.2.55. In composito materiali non sunt duae precisae entitates et distin|ctae: Sed una entitas. annotated II.2.56. Sonum non ex motu aeris intercepti inter duo corpora se per|cutientia: ut tenet Aristoteles: et expositores eius: Sed ex contactu |tali talium vel talium corporum: talem vel talem sonum causari dico. annotated II.2.57. Rationes quas adducunt peripatetici ad probandum quod in cau|sis essentialiter ordinatis non eatur in infinitum: non convincunt |de necessitate falsitatem positi. annotated II.2.58. Virtutem sensitivam sensus communis sicuti non a virtutibus |sensitivis sensuum exteriorum ut dixit conclusio .xxx. ita nec a |virtutibus sensitivis sensuum interiorum: phantastica: sive ima|ginativa: cogitativa et memorativa: subiecto id est re differre: et ut |veram: et ut Aristotelis Platonisque sententiam asserimus. annotated II.2.59. Dico omnes qualitates elementorum symbolas: esse diversa|rum specierum. annotated II.2.60. Si qua est ponenda figura quarta syllogismorum: illa est ponenda |quam Galienus ponit: non quam et Franciscus Maironis et Petrus |Mantuanus pueriliter confinxerunt: rectius est tamen nullam ponere. annotated II.2.61. De materia ut ex ea per se fiunt res tractare methaphysicum: |physicum autem ut ex ea res fiunt per accidens habemus dicere |secundum doctrinam Aristotelis. annotated II.2.62. Dictio exclusiva addita uni relativo: correlativum non excludit. annotated II.2.63. Non debet concedi partem in toto quantitativo a suo toto esse |aliquo modo actu distinctam. annotated II.2.64. Opinio quae Avicennae ascribitur quod illud unum: quod cum en|te convertitur sit unum quod est principium numeri: et ita conse|quenter quod unaquaeque res sit una per intentionem additam essen|tiae suae si non est necessario vera: est tamen probabilis et defen|detur a me. annotated II.2.65. Licet potentia intellectiva in nobis sit accidens: in angelis ta|men est substantia. annotated II.2.66. Formalitas est actualitas apta per se perficere possibilem intel|lectum. annotated II.2.67. Si ex concursu elementorum fiat mixtum: quocunque modo po|nantur elementa manere immixto fiet mixtum ex elementis: ut |ex materia digesta a calido spirituali: vaporoso elevato ab eis. annotated II.2.68. In omnibus infra deum eadem est materia secundum essentiam: diver|sa secundum esse. annotated II.2.69. Quiditates physicarum naturarum adequato concepto et pro|prio concipi possunt sine accidentibus: sive a methaphysico sive |a physico considerentur. annotated II.2.70. Corpus organicum quod est materia animae: et ponitur in dif|finitione eius ab Aristotele est corpus et organicum per formam |essentialiter distinctam ab anima eum perficiente. annotated II.2.71. Secundum omnes philosophos dicendum est deum necessario |agere quicquid agit. annotated II.2.72. Qui dubitat ex intelligibili et intellectu magis vere et substan|tialiter fieri unum quam ex materia et forma materiali non est philo|sophus. annotated II.2.73. Tenendo opinionem de anima intellectiva quam tenet Com|mentator: videtur mihi rationabiliter tenendum illam animam nul|lius accidentis esse subiectum: et positionem hanc tanquam veram de|fendam: quanquam utrum hoc ille tenuerit: ego non definio. annotated II.2.74. Dico secundum Thommam dicendum esse in actu reflexo intellectus |consistere beatitudinem nostram. annotated II.2.75. Diffinitio naturae coelestia comprehendit et ly et copulative |tenetur et non disiunctive. annotated II.2.76. Sicut quilibet philosophus habet dicere quod virtutes sensitive |sunt in corde: ita quilibet medicus habet dicere: quod sint in cerebro. annotated II.2.77. Quod dicitur a communi scola philosophantium omnium la|tinorum de prima operatione intellectus: error est: quia non est |alia operatio partis rationalis quam ille duae quas ipsi secundam et |tertiam ponunt Compositio scilicet et Discursus. annotated II.2.78. Accidentia nullo modo debent dici entia: Sed entis. annotated II.2.79. Sex principia sunt formae absolutae. annotated II.2.80. Siqua est lingua prima et non casualis: illam esse Hebraicam |multis patet coniecturis.
ChatGPT
Here is a translation of the *Conclusiones Philosophice secundum propriam opinionem*: 1. A universal species can be immediately abstracted from a species existing in the external senses. 2. A second intention is a rational being that behaves like a qualitative form arising from the operation of the intellect, consequentially, not effectively. 3. Neither the first nor the second intention exists subjectively anywhere. 4. In bodies, there is something that physically locates, but is not itself physically located, and that is the outermost sphere. Similarly, in intelligibles, there is something that intelligibly locates, but is not located in any way, and that is God. *Corollary: We should not ask how the outermost sphere is located, but should simply concede that it is not located.* 5. The singular is not understood by the intellect, neither according to truth nor according to the opinion of Aristotle, the Commentator, and Thomas. 6. Although the intellect does not understand singularly, it is from the intellect that the singular is perfectly known. 7. Whatever thing is constituted in the purity of its being is both intelligent, intellect, and intelligible. 8. From the preceding conclusion, it is understood why matter is the principle of unknowability and the Agent Intellect is the principle of knowability. 9. That action is called immanent which is not subjectively in the one who is passively denominated by it; and in this way, it is distinguished from transient action. 10. Every other method besides the one stated in the previous conclusion is insufficient to distinguish immanent action from transient action. 11. When Averroes says that there is no other means to prove abstraction except through the eternity of motion, he does not mean any abstraction, but that which is abstracted in the ultimate degree of abstraction from the body. 12. Corporeal being is not derived from any substantial form or degree of substantial form. 13. The six transcendentals, as posited by common doctrine, were fabricated by the younger Latins; neither the Greek Peripatetics nor their prince, Aristotle, knew of them. 14. It is necessary, according to Aristotle, that the first cause moves out of necessity. 15. It is impossible and utterly irrational, according to Aristotle, for everything to happen out of necessity, regardless of which cause that necessity is taken to apply. 16. The treatise on suppositions does not belong to logic. 17. The world could not have been from God from eternity through efficient causation, which is a reduction from potentiality to actuality. 18. According to Aristotle and the Commentator, the world could have been and was in fact produced from eternity by God through an efficiency which is a natural flow and effective consequence. 19. Anyone who denies that the heavens are animated, so that their mover is not their form, not only contradicts Aristotle, but destroys the foundations of all philosophy. 20. In the acts of our intellect, succession does not occur due to the sensitive powers serving the intellect, as moderns believe, but rather because the intellect is rational. 21. New knowledge acquired proceeds from preceding knowledge both as from a term from which it begins and as from a partial efficient, formal, directive cause, as well as a predisposing material cause. 22. That habit is practical which is formally regulative of the operation of one possessing the habit. 23. Habit takes its practical and speculative being from the object in relation to the subject in which it exists; however, the intellect is called practical or speculative based on the end proposed by the habit. 24. Practical habit is distinguished from speculative habit by its ends. 25. Practice is an operation which is not formally knowledge; it can be right or not right, and can be rectified by habit, which acts as a partial effective cause of rectification, by which the practitioner acquires the habit. 26. Practical and speculative are accidental differences of habit. 27. Theology for a traveler (i.e., one on a spiritual journey) is simply practical. 28. We assert that all practical medicine is true and in agreement with the words and opinions of Averroes. 29. Logic is practical. 30. The common sense is not distinct from the senses of sight, hearing, smell, taste, and touch. 31. We assert, as true, the opinion of the Commentator and Albertus that intelligible species are not abstracted from phantasms. 32. In every question that can be known by demonstration, it is necessary to first know the "what" of both the subject and the passion, not merely the "what" of the name as the expositors understand it, but the "what" of the thing itself. 33. A regression from cause to effect is possible without the negation that Burley imagines. 34. Those who hold to the existence of natural minima in qualities do not, for that reason, deny that the motion of alteration occurs successively in time. 35. According to Averroes, it is necessary to hold that the form of the genus is really distinct from the form of the species, and the opposite does not stand with the principles of his doctrine. 36. Aristotle’s demonstration in the seventh book of *Physics*—that everything moved is moved by another—proves nothing of what either Thomas, Scotus, Giles, whom John of Ghent follows, Gratian, Burley, or any others I have read intend; but rather, it proves, as the Commentator rightly said and was misunderstood by all the Latin expositors, that in every motion, the mover is distinct from the moved, either in nature or in subject. 37. The demonstration in the seventh book of *Physics* clearly proves that the heavens are not moved by themselves, given the true and firm principles of Averroes. 38. The order of the books of natural philosophy according to Aristotle is as follows: the *Physics*, the *Heavens and the World*, *On Generation*, *Meteorology*, *Mineralogy*, *On Plants*, *On the Generation of Animals*, *On the Parts of Animals*, *On the Progress of Animals*, and *On the Soul*, along with the books called the *Parva Naturalia*. *Corollary: Those who call the book *On the Soul* the sixth of the natural books entirely disagree with Aristotle’s mind.* 39. Any method other than that of the animation of the heavens used to explain why eastern winds are warmer than western ones is frivolous and null. 40. Neither the reasons brought by Aristotle nor by the expositors about the salinity of the sea are sufficient, and no reason more sufficient can be assigned than the causality of universal providence, which also brought about the uncovering of the land. 41. No part of the heavens differs from another in terms of luminous and non-luminous, but rather in terms of more or less luminous. 42. The method given by Aristotle to explain how the lower regions are heated by the higher regions does not appear correct in any way. 43. These two statements stand together and I believe both are true: that Averroes’ reasoning in the last commentary of the first book of *Physics* against Avicenna is conclusive, and at the same time that the reasoning of Avicenna to prove the first principle is good and effective. 44. If Thomas said that intelligences are in a genus according to Aristotle, he would contradict not only Aristotle but also himself. 45. If the unity of a genus exists not only on the part of the conceiver but also on the part of the concept, then it is necessary that whatever is in the same logical genus is also in the same physical genus. 46. Science is really relative, and the knowable is related to it accidentally. 47. Following the common method of doctors, that something is formally predicated of God, I assert two conclusions: the first is that God alone is such a substance that in no way is He not a substance. 48. Second: God is not in a genus because He is substantially substance. 49. To posit a difference between curvature and whiteness or similar accidents on the basis that one is separable and the other is inseparable from a certain subject is fictitious. 50. The difference between the aforementioned accidents arises solely from the imposition of names by the will. 51. It is necessary to say, following Averroes, that substance is intrinsic to the quiddity of an accident, and this opinion is most in agreement with Aristotle and philosophy. 52. In the definition of natural substances, it is not necessary to include matter, which is in agreement with both Averroes and Albertus. 53. If Thomas said that there are accidents in intelligences according to Aristotle, he would not only contradict Aristotle but also himself. 54. These propositions must be accepted as entirely true: prime matter becomes a donkey, an ox, and similar beings. 55. In a material composite, there are not two precise and distinct entities, but one entity. 56. I assert that sound is not caused by the motion of air trapped between two striking bodies, as Aristotle and his expositors hold, but rather by the contact of certain bodies producing such and such a sound. 57. The reasons that the Peripatetics bring forth to prove that in essentially ordered causes there cannot be an infinite regress do not necessarily demonstrate the falsity of the contrary position. 58
ChatGPT
. Just as the sensitive powers of the common sense are not distinct from the sensitive powers of the external senses, as stated in Conclusion 30, so neither are they distinct from the sensitive powers of the internal senses—fantasy, imagination, cogitation, and memory—and I assert this as true and in agreement with the opinions of Aristotle and Plato. 59. I assert that all the qualities of the elements are of different species. 60. If a fourth figure of syllogisms is to be posited, it is the one posited by Galen, not the one clumsily fabricated by Francis of Meyronnes and Peter of Mantua; it is better, however, to posit none at all. 61. The metaphysician should treat matter as something from which things come to be per se; the physicist, however, should treat it as something from which things come to be accidentally, according to the doctrine of Aristotle. 62. The exclusive addition to one relative does not exclude the correlative. 63. It should not be conceded that a part of a quantitative whole is in any way actually distinct from its whole. 64. The opinion attributed to Avicenna, that the one which is convertible with being is the one that is the principle of number, and that consequently each thing is one by an intention added to its essence, if not necessarily true, is nonetheless probable and will be defended by me. 65. Although the intellective power in us is an accident, in angels it is a substance. 66. Formalness is the actuality suited to perfect the possible intellect by itself. 67. If a mixture is made from the conjunction of elements, in whatever way the elements are posited to remain in the mixture, the mixture is made from the elements, as from matter digested by heat, spiritual and vaporous, and elevated by them. 68. In all things below God, matter is the same in essence, but different in being. 69. The quiddities of physical natures can be adequately and properly conceived without accidents, whether they are considered by the metaphysician or the physicist. 70. The organic body, which is the matter of the soul and is posited in its definition by Aristotle, is both body and organic through a form essentially distinct from the soul that perfects it. 71. According to all philosophers, we must say that God necessarily does whatever He does. 72. Anyone who doubts that the intelligible and the intellect are more truly and substantially united than matter and material form is not a philosopher. 73. Following the opinion of the Commentator on the intellective soul, it seems reasonable to hold that the soul is not the subject of any accident, and I will defend this position as true, although I do not definitively claim whether he held this. 74. I say, following Thomas, that our beatitude consists in the reflexive act of the intellect. 75. The definition of nature encompasses celestial bodies, and this is held copulatively, not disjunctively. 76. Just as every philosopher must say that the sensitive powers are in the heart, so every physician must say that they are in the brain. 77. What is said by the common school of Latin philosophers about the first operation of the intellect is an error: because there is no other operation of the rational part than the two they call the second and third, namely, composition and discourse. 78. Accidents should in no way be called beings, but beings of beings. 79. The six principles are absolute forms. 80. If there is a first language and it is not arbitrary, it is likely to be Hebrew based on many conjectures. This translation covers Pico's conclusions in the *Conclusiones Philosophice secundum propriam opinionem*.
You
give a close reading of the 80 conclusions you just translated
ChatGPT
A close reading of Pico’s *Conclusiones Philosophice secundum propriam opinionem*, number 80, reveals several key themes and philosophical interventions. Here's a breakdown of the conclusions: ### Abstract Concepts and Universal Forms - II.2.1 and II.2.2 discuss the abstraction of universal forms from sensory experience, focusing on how the intellect forms concepts beyond the immediate objects of sense perception. The conclusions argue that abstract universals can arise directly from sensory experiences, with second intentions being qualitative and arising from intellectual operations, not from external objects themselves. - II.2.7 and II.2.8 push further into this notion of universality, suggesting that anything constituted in its pure being is both "intelligent" and "intelligible." This marks a distinctly Neoplatonic element in Pico's thinking, where intelligibility and intelligence are bound together, echoing the metaphysical unity of being. ### The Nature of the Intellect - II.2.4 addresses the outermost sphere (likely referring to the celestial spheres of medieval cosmology) as being unmoved and purely intellectual, a position that ties into the Neoplatonic and Aristotelian cosmologies where the Prime Mover or God is considered beyond physical locality or material conditions. - II.2.5 and II.2.6 raise important issues regarding the intellect's ability to grasp singular objects, arguing that the intellect does not understand singulars directly but can perfectly know them through its operations. This challenges Aristotle’s and Thomas Aquinas’ views of how the intellect interacts with singular things, pushing toward a more abstract and universalist understanding of knowledge. - II.2.11 makes an important Averroistic point about abstraction, noting that full abstraction from the body can only be demonstrated through the eternity of motion—a doctrine that places the intellect in a realm of eternal, non-material existence. - II.2.74 returns to Thomas Aquinas’ notion that the beatific vision, or the ultimate happiness of the soul, resides in the reflexive act of the intellect. This ties together Pico’s broader exploration of the intellect’s divine or beatific capabilities. ### Immanence and Transcendence in Action - II.2.9 and II.2.10 contrast immanent and transient actions, defining immanent action as that which remains within the subject performing it. This distinction is important in Pico’s metaphysics and theology because it suggests that higher, intellectual actions—like those of God or the celestial beings—are self-contained and not directed toward external objects. - II.2.15 and II.2.16 grapple with Aristotelian metaphysics and causal necessity. Pico argues that while Aristotle holds that the first cause acts from necessity, it would be irrational to claim that everything happens by necessity. This is an attempt to reconcile free will with causal necessity, reflecting a sophisticated engagement with medieval interpretations of Aristotelian causality. ### Critiques of Contemporary Philosophy - II.2.13 critiques the invention of the six transcendentals by the “younger Latins,” asserting that these concepts were unknown to the original Greek Peripatetics, including Aristotle. This reveals Pico's critical stance toward scholastic developments that he felt departed from the original philosophical spirit of the Greeks. - II.2.52 and II.2.53 critique the inclusion of accidents in the metaphysical treatment of intelligences (i.e., angels or intellects). Pico argues, following Averroes and Aristotle, that matter should not be included in the definition of natural substances, maintaining the purity of intelligences as immaterial beings. This reflects a philosophical move away from scholastic materialism toward a more Platonic immaterialism. ### Metaphysics of Form and Matter - II.2.12 and II.2.68 explore the relationship between form, matter, and corporeality. Pico asserts that corporeal being is not derived from any substantial form, pushing against Aristotelian hylomorphism (the view that substances are composites of form and matter). He also posits that matter is the same in essence but differs in its mode of being, aligning with a more abstract, universal conception of matter as potentiality. - II.2.19 directly defends the idea that the heavens are animated, with their mover being their form. Denying this, Pico argues, undermines the foundations of philosophy, as it contradicts the essential metaphysical structure of the cosmos where form and intellect drive celestial motion. ### Practical and Speculative Knowledge - II.2.22 through II.2.26 explore the distinction between practical and speculative knowledge. Pico emphasizes that practical knowledge is regulative and that the practical and speculative aspects of knowledge are distinguished by their ends. This division is a fundamental aspect of medieval and Renaissance philosophy, wherein practical philosophy (ethics, politics) is distinct from speculative philosophy (metaphysics, theology). - II.2.27 asserts that theology for those on a spiritual journey should be considered practical, not speculative. This introduces a mystical or spiritual dimension into Pico’s thought, suggesting that theology is not merely theoretical but should guide one’s actions and life. ### Engagement with Aristotle, Averroes, and Avicenna - II.2.17 and II.2.18 show Pico engaging with Aristotle, Averroes, and Avicenna on the question of whether the world was created eternally. Pico appears to side with the idea that the world, as an eternal production, aligns with a natural flow or consequence of God’s being, rather than a temporal act of creation. This reflects a sophisticated attempt to harmonize Aristotelian, Neoplatonic, and Islamic philosophical traditions. ### The Unity of Being and Intellect - II.2.72 emphasizes that the union of the intelligible and the intellect is more real and substantial than that of matter and form. This conclusion elevates the intellect to the highest metaphysical status, in line with Neoplatonic and Aristotelian views where intellectual apprehension is seen as the most perfect form of unity. - II.2.66 posits that formalness (or formality) is the actuality that perfects the possible intellect. This highlights the importance of intellectual form in actualizing potential knowledge, a key theme in both Aristotelian and Neoplatonic thought. ### Criticism of Scholasticism - II.2.77 criticizes the common Latin scholastic understanding of the operations of the intellect, claiming that there are no other operations of the rational part beyond composition and discourse. This challenges the dominant scholastic account of how the intellect operates, aligning Pico more closely with earlier Greek philosophical traditions. ### Conclusion of the Close Reading Pico’s *Conclusiones Philosophice* represent a deeply synthetic and critical engagement with the philosophical traditions of Aristotle, Averroes, Avicenna, and Neoplatonism. He critiques scholastic developments that he sees as straying from the original insights of the Greeks and Arab philosophers, advocating for a return to more universal and abstract conceptions of being, knowledge, and the intellect. Through this, Pico seeks to harmonize the intellectual traditions of the Greeks, Arabs, and medieval Latins, while also infusing his own mystical and metaphysical insights. His work suggests a vision of philosophy that transcends the particularities of scholastic logic and metaphysics, moving toward a more integrated understanding of the cosmos as driven by intellectual and divine principles.
ChatGPT
### Formal Universals and Logic - II.2.1 emphasizes the possibility of abstracting universal species directly from sensory experience. This reflects Pico’s engagement with Aristotelian epistemology, where knowledge begins with the senses but is elevated to universals by the intellect. Here, Pico asserts that the intellect can move immediately from the particular (perceived by the senses) to the universal, bypassing intermediate steps. This is an important claim in the debate between realists and nominalists in medieval philosophy, as it advocates a more direct realist position. - II.2.2 elaborates on the idea of second intentions—concepts that arise not from external objects but from the intellect's operations. These are forms that emerge as the intellect processes and categorizes experience. This distinction between first and second intentions was a central issue in medieval logic, where first intentions refer to objects as they are in themselves, while second intentions refer to the logical relationships between those objects. - II.2.3 adds that neither first nor second intentions exist subjectively, meaning that they do not exist as independent entities in the mind. Rather, they are logical constructs that arise through intellectual operations. This is in line with the realist position Pico generally defends, but it also shows his subtle awareness of the role of the intellect in forming knowledge, blurring the line between realism and a certain conceptualism. ### The Nature of Corporeality and the Divine - II.2.4 introduces the idea that there is something in the cosmos—namely, the ultimate sphere—that is so pure that it locates other things corporeally but is not itself subject to corporeal location. This is a clear reference to the Neoplatonic and Aristotelian conception of the Prime Mover or the outermost celestial sphere, which imparts motion to the cosmos without itself being in motion or subject to physical conditions. The corollary extends this point, arguing that the Prime Mover should not be subject to the usual questions about location or movement. - II.2.12 takes this cosmological framework further by stating that corporeality does not come from any specific form or degree of substantiality, challenging the traditional Aristotelian view that corporeal things are composites of form and matter. This indicates Pico's departure from strict Aristotelian hylomorphism, aligning more with Neoplatonic ideas of form and intellect being primary, while matter is secondary or derivative. - II.2.14 posits that according to Aristotle, the first cause moves necessarily. This aligns with the Aristotelian conception of the Prime Mover, who moves the cosmos as an object of desire, not as an efficient cause. Pico, however, emphasizes the necessity of this movement, drawing on Aristotelian metaphysics to assert the consistency of cosmic order. - II.2.15 counters this claim by arguing that it is irrational to claim that everything happens by necessity. This reflects Pico’s desire to maintain a balance between necessity and contingency in the cosmos, defending the possibility of free will and divine intervention within a system governed by necessary causes. ### Metaphysics of Motion and Matter - II.2.17 and II.2.18 deal with the eternality of the world and its creation. Pico here engages with the long-standing debate between the Aristotelian and Christian views on the creation of the world. While Aristotelian philosophy (as interpreted by Averroes) holds that the world is eternal, Pico carefully suggests that while the world was produced eternally by God, it is not eternal in the same sense as God. This is an important distinction that allows Pico to harmonize Aristotelian eternalism with Christian creationism, presenting a nuanced philosophical and theological synthesis. - II.2.19 defends the view that the heavens are animated and that their mover is their form. This conclusion aligns with the Aristotelian and Neoplatonic understanding of the cosmos, where celestial bodies are not inanimate but possess a form of life or intelligence that governs their motion. This idea was foundational in medieval cosmology, where the heavens were seen as living, intelligent beings moved by divine intellects or angelic beings. ### Intellect, Abstraction, and Sensory Knowledge - II.2.21 through II.2.23 address the process of acquiring knowledge, emphasizing the role of prior cognition as a prerequisite for new knowledge. Pico argues that new knowledge is always built upon prior understanding, whether as an efficient cause, a formal cause, or a material predisposition. This echoes the Aristotelian notion that knowledge is cumulative and builds upon previous experiences and insights. - II.2.24 and II.2.25 distinguish between practical and speculative knowledge, reinforcing the classical philosophical distinction. Practical knowledge is regulative, dealing with action, while speculative knowledge is contemplative, dealing with understanding. This differentiation is important for Pico’s philosophical system, which seeks to integrate both forms of knowledge in a harmonious whole. - II.2.27 extends this distinction to theology, arguing that theology for those on a spiritual journey should be considered practical, not merely speculative. This introduces a mystical dimension to Pico’s theology, where theological knowledge is not an end in itself but a guide for practical living and spiritual ascent. ### Critique of Scholastic Logic and Causality - II.2.29 makes the claim that logic itself is practical, likely referring to the way that logical systems guide thought and reasoning, and are thus not purely speculative but have practical consequences in guiding correct reasoning. - II.2.36 criticizes the scholastic interpretations of Aristotle’s demonstration that everything that moves is moved by something else, arguing that they have misunderstood Aristotle’s point. This highlights Pico’s critical stance toward the prevailing interpretations of Aristotle by scholastic thinkers like Thomas Aquinas, John Duns Scotus, and Giles of Rome. Pico argues for a return to a more direct understanding of Aristotle’s original intent. ### The Role of the Agent Intellect - II.2.66 and II.2.72 explore the nature of the intellect and its relationship to intelligible objects. Pico follows the Averroistic tradition in asserting that the unity between the intellect and intelligible objects is more substantial than the unity between form and matter in material objects. This places the intellect in a higher metaphysical realm, where knowledge is not merely a passive reception but an active unification with the object of knowledge. ### Practical Applications and Mysticism - II.2.30 through II.2.32 explore the role of the common sense in integrating the sensory faculties, arguing that the common sense is not distinct from the other sensory faculties but is unified with them. This reflects the Aristotelian view of common sense as the faculty that integrates sensory information, a view that was highly influential in medieval theories of perception. - II.2.37 through II.2.39 discuss celestial phenomena, offering a critique of contemporary explanations of how the heavens affect the earth. Pico seems to favor a more mystical or providential explanation of natural phenomena, tying them to divine providence rather than purely mechanical causes. This reflects his broader project of integrating mysticism and natural philosophy, where the natural world is seen as an expression of divine will. ### Conclusion of the Close Reading Pico’s *Conclusiones Philosophice* present a deeply synthetic philosophical vision, integrating insights from Aristotle, Averroes, Avicenna, Neoplatonism, and Christian theology. His conclusions challenge the prevailing scholastic interpretations of Aristotle, offering a more direct engagement with Greek and Arab sources. Throughout the *Conclusiones*, Pico emphasizes the primacy of the intellect and its capacity to unite with intelligible objects, presenting a vision of knowledge as an act of unification and transformation. His metaphysics bridges the gap between Aristotelian materialism and Neoplatonic immaterialism, suggesting that while matter and form are important, the ultimate reality is intellectual and divine.

continue
ChatGPT
Continuing from where the close reading left off, we delve further into Pico’s conclusions regarding the interrelationship between intellect, metaphysics, and practical knowledge. ### Intellectual Cognition and Unity - II.2.73 reinforces the idea that the intellect, particularly the intellective soul, is not a subject of accidents. Pico is engaging here with the Aristotelian and Averroistic traditions, which hold that the intellect, as something immaterial, cannot be subject to material accidents. This conclusion aligns with Pico’s broader metaphysical vision that places the intellect in a higher ontological realm, where it interacts with pure forms and universals, distinct from the material, perishable world. - II.2.74 further develops this by referencing Thomas Aquinas' position that human beatitude, or ultimate happiness, consists in the reflexive act of the intellect. This is a distinctly Christianized version of Aristotelian intellectualism, in which ultimate fulfillment is found in the intellect’s self-awareness and contemplation of the divine. Pico’s agreement with Aquinas here reflects his effort to harmonize Christian and classical philosophical doctrines, positioning the intellect’s beatific function as central to both metaphysics and theology. - II.2.72 takes this even further, suggesting that the unity between intellect and intelligible is more substantial than that of form and matter. This is a key Neoplatonic idea—derived especially from Plotinus—where the act of knowing is not merely a passive reception but a true unification of the knower and the known. This metaphysical unity of intellect and form elevates the process of cognition to a divine level, resonating with mystical traditions as well. ### Critique of Scholastic Positions on Substance and Form - II.2.75 addresses a specific scholastic issue regarding the definition of natural substances. By stating that celestial nature is comprehensive and copulative (not disjunctive), Pico is likely pointing to a holistic understanding of celestial substances, possibly contrasting with scholastic views that fragmented substance into categories. This reflects his broader effort to reconcile Aristotelian cosmology with Neoplatonic unity. - II.2.77 offers a pointed critique of the common view among Latin philosophers regarding the operations of the intellect. Pico argues that the intellect does not have multiple operations but only two—composition and discourse. This is a direct challenge to the scholastic tradition, which often multiplied the intellectual operations (such as apprehension, judgment, and reasoning). By simplifying the operations of the intellect, Pico emphasizes the fundamental unity of intellectual activity, aligning more with the Neoplatonic and Peripatetic traditions. - II.2.79 returns to metaphysics with the assertion that the six principles commonly held as absolute forms (likely referring to the transcendentals) are real forms. Here, Pico aligns himself with a more abstract metaphysical system, where the principles that govern reality are seen as absolute and transcendent. This reflects his broader metaphysical vision, where forms and universals occupy a central role in both the structure of reality and the operations of the intellect. ### Reconciling Ancient Philosophers with Scholastic Thought - II.2.47 through II.2.49 present Pico’s effort to reconcile Aristotelian philosophy with scholastic interpretations, particularly those related to divine substance. In these conclusions, Pico argues that while God is substantively a substance, God is not "in a genus" because He is beyond any form of categorization. This reflects the classical theological doctrine that God, as the first cause, transcends all categories of being and substance. Pico's conclusions here show his deep engagement with the metaphysical and theological problems concerning divine simplicity and transcendence, borrowing heavily from both scholastic and classical sources. - II.2.51 discusses substance and accidents, asserting the essential unity of substance and rejecting the separation of accidents from substance. This is significant because it shows Pico’s philosophical alignment with earlier, purer forms of Aristotelianism, avoiding the more intricate scholastic debates over the nature of substance and accidents that developed later. - II.2.57 and II.2.58 offer a critique of Peripatetic philosophy regarding the issue of causality. Pico argues that the typical demonstrations used to prove that there cannot be an infinite regress in essential causes are insufficient. This suggests Pico’s engagement with both scholastic and Arabic commentaries on Aristotle, where the problem of causality and infinity is frequently debated. His critique implies that the methods of proving causal chains are lacking and that there needs to be a re-examination of Aristotle’s original intent. ### The Nature of Knowledge and Universals - II.2.64 makes a complex metaphysical claim about the nature of unity and being, referring to Avicenna’s view that unity is convertible with being. This is part of the broader medieval debate over whether unity is a property added to being or inherent in being itself. Pico sides with the more Neoplatonic interpretation, where unity is a fundamental aspect of being, rather than a secondary property. - II.2.65 makes a fascinating claim about the intellect, arguing that in humans, the intellective power is an accident, but in angels, it is a substance. This ties into the medieval hierarchical cosmology, where angels are seen as purely intellectual beings, without the material constraints that humans experience. Pico’s metaphysics here integrates Christian angelology with Aristotelian and Neoplatonic views on the intellect, emphasizing the distinction between human and angelic modes of cognition. ### Practical Philosophy and the Role of Reason - II.2.22 through II.2.26 focus on practical and speculative habits, outlining a framework where practical philosophy is distinct from speculative philosophy based on its ends. Practical philosophy deals with action and is regulative, while speculative philosophy is contemplative and deals with knowledge. Pico’s conclusions here align with the classical distinction between ethics (practical) and metaphysics (speculative), but he adds a unique element by suggesting that theology, for those on a spiritual journey, is ultimately practical. - II.2.29 emphasizes that logic itself is a practical discipline. This reflects Pico’s view that logical reasoning has practical consequences for the way we think and act. By framing logic as practical, Pico bridges the gap between the speculative and the practical, suggesting that intellectual exercises (even in abstract reasoning) are ultimately directed toward guiding action and life. ### Cosmic Order and Celestial Influence - II.2.41 through II.2.43 delve into the nature of the heavens and their influence on the earthly realm. Pico critiques common explanations for celestial phenomena, suggesting that they are insufficient without considering divine providence. This shows Pico’s attempt to reconcile natural philosophy with theology, where the natural world is not merely mechanical but deeply imbued with divine purpose and order. - II.2.57 critiques the common scholastic view that causal chains cannot regress infinitely. Pico here engages deeply with Aristotelian metaphysics, suggesting that the methods used to demonstrate finite causal chains are insufficient. His engagement with both Aristotelian and scholastic thought reveals his desire to push beyond the limitations of scholastic reasoning to arrive at a more direct understanding of causality, possibly influenced by Neoplatonic ideas of emanation and unity. ### Conclusion of the Close Reading In sum, Pico’s *Conclusiones Philosophice* are a profound synthesis of Aristotelian, Averroistic, Neoplatonic, and Christian thought. He critiques the prevailing scholastic interpretations of Aristotle, advocating for a return to a more direct engagement with Greek and Arabic philosophical traditions. Pico emphasizes the primacy of the intellect, which he sees as not merely receptive but as actively uniting with the intelligible objects it contemplates. This metaphysical unity is central to Pico’s vision of knowledge and being. Moreover, Pico’s conclusions challenge the prevailing scholastic notions of causality, substance, and accidents, offering instead a vision where intellectual and divine realities are primary, and material existence is secondary. Ultimately, Pico seeks to harmonize practical and speculative knowledge, emphasizing that even abstract philosophical and theological inquiries should guide the way one lives and engages with the world.
You
Write me an essay on Pico's encounter with Averroes as it impacts his intervention on the Christian Platonist tradition.
ChatGPT
### Pico della Mirandola's Encounter with Averroes and Its Impact on His Intervention in the Christian Platonist Tradition Giovanni Pico della Mirandola (1463-1494) stands as a towering figure in Renaissance thought, not only for his ambitious goal of harmonizing various philosophical and theological traditions but also for his deep engagement with Islamic and Jewish intellectual heritage. Among these influences, the philosophy of Averroes (Ibn Rushd) played a crucial role in shaping Pico's ideas, especially in relation to his broader intervention in the Christian Platonist tradition. Pico's engagement with Averroes was complex: while he was often critical of Averroes' interpretation of Aristotle, he nonetheless integrated key elements of Averroism into his own synthesis, thereby offering a nuanced contribution to Christian Platonism. In this essay, we will explore how Pico's encounter with Averroes influenced his metaphysical, epistemological, and theological ideas, as well as how this encounter impacted his larger project of synthesizing Platonic and Aristotelian thought within a Christian framework. We will analyze Pico’s *Conclusiones*, his *Oration*, and his engagement with Averroes on the nature of the intellect and its place in the cosmic order. ### Averroes in the Intellectual Landscape of Renaissance Europe Averroes, known as "The Commentator" for his extensive and influential commentaries on Aristotle, had a profound influence on medieval and Renaissance philosophy. His interpretation of Aristotle, especially regarding the nature of the intellect, was revolutionary and deeply controversial in both Islamic and Christian contexts. Averroes proposed that the *intellectus agens* (active intellect) is a single, universal, and eternal entity shared by all humans, and it operates independently of individual human minds. This idea, known as the "unity of the intellect," clashed with the Christian doctrine of personal immortality, which holds that each soul is unique and immortal. In medieval Christian Europe, Averroism became a hotly debated school of thought. It was condemned by the Catholic Church, particularly due to its implications for individual immortality and its apparent denial of personal responsibility in the afterlife. Nevertheless, Averroes' ideas were deeply influential on thinkers such as Thomas Aquinas, Siger of Brabant, and later, Giovanni Pico della Mirandola. Pico was aware of these debates and engaged with Averroes in a manner that was both critical and appreciative. He saw in Averroes a powerful and rigorous interpreter of Aristotle but also recognized the limitations of Averroes' strict Aristotelianism when it came to reconciling Greek philosophy with Christian theology. ### The Problem of the Agent Intellect One of the central areas where Pico encounters Averroes is the question of the *intellectus agens*, or the active intellect. According to Averroes, the active intellect is a separate, divine substance that illuminates the passive intellects of individual human beings, enabling them to think and understand universals. For Averroes, this active intellect is shared among all humans and does not belong to any one individual. This view is often understood as a denial of individual intellectual immortality, which poses a significant challenge to Christian theology, where the immortal soul is a cornerstone of belief. Pico, in his *Conclusiones*, directly engages with Averroes’ ideas on the unity of the intellect. For example, in his *Conclusio* I.7.2, Pico paraphrases Averroes' claim that "Una est anima intellectiva in omnibus hominibus" (There is one intellective soul in all men). However, Pico's interpretation of this idea is far more nuanced than a simple acceptance or rejection. While Pico acknowledges the existence of a universal intellect, he does not deny the immortality of individual souls. Instead, he integrates this Averroistic idea into a broader metaphysical framework influenced by Neoplatonism, where individual souls can partake in the divine intellect while retaining their uniqueness. In this way, Pico attempts to reconcile the Averroistic notion of a shared, universal intellect with the Christian Platonist belief in personal immortality. For Pico, the human soul's ability to ascend toward the divine intellect (or God) does not negate the soul's individuality but rather perfects it. This ascent is key to Pico's metaphysical vision, where the soul moves through different levels of intellectual and spiritual understanding, ultimately uniting with God without losing its unique identity. ### The Role of the Intellect in Pico’s Metaphysics and Angelology In Pico's metaphysics, the *intellectus agens* takes on a significant role as the bridge between human intellects and the divine order. The active intellect, which for Averroes was a universal, external force, becomes in Pico's hands a tool for human spiritual ascent. In Pico's *Oration on the Dignity of Man*, he describes humanity's unique capacity to choose its own nature and to ascend toward the divine through intellectual and spiritual effort. This process of ascent is facilitated by the intellect's ability to grasp divine truths and partake in the divine intellect, which Pico often describes using Neoplatonic terminology. Pico's engagement with Averroes becomes even more apparent in his angelology. In the *Conclusiones* and the *Oration*, Pico describes the hierarchy of angels as an intellectual order, where higher angels are closer to God and possess a more immediate understanding of divine truths. These angels, much like Averroes' active intellect, illuminate the lower intellects of both humans and lower angels. However, Pico diverges from Averroes by insisting that individual human souls can also ascend this intellectual hierarchy, gradually becoming more like the angels through the exercise of their intellect and the practice of virtue. In Pico's angelology, the human intellect plays a crucial role in mediating between the material and the divine. This is where Pico's synthesis of Averroism and Neoplatonism becomes most apparent: while Averroes emphasized the intellect's ability to abstract universal truths from particular experiences, Pico extends this capacity to include the mystical ascent of the soul toward divine union. In this ascent, the intellect is not merely an abstracting faculty but a transformative one, leading the soul closer to God and, ultimately, to the angelic state. ### Magic, Kabbalah, and the Role of the Active Intellect Pico’s encounter with Averroes also influences his views on magic and Kabbalah. In his *Conclusiones* and *Oration*, Pico defends the use of magic and Kabbalah as legitimate means of spiritual ascent. For Pico, magic is not simply a set of rituals for controlling nature, but a way of accessing higher intellectual and spiritual realities. The *intellectus agens*, in this context, becomes the means through which the magician gains knowledge of the divine order and manipulates the natural world in accordance with divine will. Pico's engagement with Kabbalah, especially in his discussions of the sefirot, also reflects his integration of Averroistic and Neoplatonic ideas. The sefirot, or divine emanations, can be seen as analogous to the levels of intellect in Neoplatonism and the various levels of the soul in Christian Platonism. For Pico, the sefirot represent different aspects of the divine intellect, which the human soul can come to know through intellectual and mystical ascent. The active intellect, as understood by Averroes, is thus transformed into a Kabbalistic tool for understanding the divine mysteries and for bringing the human soul closer to God. ### Pico’s Critique of Averroes and His Christian Platonist Synthesis While Pico incorporates many elements of Averroism into his own thought, he is also deeply critical of Averroes, particularly when Averroes' ideas seem to conflict with Christian doctrine. For example, Pico rejects Averroes’ strict separation between the active intellect and individual souls. In Pico’s view, the human soul is not merely a passive recipient of intellectual illumination from the active intellect, but an active participant in the process of intellectual and spiritual ascent. Pico’s critique of Averroes is most clearly articulated in his *Conclusio* I.7.3, where he accuses Averroes of corrupting Aristotle’s philosophy and of misunderstanding the true nature of intellectual union. While Averroes held that the ultimate happiness of human beings consists in the intellectual union with the active intellect, Pico insists that this union must also involve the individual soul's participation in the divine. For Pico, the ultimate goal of intellectual and spiritual ascent is not merely an abstract union with the active intellect, but a personal and transformative union with God. Thus, Pico’s encounter with Averroes is marked by both appropriation and critique. On the one hand, Pico adopts many Averroistic ideas about the intellect, the cosmos, and the nature of knowledge. On the other hand, he modifies these ideas in order to integrate them into a broader Christian Platonist framework, where individual souls retain their uniqueness even as they ascend toward divine union. ### Conclusion: Pico’s Averroistic Platonism In his encounter with Averroes, Pico della Mirandola demonstrates his ability to navigate between different philosophical traditions and to synthesize them in a creative and original way. While he adopts many aspects of Averroes’ philosophy—especially regarding the nature of the intellect and the cosmos—he also critiques and transforms these ideas to fit within a Christian Platonist framework. For Pico, the intellect is not merely a passive recipient of divine illumination, but an active participant in the soul's ascent toward God. Through this synthesis of Averroism and Christian Platonism, Pico makes a significant contribution to Renaissance thought, demonstrating the possibility of reconciling diverse philosophical traditions in the service of a unified spiritual and intellectual vision.
You
Use this Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy article to improve your essay on Pico and Averroes. Discuss the disagreement with Ficino, and the influence of Dionysius on Aquinas's angelology as it impacts Pico's metaphysical speculations. Ibn Rushd [Averroes] First published Wed Jun 23, 2021 The Andalusian philosopher, physician and judge Ibn Rushd (1126–1198) is one of the great figures of philosophy within the Muslim contexts, and a foundational source for post-classical European thought. The hallmarks of Ibn Rushd’s work are his convictions that philosophy is capable of demonstrative certainty in many domains, that it is Aristotle who should be our preeminent guide in philosophy, and that philosophy should play a central role within religious inquiry, rather than being an alternative to religion. But part of what gives his ideas their enduring interest is the subtle way in which he promotes other methods of reasoning and persuasion in contexts where the rigors of Aristotelian demonstration are not a practical option. To grasp Ibn Rushd’s thought in full requires attending not only to the Aristotelian commentaries where he attempts to develop philosophy as a demonstrative science, but also to areas like religion, medicine, and law, where constraints of both subject-matter and audience require other argumentative and rhetorical techniques. Often improperly referred to as Averroes—the corrupted form his name took in Latin—Ibn Rushd quickly achieved such prominence in later European thought as to rival the influence of Aristotle himself, whose works Ibn Rushd tirelessly championed. Most modern scholarship orients itself around his reception in Christian Europe, where he was known simply as “the Commentator,” and so fails to appreciate Ibn Rushd’s own distinctive philosophical achievements. 1. Life and Works 1.1 Life 1.2 Works 2. Logic and Methodology 3. Metaphysics 4. Natural Philosophy 5. Psychology 6. Religion 6.1 God 6.2 Law 7. Medicine 8. Ethics and Politics 9. Reception 9.1 Arabic 9.2 Hebrew 9.3 Latin Bibliography A. Works of Ibn Rushd B. Other Works Academic Tools Other Internet Resources Related Entries 1. Life and Works 1.1 Life Abū al-Walīd Muḥammad ibn Ahmad Ibn Rushd was born in Cordova in 1126. He belonged to an influential Andalusian family, famous for its judicial power and for its scholarship in the religious sciences. His father was a prominent judge, but the most important figure in the family was his grandfather, who also bears his name, Ibn Rushd, and so the philosopher is called “the grandson” (al-ḥafīd) to distinguish him from his grandfather (al-jadd). The latter was both a well-known judge and a famed jurist, being the author of many books in jurisprudence following the Mālikī school. Unlike Ibn Sīnā and al-Ghazālī, Ibn Rushd did not write an autobiography, and as a result many aspects of his life are obscure and will remain so unless new documents are discovered. The limited information we have from his biographers unanimously agrees on his good conduct, his diligence in science, and his fairness as a judge, while noting his interests in philosophy and his adoption of certain “audacious” views. The surviving historical sources tell us much about his teachers in the religious sciences, but, with the exception of medicine, we know little about those who taught him in other fields. He was certainly not a disciple of either of his famous Andalusian contemporaries, Ibn Bājja or Ibn Tufayl, although he read their philosophical works. (Puig 1992 and Ben Sharīfa 1999 discuss the intellectual circles around Ibn Rushd.) Ibn Rushd was 22 when the Almohads came to power in the western Maghreb and Andalusia. Given that the Ibn Rushds had been prominent in circles close to the previous Almoravid dynasty, it was imperative for the grandson to express in his writings, and perhaps even in person, his commitment to the new rulers and the Almohad creed (daʿwa) conceptualized by Muḥammad Ibn Tūmart (d. 1130). Some surviving testimonies suggest that Ibn Rushd did in fact adopt Ibn Tūmart’s creed at some point in his life (see Ben Sharīfa 1999). Given the social position of his family, Ibn Rushd soon found himself in the ruling circles of Marrakesh and close to the princes, or at least some of them, in Andalusia. He engaged in debates on philosophical and theological issues with this inner circle, and there is a record of a meeting with Abū Yaʿqūb Yūsuf (r. 1163–84), the second Almohad ruler, who officially asked Ibn Rushd to comment on Aristotle’s works and render them accessible. Later he became chief physician to the caliph in Marrakesh. Nevertheless, Ibn Rushd’s relationship with the Almohad creed was complex and seems to have evolved (Geoffroy 1999; Ben Ahmed 2020c). Recently discovered revisions to his al-Kashf ʿan manāhij al-adilla contain paragraphs where Ibn Rushd shows a sort of critical distance towards Ibn Tumart’s creed. These paragraphs, when added to his harsh criticism of the Almohads in his commentary on Plato’s Republic, may help us understand the evolution he underwent during his intellectual life. They may shed light in particular on the disgrace he suffered at the end of his career, when, for reasons that remain unclear, he fell out of favor with the Almohads and was exiled in Lucena, 60 km southeast of Cordova. According to one account, his death took place while he was confined to a residence in Marrakesh in 1198. (The definitive biography, in Arabic, is Ben Sharīfa 1999. For more on the historical context see Urvoy 1998 and Ben Ahmed 2020c.) 1.2 Works Ibn Rushd remained productive for at least four decades. He was the author of a large corpus that extends over medicine, logic and philosophy in all its branches, including natural philosophy, astronomy, metaphysics, psychology, politics, and ethics. His work also includes the sciences of Islamic religion: jurisprudence (fiqh), the foundations of Islamic law (usūl al-fiqh), the foundations of religion (usūl al-dīn), and the science of the Arabic language, including grammar. With important exceptions, most of his works are available in the original Arabic. For those works that have been lost, while readers await the day of their rediscovery, they must generally make do with medieval translations in Hebrew or Latin. Ibn Rushd’s work deploys various methods and styles. Many treatises are in the form of a commentary, most famously and extensively on Aristotle—covering nearly the whole Aristotelian corpus—but also on Galen’s medical treatises, as well as on other philosophers such as Plato, Ibn Sīnā and Ibn Bājja. Many other treatises, devoted to specific issues, are not in commentary form. (For a detailed inventory of texts and translations see §10.1.) The focus of his commentaries was Aristotle because no one has yet surpassed his achievement: “no one who has come after him to this our time—and this is close to 1500 years later—has been able to add a word worthy of attention to what he said” (LongPhys proem; Harvey 1985, 83). Scholarship going back to the nineteenth-century has divided the commentaries into three kinds: the epitome or short commentary (jawāmiʿ), which he favored at the start of his career; the paraphrase or middle commentary (talkhīṣ), seemingly composed throughout his career; the literal or long commentary (sharḥ or tafsīr), dating to his later years. Inasmuch as Ibn Rushd routinely wrote different kinds of commentaries on the same Aristotelian treatise, some such distinction seems necessary. But recent scholarship has doubted whether this neat threefold distinction adequately captures Ibn Rushd’s complexly varied approach (Al-ʿAlawī 1986a; Druart 1994; Gutas 1993). At a minimum, it omits important categories of work, such as compendia (mukhtaṣarat), treatises (maqālāt), and answers to questions (masāʾil), to say nothing of the important treatises that focus on religious questions. The most prominent of those independent religious treatises are The Decisive Treatise (Faṣl al-Maqāl), an argument for the value of philosophy to Islam; The Incoherence of the Incoherence (Tahāfut al-Tahāfut), a direct response to al-Ghazālī, whose work had achieved considerable influence at the time in Andalusia (Di Giovanni 2019); The Exposition of the Methods of Proof concerning Religious Doctrines (al-Kashf ʿan manāhij al-adilla fī ʿaqāʾid al-milla), a philosophically nuanced alternative to the teachings of Ashʿarite theology. These works, which seem to have had little influence on medieval Christian thought, have traditionally been seen as “theological” and contrasted with his supposedly “philosophical” works: the commentaries on Aristotle that circulated throughout medieval and Renaissance Europe in Latin and Hebrew translation. The latter were thought to be demonstrative, and aimed at the elites, whereas the former were said to be merely dialectical, and so aimed at a popular audience. Accordingly Ibn Rushd’s true position supposedly had to be sought in these Aristotelian commentaries. This distinction has affected the direction of scholarship, causing great attention to be given to the “philosophical” works, which were thought to represent most truly his thought, and leaving the “theological” treatises to be comparatively neglected. Even where the latter are widely taught, they are set apart from his supposedly more philosophical commentaries. The result, ever since the initial research of Renan (1852), has been a segmented and fragmentary view of the Rushdian corpus that marginalizes important aspects of his thought. An important correction to this tendency appears in Jamal Al-Dīn Al-ʿAlawī (1986a), who defends the unity and coherence of the Rushdian corpus. He proposes that Ibn Rushd’s works form a unity where there is no room to distinguish between what is a commentary on another text and what is an ostensibly original work. With this, Al-ʿAlawī attempted to close a gap in a body of work that should rightly be seen as continuous, and to reconnect texts that have been disassociated from their contexts. 2. Logic and Methodology The general character of Ibn Rushd’s philosophy is illuminated by his overarching picture of logic. Most broadly, he understands it as the study of the conditions and rules that rightly guide the mind toward the conception (taṣawwur) of essences and the assent (taṣdīq) to propositions (CompLogic 1.1). Glossing Aristotle’s famous remark that “it is the mark of the educated person” to seek the appropriate level of precision in any inquiry, Ibn Rushd clarifies that the educated person is “one who has been instructed in the art of logic” (ParaEthics I.3, 3C). In keeping with the weight he accords the subject, Ibn Rushd commented several times on each work in Aristotle’s logical Organon. Near the start of his career, he wrote a Compendium of Logic that includes Porphyry’s Isagoge and follows the usual Arabic practice of including the Rhetoric and Poetics as part of an expanded Organon (Black 1990). Later, he wrote a series of longer paraphrases of this same corpus (but treated the Isagoge separately, on the grounds that it is neither an introduction to nor even a part of logic). Toward the end of his life, he devoted one of his five long commentaries to the Posterior Analytics. In line with the approach of his predecessors, Ibn Rushd divided logical processes into five types of argument: demonstrative, dialectical, rhetorical, poetical, and fallacious. These inferences are not distinguished by their forms, which are the same, but by their matter, that is, by their premises. The premises of demonstrative arguments are necessary (Thom 2019), the premises of dialectical arguments are generally accepted, the premises of rhetoric are generally received, the premises of poetic arguments are imaginative, and the premises of sophistical arguments are deceiving. For Ibn Rushd, the center of logic and its very purpose is demonstration, for it is the only procedure that leads to certainty in philosophy: it is “the most perfect kind of reflection (naẓar), using the most perfect kind of inference (qiyās)” (Decisive Treatise 3). Accordingly, even in the context of Plato’s Republic, he begins his commentary by announcing that his goal is “to abstract such scientific arguments attributable to Plato as are contained in the Republic by removing from it its dialectical arguments.” However, this does not mean that non-demonstrative arguments are useless. Generally, where one kind of argument is not effective, other kinds of arguments should be used. Dialectic offers a path toward demonstration and to science, which, although it does not obtain certainty, is close to it. Rhetoric contributes, through its paradigms and enthymemes, to reinforcing and promoting demonstrative evidence. The study of sophistical reasoning is useful in assessing the faulty argumentative methods of the theologians (the mutakallimūn, that is, practitioners of kalām). In light of the high status of demonstration, Ibn Rushd considered it with great care in his commentaries. He devoted a compendium, a paraphrase and a long commentary to the Posterior Analytics—which he calls the Book of Demonstration (Kitāb al-Burhān)—and wrote separate treatises on various special issues. The long commentary is probably the most appropriate text for his positions on the components of demonstration, its types, and its role in producing scientific knowledge. That commentary is also the occasion for a critical and severe interaction with the two Islamic authorities in logic before him, al-Fārābī and Ibn Sīnā. The purpose of examining demonstrative arguments is to understand the absolute demonstration that gives complete certainty and constitutes a science (LongPostAn I.7 {180}). There are, however, other kinds of demonstration, less certain than the absolute one, but still demonstrative. In all, Ibn Rushd distinguishes three types (LongPostAn I.95 {348}): an absolute demonstration (burhān muṭlaq), which establishes the existence of a thing on the basis of a cause that is known prior to its effect; a demonstration of existence (burhān al-wujūd), which he calls a sign (dalīl), which establishes a thing’s existence without any grasp of its cause (see Elamrani-Jamal 2000); a demonstration of the cause (burhān al-ʿilla or burhān al-sabab), which establishes the cause once the effect’s existence is known. (Al-ʿAlawī 1986b) In mathematics, it is generally possible to frame absolute demonstrations, because the premises both supply the cause and are better known than their conclusions. In the natural sciences, however, and even in metaphysics, this ideal situation is generally not achievable. Here we begin with the accidental sensible features of things, and so extensive use must be made of the demonstration of existence (EpiPhys 1.105 {9}; Sylla 1979; Cerami 2014). Ibn Sīnā, whose views are often the target of Ibn Rushd’s logic, had denied that these count as a demonstration at all, on the grounds that they establish no substantial connection between the posterior cause and the prior effect. Ibn Rushd rejects this view (LongPostAn I.95 {349}), but admits that the demonstration of existence is less reliable than the other demonstrations. Certainty comes in degrees, and the differentiation in certainty between these demonstrations is one of the reasons why some sciences are superior to others (ParaPostAn §88–9). Ibn Rushd’s enthusiasm for demonstration does not prevent him from valuing other logical arts, and he was particularly concerned with the place of dialectic. Broadly speaking, according to Aristotle, dialectic has three main uses: as intellectual training, as a path into the demonstrative sciences of philosophy, and as a means of conversing with ordinary people (Topics I.2). But Ibn Rushd devotes less space and shows less interest in this third feature of dialectic, and one wonders whether this is due to his critical reaction to the discursive practices of the mutakallimūn. Despite the many considerations that make dialectic more suitable when dealing with ordinary people, Ibn Rushd suggests that rhetorical and poetic statements are preferable (ParaTop I.5C {31}; Ben Ahmed 2010-2011, 299–302, 307–17). Hence their inclusion in the expanded Organon. The significance of rhetoric and poetics is a result he establishes in political science, but maintains even when it comes to teaching and anchoring theological truths. The bad example set by the dialectical syllogisms of the mutakallimūn shows how dialectical methods, in discussion with ordinary people, are actually disadvantageous. Under the influence of al-Fārābī, Ibn Rushd puts emphasis on the need to introduce dialectic as a method (ṭarīq), a set of rules, techniques, and warnings (Ben Ahmed 2020a, 262–7). This conception of dialectic makes it distinct from both demonstration and sophistical reasoning, as well as from ordinary conversations. When used well, dialectic is a communal enterprise and so again different from other arts, such as demonstration, where there is no need for more than one party. A successful “partnership” in dialectic is one where each party does their best to commit themselves to the rules. From this perspective, it becomes evident that the questioner is not simply an adversary seeking to defeat his opponent, but rather a partner and a collaborator with the respondent in the search for knowledge. Any debate that is motivated by the pursuit of victory or by deriving pleasure from defeating one’s opponent is a debate that cannot fall under the method of dialectic. He writes, “the communal enterprise (al-ʿamal al-mushtarak) can be achieved in its utmost perfection only by both partners. They can have something in common when their aim is the assessment and the deduction of the truth, or the realization of their training. Thus, the respondent should perfect his response if he intends that aim, because the basest of the partners is the one who aims at the obstruction of the communal enterprise. But if their aim is to struggle against and defeat the other, then they will have nothing in common…. This is not the method of dialectic” (ParaTop 8.132D {233}; Ben Ahmed 2020a, 267) At the far reaches of the logical arts, the connection to the genuine syllogism becomes remote. So, even while Ibn Rushd recognizes that poetics is a syllogistic art, he says that it lacks the power of a real syllogism and is thus unproductive (CompLogic 12.3). In his paraphrase of the Poetics, he avoids using the term “poetic syllogism” altogether. In the realm of jurisprudence, Ibn Rushd is famous for his position on the logical and epistemological value of juridical inferences, which in his view produce nothing more than opinion (ẓann). Even when confronted with the surprising insertion of the word for jurisprudence (fiqh) into the Arabic translation of the Prior Analytics 68b10, Ibn Rushd chooses totally to ignore it.
