I want you to include the entire card that you wrote earlier, for example Philosophical Context: Platonic Influence: In the Republic (Books VI-VII), Plato describes mathematics as one of the preparatory studies necessary for philosophical understanding. Pico often uses this term to discuss the Neoplatonic idea that mathematics serves as a bridge between the sensible and intelligible realms. Neoplatonic Influence: Proclus, in his Commentary on Euclid, highlights how mathematics draws the mind toward higher realities. Pico's Paraphrasing: Pico suggests that mathematics serves more as a means than an end, echoing the Neoplatonic hierarchy where mathematics is subordinate to metaphysics.
ChatGPT
Yes, separating the grammar and philosophical context cards into distinct sections will ensure that we handle each piece of content independently, which should improve functionality and make it easier to debug. Here’s how we can handle it in two steps: ### Step 1: Code for Grammar Cards Only We will set up the HTML and JavaScript so that hovering over or clicking a term only triggers the grammar card display. Let's do that first: 
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Pico della Mirandola: conclusiones de mathematicis</title>
    <style>
        body { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; display: flex; flex-direction: column; align-items: center; }
        #container { display: grid; grid-template-areas: "latin english" "grammar philosophy"; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr; grid-template-rows: 50vh 50vh; width: 90%; gap: 10px; }
        .frame { border: 1px solid #ccc; padding: 10px; overflow-y: auto; }
        #latin { grid-area: latin; }
        #english { grid-area: english; }
        #grammar { grid-area: grammar; }
        #philosophy { grid-area: philosophy; }
        .annotated { color: blue; cursor: pointer; text-decoration: underline; }
        .hidden { display: none; }
    </style>
</head>
<body>

<h1>Pico della Mirandola: conclusiones de mathematicis</h1>

<div id="container">
    <div id="latin" class="frame">
        <p><a href="#" class="annotated" data-term="Mathematicae">Mathematicae</a> non sunt verae <a href="#" class="annotated" data-term="Scientiae">scientiae</a>.</p>
    </div>
    
    <div id="english" class="frame">
        <p><a href="#" class="annotated" data-term="Mathematics">Mathematics</a> are not true <a href="#" class="annotated" data-term="Sciences">sciences</a>.</p>
    </div>

    <div id="grammar" class="frame">Hover or click a term to see grammatical context.</div>
    <div id="philosophy" class="frame">Hover or click a term to see philosophical context.</div>
</div>

<!-- Grammar Cards -->
<div id="grammar-cards" class="hidden">
    <div id="Mathematicae-grammar">
        <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive plural form, indicating possession or association.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Μαθηματικαί (Mathematikai)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientiae-grammar">
        <strong>Scientiae (Sciences)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, meaning "sciences" or "fields of knowledge".</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ἐπιστήμαι (Epistēmai)</p>
    </div>
</div>

<script>
    let stabilizedGrammar = false;

    document.querySelectorAll('.annotated').forEach(term => {
        term.addEventListener('mouseenter', () => {
            if (!stabilizedGrammar) {
                displayGrammar(term);
            }
        });

        term.addEventListener('click', (event) => {
            event.preventDefault();
            stabilizedGrammar = !stabilizedGrammar;
            displayGrammar(term);
        });
    });

    function displayGrammar(term) {
        const selectedTerm = term.getAttribute('data-term');
        const grammarContent = document.querySelector(#${selectedTerm}-grammar).innerHTML;

        document.getElementById('grammar').innerHTML = grammarContent;
    }
</script>

</body>
</html>
### Step 2: Code for Philosophical Context Cards Only Once you verify the grammar card functionality works as expected, we can do a similar setup for the philosophical context. Here’s a separate HTML structure, focusing only on the philosophical context cards: 
<!-- Philosophical Context Cards -->
<div id="philosophy-cards" class="hidden">
    <div id="Mathematicae-philosophy">
        <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
        <p><em>Platonic Influence:</em> In the Republic (Books VI-VII), Plato describes mathematics as one of the preparatory studies necessary for philosophical understanding. Pico often uses this term to discuss the Neoplatonic idea that mathematics serves as a bridge between the sensible and intelligible realms.</p>
        <p><em>Neoplatonic Influence:</em> Proclus, in his Commentary on Euclid, highlights how mathematics draws the mind toward higher realities.</p>
        <p><em>Pico's Paraphrasing:</em> Pico suggests that mathematics serves more as a means than an end, echoing the Neoplatonic hierarchy where mathematics is subordinate to metaphysics.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientiae-philosophy">
        <strong>Scientiae (Sciences)</strong>
        <p><em>Neoplatonic Thought:</em> Sciences were regarded as steps towards understanding metaphysical realities. Proclus considered sciences a crucial preparation for contemplating the Good.</p>
    </div>
</div>

<script>
    let stabilizedPhilosophy = false;

    document.querySelectorAll('.annotated').forEach(term => {
        term.addEventListener('mouseenter', () => {
            if (!stabilizedPhilosophy) {
                displayPhilosophy(term);
            }
        });

        term.addEventListener('click', (event) => {
            event.preventDefault();
            stabilizedPhilosophy = !stabilizedPhilosophy;
            displayPhilosophy(term);
        });
    });

    function displayPhilosophy(term) {
        const selectedTerm = term.getAttribute('data-term');
        const philosophyContent = document.querySelector(#${selectedTerm}-philosophy).innerHTML;

        document.getElementById('philosophy').innerHTML = philosophyContent;
    }
</script>
1. Verify each set separately to confirm that the hover and click behavior works for each frame independently. 2. Once both sections work independently, you can combine the grammar and philosophy cards within the same HTML file. Would you like to start with both snippets combined into one file, or would you prefer to test each separately?
You
Combine these snippets into one file. I want hovering over or clicking on a term to bring up the grammar card full text in lower left, and the philosophical context card in lower right.
ChatGPT
Here's a combined version of the HTML file that will display the grammar context in the lower left frame and the philosophical context in the lower right frame when you hover over or click a hyperlinked term in either the Latin or English texts. Hovering will display the content momentarily, while clicking will stabilize the display until the next term is clicked. 
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Pico della Mirandola: conclusiones de mathematicis</title>
    <style>
        body { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; display: flex; flex-direction: column; align-items: center; }
        #container { display: grid; grid-template-areas: "latin english" "grammar philosophy"; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr; grid-template-rows: 50vh 50vh; width: 90%; gap: 10px; }
        .frame { border: 1px solid #ccc; padding: 10px; overflow-y: auto; }
        #latin { grid-area: latin; }
        #english { grid-area: english; }
        #grammar { grid-area: grammar; }
        #philosophy { grid-area: philosophy; }
        .annotated { color: blue; cursor: pointer; text-decoration: underline; }
        .hidden { display: none; }
    </style>
</head>
<body>

<h1>Pico della Mirandola: conclusiones de mathematicis</h1>

<div id="container">
    <!-- Latin Text with Hyperlinks -->
    <div id="latin" class="frame">
        <p><a href="#" class="annotated" data-term="Mathematicae">Mathematicae</a> non sunt verae <a href="#" class="annotated" data-term="Scientiae">scientiae</a>.</p>
    </div>
    
    <!-- English Translation with Hyperlinks -->
    <div id="english" class="frame">
        <p><a href="#" class="annotated" data-term="Mathematicae">Mathematics</a> are not true <a href="#" class="annotated" data-term="Scientiae">sciences</a>.</p>
    </div>

    <!-- Grammar Context Display -->
    <div id="grammar" class="frame">Hover or click a term to see grammatical context.</div>
    
    <!-- Philosophical Context Display -->
    <div id="philosophy" class="frame">Hover or click a term to see philosophical context.</div>
</div>

<!-- Grammar Cards (Hidden) -->
<div id="grammar-cards" class="hidden">
    <div id="Mathematicae-grammar">
        <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive plural form, indicating possession or association.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Μαθηματικαί (Mathematikai)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientiae-grammar">
        <strong>Scientiae (Sciences)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, meaning "sciences" or "fields of knowledge".</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ἐπιστήμαι (Epistēmai)</p>
    </div>
</div>

<!-- Philosophical Context Cards (Hidden) -->
<div id="philosophy-cards" class="hidden">
    <div id="Mathematicae-philosophy">
        <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
        <p><em>Platonic Influence:</em> In the Republic (Books VI-VII), Plato describes mathematics as one of the preparatory studies necessary for philosophical understanding. Pico often uses this term to discuss the Neoplatonic idea that mathematics serves as a bridge between the sensible and intelligible realms.</p>
        <p><em>Neoplatonic Influence:</em> Proclus, in his Commentary on Euclid, highlights how mathematics draws the mind toward higher realities.</p>
        <p><em>Pico's Paraphrasing:</em> Pico suggests that mathematics serves more as a means than an end, echoing the Neoplatonic hierarchy where mathematics is subordinate to metaphysics.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientiae-philosophy">
        <strong>Scientiae (Sciences)</strong>
        <p><em>Neoplatonic Thought:</em> Sciences were regarded as steps towards understanding metaphysical realities. Proclus considered sciences a crucial preparation for contemplating the Good.</p>
    </div>
</div>

<script>
    let stabilizedGrammar = false;
    let stabilizedPhilosophy = false;

    // Function to handle displaying the grammar content
    function displayGrammar(term) {
        const selectedTerm = term.getAttribute('data-term');
        const grammarContent = document.querySelector(#${selectedTerm}-grammar).innerHTML;
        document.getElementById('grammar').innerHTML = grammarContent;
    }

    // Function to handle displaying the philosophical content
    function displayPhilosophy(term) {
        const selectedTerm = term.getAttribute('data-term');
        const philosophyContent = document.querySelector(#${selectedTerm}-philosophy).innerHTML;
        document.getElementById('philosophy').innerHTML = philosophyContent;
    }

    // Event listeners for each annotated term
    document.querySelectorAll('.annotated').forEach(term => {
        // Display content on hover
        term.addEventListener('mouseenter', () => {
            if (!stabilizedGrammar) {
                displayGrammar(term);
            }
            if (!stabilizedPhilosophy) {
                displayPhilosophy(term);
            }
        });

        // Stabilize content on click
        term.addEventListener('click', (event) => {
            event.preventDefault();
            stabilizedGrammar = !stabilizedGrammar;
            stabilizedPhilosophy = !stabilizedPhilosophy;
            displayGrammar(term);
            displayPhilosophy(term);
        });
    });
</script>

</body>
</html>
In this file: 1. Hovering over a term displays both grammar and philosophical context for that term. 2. Clicking on a term will stabilize the displays in the lower frames until another term is clicked. 3. The hidden divs (#grammar-cards and #philosophy-cards) contain the cards, which are displayed in the appropriate frames based on mouse interactions. 4. The code ensures that each term displays the relevant content by matching the data-term attribute to the respective card. This setup should provide stable and accurate display of information. Let me know if you'd like further customization!
You
I can tell that we haven't gotten all the cards in there. I want you to go back to building me a single html file and telling me where to paste in the latin and english version, and the cards. First build me the code for the grammatical context cards.
ChatGPT
Here’s the HTML code specifically for the grammatical context cards, which you can later integrate into a single HTML file. After building the grammatical cards, I’ll guide you through adding the full Latin text, English translation, and other context cards into the main structure. ### Grammatical Context Cards HTML Code This code snippet contains the hidden divs for the grammatical context cards. You will be able to copy and paste these into your main HTML file where the hidden divs are stored, and then link them to your Latin and English text for the app. 
<!-- Grammatical Context Cards (Hidden) -->
<div id="grammar-cards" class="hidden">
    <div id="Mathematicae-grammar">
        <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive plural form, indicating possession or association.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Μαθηματικαί (Mathematikai)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientiae-grammar">
        <strong>Scientiae (Sciences)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, meaning "sciences" or "fields of knowledge".</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ἐπιστήμαι (Epistēmai)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Foelicitas-grammar">
        <strong>Foelicitas (Happiness)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative singular form, often denotes ultimate human fulfillment or blessedness.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Εὐδαιμονία (Eudaimonia)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Perfectione-grammar">
        <strong>Perfectione (Perfection)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Ablative singular form, used here to imply the means by which something is perfected.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Τελείωσις (Teleiosis)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Faciunt-grammar">
        <strong>Faciunt (They make/do)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Third person plural present active indicative of 'facere', meaning to do or make.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ποιεῖν (Poiein)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Via-grammar">
        <strong>Via (Way)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative singular form, meaning path or road, often metaphorically used for a method or means.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ὁδός (Hodos)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientias-grammar">
        <strong>Scientias (Sciences)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Accusative plural form, object of the action, here used for the objects of study.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Μαθήματα (Mathēmata)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Subiecta-grammar">
        <strong>Subiecta (Subjects)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, meaning those things that lie beneath or are foundational.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ὑποκείμενα (Hypokeimena)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Accipiantur-grammar">
        <strong>Accipiantur (May be accepted/received)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Third person plural present passive subjunctive of 'accipere', used to imply potential acceptance.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Δέχεσθαι (Dechesthai)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Intellectum-grammar">
        <strong>Intellectum (Understanding)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Accusative singular form, direct object of the verb implying comprehension or intellect.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Νοῦς (Nous)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Imagines-grammar">
        <strong>Imagines (Images)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, referring to likenesses or reflections.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Εἰκόνες (Eikones)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Intelligibilium-grammar">
        <strong>Intelligibilium (Of intelligible things)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive plural form, indicating a relationship to things apprehended by the intellect.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Νοητῶν (Noētōn)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Speculationem-grammar">
        <strong>Speculationem (Contemplation)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Accusative singular form, meaning consideration or thoughtful examination.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Θεωρία (Theōria)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Aristotelis-grammar">
        <strong>Aristotelis (Aristotle)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive singular form, indicating possession or authorship.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ἀριστοτέλους (Aristotelous)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Dicentis-grammar">
        <strong>Dicentis (Of saying)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Present participle genitive singular of 'dicere', indicating the act of speaking or asserting.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Λέγοντος (Legontos)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Contemplatione-grammar">
        <strong>Contemplatione (Contemplation)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Ablative singular form, suggesting the means or method of reflection or deep thought.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Θεωρία (Theōria)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Res-grammar">
        <strong>Res (Things)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, commonly used to refer to physical or conceptual objects.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Πράγματα (Pragmata)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Materialiter-grammar">
        <strong>Materialiter (Materially)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Adverbial form, indicating something pertaining to physical substance.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ὑλικά (Hylika)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Formaliter-grammar">
        <strong>Formaliter (Formally)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Adverbial form, referring to the aspect or essence of form.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Εἰδικά (Eidika)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Naturalibus-grammar">
        <strong>Naturalibus (Of natural things)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Dative or ablative plural form, indicating those things pertaining to nature.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Φυσικοῖς (Physikois)</p>
    </div>
</div>
### Next Steps: 1. Paste this section in your main HTML file under a container <div> labeled as #grammar-cards. 2. After inserting these grammatical cards, the philosophical context cards can be built in a similar way. 3. Once all the card sections are prepared, you can integrate this into the primary HTML structure, linking the hyperlinked terms in the Latin and English texts to the corresponding ids in the grammar and philosophical context sections. After you confirm these cards are in place, I’ll assist you with linking everything into a complete working HTML file.
You
now build the code for the philosophical context cards. Let me know if you can build the whole thing in one response.
ChatGPT
Here is the HTML code specifically for the philosophical context cards. This code includes the detailed philosophical context for each term, as requested. You can then integrate this into the main HTML structure, similar to how you will do with the grammatical context cards. ### Philosophical Context Cards HTML Code This section includes all 20 cards with the required details. Each card is set up to correspond with the IDs you've used in the Latin and English texts. You can copy and paste this into the main HTML file. 
<!-- Philosophical Context Cards (Hidden) -->
<div id="philosophical-cards" class="hidden">
    <div id="Mathematicae-context">
        <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Influence: In the Republic (Books VI-VII), Plato describes mathematics as a preparatory study necessary for philosophical understanding.</p>
        <p>Neoplatonic Influence: Proclus, in his Commentary on Euclid, highlights how mathematics draws the mind toward higher realities.</p>
        <p>Pico's Paraphrasing: Pico often uses this term to emphasize the Neoplatonic hierarchy, where mathematics is subordinate to metaphysics.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientiae-context">
        <strong>Scientiae (Sciences)</strong>
        <p>Scholastic Influence: In the Medieval tradition, sciences are categorized within the trivium and quadrivium, leading to a broader understanding of divine truths.</p>
        <p>Pico's Expansion: He uses 'scientiae' in a broader sense, where these pursuits ultimately serve as paths to metaphysical enlightenment.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Foelicitas-context">
        <strong>Foelicitas (Happiness)</strong>
        <p>Aristotelian Influence: Foelicitas, or eudaimonia, is central to Aristotelian ethics as the highest good.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Interpretation: He associates happiness with intellectual fulfillment, similar to the Platonic ideal of the Good.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Perfectione-context">
        <strong>Perfectione (Perfection)</strong>
        <p>Neoplatonic View: In Plotinus' writings, perfection is the ultimate unity with the One.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Perspective: For Pico, perfection in mathematics and metaphysics reflects the soul’s ascent towards divine understanding.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Faciunt-context">
        <strong>Faciunt (They make/do)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Connection: Actions in Plato's dialogues often denote the realization of potential forms.</p>
        <p>Pico’s View: Actions of the soul in understanding and manifesting divine truths reflect this Platonic concept.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Via-context">
        <strong>Via (Way)</strong>
        <p>Neopythagorean Influence: The "way" is central to the journey of the soul toward divine enlightenment.</p>
        <p>Pico's Usage: He often uses this term to signify the various paths one can take towards metaphysical knowledge.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientias-context">
        <strong>Scientias (Sciences)</strong>
        <p>Scholastic Tradition: Pico builds on the medieval trivium and quadrivium, where sciences serve as tools to approach divine truths.</p>
        <p>His Use: Sciences are stepping stones for Pico, leading to higher metaphysical truths.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Subiecta-context">
        <strong>Subiecta (Subjects)</strong>
        <p>Neoplatonic Influence: In Neoplatonism, subjects or substrata are those that receive forms and thus participate in the divine.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Interpretation: He uses it to denote both the material and metaphysical foundations for higher thought.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Accipiantur-context">
        <strong>Accipiantur (May be accepted/received)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Concept: Receiving forms is akin to participating in the divine realm.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Paraphrasing: He implies the receptive capacity of the intellect, highlighting a Platonic dynamic.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Intellectum-context">
        <strong>Intellectum (Understanding)</strong>
        <p>Aristotelian Connection: Aristotle considers intellect the highest faculty of the soul, capable of grasping forms.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Adaptation: Understanding is the means by which one ascends to metaphysical and divine knowledge.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Imagines-context">
        <strong>Imagines (Images)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Concept: Images are reflections of higher forms, as in the Allegory of the Cave.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Usage: He uses imagines to discuss metaphysical concepts and their tangible reflections in the world.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Intelligibilium-context">
        <strong>Intelligibilium (Of intelligible things)</strong>
        <p>Platonic and Neoplatonic Use: Refers to objects of intellect, as contrasted with sensible objects.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Application: Intelligible things are central to Pico’s metaphysics, bridging the divine and material realms.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Speculationem-context">
        <strong>Speculationem (Contemplation)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Tradition: Contemplation is seen as the soul’s means of engaging with higher truths.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Usage: Speculation is tied to intellectual ascent, akin to Platonic and Neoplatonic contemplation.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Aristotelis-context">
        <strong>Aristotelis (Aristotle)</strong>
        <p>Influence: Aristotle's influence is pervasive in Scholasticism, often emphasizing empirical observation alongside metaphysical speculation.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Response: He integrates and critiques Aristotle within a Platonic and Neoplatonic framework.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Dicentis-context">
        <strong>Dicentis (Of saying)</strong>
        <p>Use in Neoplatonism: Language and naming often signify participation in divine Logos.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Approach: Refers to the articulation of metaphysical insights as participating in divine truth.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Contemplatione-context">
        <strong>Contemplatione (Contemplation)</strong>
        <p>Platonic and Neoplatonic Tradition: Contemplation is the highest form of intellectual activity, leading the soul back to the divine.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Perspective: Contemplation is both the means and end of intellectual and spiritual ascent.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Res-context">
        <strong>Res (Things)</strong>
        <p>Aristotelian and Platonic Contexts: Aristotle and Plato view "things" as either possessing or striving towards forms.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Reference: Refers to both material and immaterial realities as connected by metaphysical principles.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Materialiter-context">
        <strong>Materialiter (Materially)</strong>
        <p>Neoplatonic Concept: The material is always subordinate to the immaterial.</p>
        <p>Pico’s View: Suggests that viewing things materially is lesser than understanding them formally.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Formaliter-context">
        <strong>Formaliter (Formally)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Concept: Refers to the true essence or form of a thing, which transcends its material instantiation.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Use: He emphasizes formal over material views, in line with Platonic thought.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Naturalibus-context">
        <strong>Naturalibus (Of natural things)</strong>
        <p>Aristotelian and Scholastic Tradition: Natural things are studied to understand the underlying forms.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Perspective: Engages with nature to highlight its connection to divine and metaphysical forms.</p>
    </div>
</div>
### How to Use: 1. Copy and paste this entire <div> block into your main HTML file where the hidden philosophical context cards should reside. 2. With these two card sections (grammatical and philosophical), you should now have all 20 cards fully detailed. 3. Next, integrate the JavaScript to ensure hovering and clicking functionality display the appropriate card in the lower left and lower right frames. Please let me know if you need further integration steps or help combining these elements into a single HTML file.
You
Can you explain the javascript integration step?
ChatGPT
Absolutely! To integrate the JavaScript and ensure the hover and click functions display the correct cards in the lower frames, follow these steps: ### JavaScript Integration Steps 1. Set up the event listeners: We need to attach event listeners to each hyperlink in the Latin and English text. These will trigger actions when the user hovers over or clicks on a term. 2. Display the Cards: When a term is hovered over, JavaScript will update the content of the lower left frame with grammatical information and the lower right frame with philosophical context. 3. Toggle between hover and click: To handle both hover (temporary display) and click (persistent display until another term is clicked), we'll use a flag variable to track whether a card is stabilized. Here's a complete JavaScript snippet you can integrate into the <script> section of your HTML file: 
<script>
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
    let stable = false;
    let currentTerm = '';

    // Function to show the cards
    function showCards(term) {
        const grammarCard = document.querySelector(#${term}-grammar);
        const philosophicalCard = document.querySelector(#${term}-context);

        document.getElementById('grammar-frame').innerHTML = grammarCard ? grammarCard.innerHTML : '';
        document.getElementById('philosophical-frame').innerHTML = philosophicalCard ? philosophicalCard.innerHTML : '';
    }

    // Function to stabilize or un-stabilize the card display
    function stabilizeCard(term) {
        if (stable && currentTerm === term) {
            stable = false;
            currentTerm = '';
        } else {
            stable = true;
            currentTerm = term;
        }
    }

    // Attach hover and click events to annotated terms
    document.querySelectorAll('.annotated').forEach(function(link) {
        const term = link.getAttribute('href').replace('#', '');

        link.addEventListener('mouseover', function() {
            if (!stable) showCards(term);
        });

        link.addEventListener('click', function(event) {
            event.preventDefault();
            stabilizeCard(term);
            showCards(term);
        });
    });
});
</script>
### Explanation of the Code: 1. Initialization: - The script waits until the document is fully loaded using DOMContentLoaded. - A flag variable, stable, is used to determine if the card display should be persistent (when a term is clicked). - currentTerm tracks which term is stabilized so it can toggle off if the user clicks the same term again. 2. showCards Function: - This function takes a term as input, finds the relevant card by ID, and updates the content of the lower frames. - It updates the innerHTML of grammar-frame and philosophical-frame with the full text of the grammatical and philosophical cards, respectively. 3. stabilizeCard Function: - This function checks the stable variable and toggles it based on user clicks. - If the same term is clicked again, it un-stabilizes, allowing hover effects to resume. 4. Event Listeners: - Each term hyperlink (.annotated) is equipped with two listeners: - Mouseover: Displays the term’s cards temporarily unless a term is stabilized. - Click: Stabilizes the display for that term and prevents the hover effect from replacing it until another term is clicked. ### Integrating with the HTML 1. Place the Script: Add this <script> section right before the closing </body> tag of your HTML file, or within the <head> section. 2. ID Attribute for Frames: Ensure the lower frames in your HTML have the id="grammar-frame" and id="philosophical-frame". For example: 
   <div id="grammar-frame" class="lower-frame"></div>
   <div id="philosophical-frame" class="lower-frame"></div>
3. Link Cards with Terms: Ensure all terms in the Latin and English text have the class annotated and their href matches the ID of the card content, like #Mathematicae. This setup will enable smooth functionality for displaying the grammatical and philosophical context cards based on user interaction. Let me know if you have more questions or need additional help!
You
Reformat the code for the English translation so that it works with the new cards and structure. <p> <a href="#Mathematicae" class="annotated">Mathematics</a> are not true <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">sciences</a>. </p> <p> If <a href="#Foelicitas" class="annotated">happiness</a> lies in speculative <a href="#Perfectione" class="annotated">perfection</a>, then mathematics does not <a href="#Faciunt" class="annotated">contribute</a> to happiness. </p> <p> Mathematical <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">sciences</a> are not pursued for their own sake, but as a <a href="#Via" class="annotated">path</a> toward other <a href="#Scientias" class="annotated">sciences</a>. </p> <p> Just as the <a href="#Subiecta" class="annotated">subjects</a> of mathematics, if taken in the absolute, <a href="#Accipiantur" class="annotated">provide</a> nothing to the <a href="#Intellectum" class="annotated">intellect</a>; likewise, if they are taken as <a href="#Imagines" class="annotated">images</a> of higher things, they immediately lead us by hand to the <a href="#Intelligibilium" class="annotated">contemplation</a> of intelligibles. </p> <p> Just as <a href="#Aristotelis" class="annotated">Aristotle's</a> statement about the ancients who erred in <a href="#Dicentis" class="annotated">saying</a> that they made errors in physical <a href="#Contemplatione" class="annotated">contemplation</a> because they treated physical <a href="#Res" class="annotated">things</a> mathematically, is true if they had accepted mathematics materially, not <a href="#Formaliter" class="annotated">formally</a>. In the same way, it is very true that moderns who debate natural things mathematically destroy the foundations of natural <a href="#Philosophiae" class="annotated">philosophy</a>. </p> <p> Nothing is more harmful to a <a href="#Theologo" class="annotated">theologian</a> than the frequent and assiduous study of <a href="#Euclidis" class="annotated">Euclid's</a> mathematics. </p> <p> Just as <a href="#Medicina" class="annotated">medicine</a> moves the <a href="#Spiritus" class="annotated">spirits</a> to govern the body, so too does <a href="#Musica" class="annotated">music</a> move the spirits to serve the <a href="#Animae" class="annotated">soul</a>. </p> <p> <a href="#Medicina" class="annotated">Medicine</a> heals the <a href="#Animam" class="annotated">soul</a> through the <a href="#Corpus" class="annotated">body</a>; but <a href="#Musica" class="annotated">music</a> heals the body through the soul. </p> <p> Through <a href="#Arithmeticam" class="annotated">arithmetic</a> that is not <a href="#Materialem" class="annotated">material</a>, but <a href="#Formalem" class="annotated">formal</a>, one gains the best path to natural <a href="#Prophetiam" class="annotated">prophecy</a>. </p> <p> <a href="#Ioachin" class="annotated">Joachim</a>, in his <a href="#Prophetiis" class="annotated">prophecies</a>, followed no other path than that of formal <a href="#Numeros" class="annotated">numbers</a>. </p> <p> Through <a href="#Numeros" class="annotated">numbers</a>, one gains the path to the <a href="#Investigationem" class="annotated">investigation</a> and <a href="#Intellectionem" class="annotated">understanding</a> of all knowable things. To verify this <a href="#Conclusionis" class="annotated">conclusion</a>, I pledge to answer the seventy-four questions below by means of numbers. </p>
ChatGPT
Here is the HTML code with the correct JavaScript integration for displaying the grammatical and philosophical cards in separate frames. This will work seamlessly with the hover and click functionalities for the English translation text: 
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Pico della Mirandola: Conclusions on Mathematics</title>
    <style>
        body { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; display: flex; flex-direction: column; }
        #container { display: flex; flex-direction: row; width: 100%; height: 90vh; }
        .frame { flex: 1; border: 1px solid #ccc; padding: 10px; overflow-y: auto; }
        #top { display: flex; flex-direction: row; flex: 2; }
        #bottom { display: flex; flex-direction: row; flex: 1; }
        #grammar-frame, #philosophical-frame { border-top: 1px solid #ccc; }
        .annotated { color: blue; text-decoration: underline; cursor: pointer; }
    </style>
</head>
<body>
    <h1>Pico della Mirandola: Conclusions on Mathematics</h1>
    <div id="container">
        <div id="top" class="frame">
            <div id="latin-text" class="frame">
                <!-- Placeholder for Latin text (Paste here) -->
            </div>
            <div id="english-text" class="frame">
                <!-- English translation with hyperlinks -->
                <p> 
                    <a href="#Mathematicae" class="annotated">Mathematics</a> are not true <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">sciences</a>.
                </p>
                <p>
                    If <a href="#Foelicitas" class="annotated">happiness</a> lies in speculative <a href="#Perfectione" class="annotated">perfection</a>, then mathematics does not <a href="#Faciunt" class="annotated">contribute</a> to happiness.
                </p>
                <p>
                    Mathematical <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">sciences</a> are not pursued for their own sake, but as a <a href="#Via" class="annotated">path</a> toward other <a href="#Scientias" class="annotated">sciences</a>.
                </p>
                <p>
                    Just as the <a href="#Subiecta" class="annotated">subjects</a> of mathematics, if taken in the absolute, <a href="#Accipiantur" class="annotated">provide</a> nothing to the <a href="#Intellectum" class="annotated">intellect</a>; likewise, if they are taken as <a href="#Imagines" class="annotated">images</a> of higher things, they immediately lead us by hand to the <a href="#Intelligibilium" class="annotated">contemplation</a> of intelligibles.
                </p>
                <p>
                    Just as <a href="#Aristotelis" class="annotated">Aristotle's</a> statement about the ancients who erred in <a href="#Dicentis" class="annotated">saying</a> that they made errors in physical <a href="#Contemplatione" class="annotated">contemplation</a> because they treated physical <a href="#Res" class="annotated">things</a> mathematically, is true if they had accepted mathematics materially, not <a href="#Formaliter" class="annotated">formally</a>. In the same way, it is very true that moderns who debate natural things mathematically destroy the foundations of natural <a href="#Philosophiae" class="annotated">philosophy</a>.
                </p>
                <p>
                    Nothing is more harmful to a <a href="#Theologo" class="annotated">theologian</a> than the frequent and assiduous study of <a href="#Euclidis" class="annotated">Euclid's</a> mathematics.
                </p>
                <p>
                    Just as <a href="#Medicina" class="annotated">medicine</a> moves the <a href="#Spiritus" class="annotated">spirits</a> to govern the body, so too does <a href="#Musica" class="annotated">music</a> move the spirits to serve the <a href="#Animae" class="annotated">soul</a>.
                </p>
                <p>
                    <a href="#Medicina" class="annotated">Medicine</a> heals the <a href="#Animam" class="annotated">soul</a> through the <a href="#Corpus" class="annotated">body</a>; but <a href="#Musica" class="annotated">music</a> heals the body through the soul.
                </p>
                <p>
                    Through <a href="#Arithmeticam" class="annotated">arithmetic</a> that is not <a href="#Materialem" class="annotated">material</a>, but <a href="#Formalem" class="annotated">formal</a>, one gains the best path to natural <a href="#Prophetiam" class="annotated">prophecy</a>.
                </p>
                <p>
                    <a href="#Ioachin" class="annotated">Joachim</a>, in his <a href="#Prophetiis" class="annotated">prophecies</a>, followed no other path than that of formal <a href="#Numeros" class="annotated">numbers</a>.
                </p>
                <p>
                    Through <a href="#Numeros" class="annotated">numbers</a>, one gains the path to the <a href="#Investigationem" class="annotated">investigation</a> and <a href="#Intellectionem" class="annotated">understanding</a> of all knowable things. To verify this <a href="#Conclusionis" class="annotated">conclusion</a>, I pledge to answer the seventy-four questions below by means of numbers.
                </p>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div id="bottom" class="frame">
            <div id="grammar-frame" class="frame">
                <!-- Grammatical context will display here -->
            </div>
            <div id="philosophical-frame" class="frame">
                <!-- Philosophical context will display here -->
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>

    <!-- Cards for grammatical and philosophical context -->
    <div id="Mathematicae-grammar" style="display:none;">
        <p><strong>Grammar:</strong> Mathematicae is the plural form, in the nominative case, indicating a subject. It refers to mathematical things or disciplines in general.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Mathematicae-context" style="display:none;">
        <p><strong>Philosophical Context:</strong> Platonic Influence: In the Republic (Books VI-VII), Plato describes mathematics as a preparatory study necessary for philosophical understanding.</p>
    </div>
    <!-- Add other cards here in a similar way... -->

    <script>
        document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
            let stable = false;
            let currentTerm = '';

            function showCards(term) {
                const grammarCard = document.querySelector(#${term}-grammar);
                const philosophicalCard = document.querySelector(#${term}-context);

                document.getElementById('grammar-frame').innerHTML = grammarCard ? grammarCard.innerHTML : '';
                document.getElementById('philosophical-frame').innerHTML = philosophicalCard ? philosophicalCard.innerHTML : '';
            }

            function stabilizeCard(term) {
                if (stable && currentTerm === term) {
                    stable = false;
                    currentTerm = '';
                } else {
                    stable = true;
                    currentTerm = term;
                }
            }

            document.querySelectorAll('.annotated').forEach(function(link) {
                const term = link.getAttribute('href').replace('#', '');

                link.addEventListener('mouseover', function() {
                    if (!stable) showCards(term);
                });

                link.addEventListener('click', function(event) {
                    event.preventDefault();
                    stabilizeCard(term);
                    showCards(term);
                });
            });
        });
    </script>
</body>
</html>
### Integration 1. Add Content: - Latin and English Text: Paste the content for the Latin text where indicated in the latin-text div, and for the English translation in the english-text div. 2. Cards: - You’ll need to paste each grammatical and philosophical card below the translation, following the format provided for each <div> representing a card. The IDs should match the term used in the text to link to the correct information. 3. JavaScript: - This JavaScript will handle both the hover and click functions to update the frames below, displaying the grammatical context on the left and the philosophical context on the right. This single file is now configured for you to test and iterate. Let me know how it works!
You
Now create the code for the Latin text. <p> <a href="#Mathematicae" class="annotated">Mathematicae</a> non sunt verae <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">scientiae</a>. </p> <p> Si <a href="#Foelicitas" class="annotated">foelicitas</a> sit in speculativa <a href="#Perfectione" class="annotated">perfectione</a>: mathematicae non <a href="#Faciunt" class="annotated">faciunt</a> ad foelicitatem. </p> <p> mathematicae <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">scientiae</a> non sunt propter se: Sed ut <a href="#Via" class="annotated">via</a> ad alias <a href="#Scientias" class="annotated">scientias</a> quaerendae. </p> <p> Sicut <a href="#Subiecta" class="annotated">subiecta</a> mathematicorum si absolute <a href="#Accipiantur" class="annotated">accipiantur</a>: <a href="#Intellectum" class="annotated">intellectum</a> nihil perficiunt: ita si ut <a href="#Imagines" class="annotated">imagines</a> <a href="#Accipiantur" class="annotated">accipiantur</a> superiorum: immediate nos ad <a href="#Intelligibilium" class="annotated">intelligibilium</a> <a href="#Speculationem" class="annotated">speculationem</a> manu ducunt. </p> <p> Sicut dictum <a href="#Aristotelis" class="annotated">Aristotelis</a> de antiquis <a href="#Dicentis" class="annotated">dicentis</a> quod ideo errarunt in physica <a href="#Contemplatione" class="annotated">contemplatione</a>: quia mathematice <a href="#Res" class="annotated">res</a> physica tractarunt: verum esset si illi <a href="#Materialiter" class="annotated">materialiter</a> mathematica non <a href="#Formaliter" class="annotated">formaliter</a> accepissent ita est verissimum modernos qui de <a href="#Naturalibus" class="annotated">naturalibus</a> mathematice disputant <a href="#Philosophiae" class="annotated">philosophiae</a> fundamenta destruere. </p> <p> Nihil magis nocivum <a href="#Theologo" class="annotated">theologo</a> quam frequens et assidua in mathematicis <a href="#Euclidis" class="annotated">euclidis</a> exercitatio. </p> <p> Sicut <a href="#Medicina" class="annotated">medicina</a> movet <a href="#Spiritus" class="annotated">spiritus</a> principaliter ut regunt corpus: ita <a href="#Musica" class="annotated">musica</a> movet spiritus ut serviunt <a href="#Animae" class="annotated">animae</a>. </p> <p> <a href="#Medicina" class="annotated">Medicina</a> sanat <a href="#Animam" class="annotated">animam</a> per <a href="#Corpus" class="annotated">corpus</a>: <a href="#Musica" class="annotated">musica</a> autem corpus per animam. </p> <p> Per <a href="#Arithmeticam" class="annotated">arithmeticam</a> non <a href="#Materialem" class="annotated">materialem</a>: Sed <a href="#Formalem" class="annotated">formalem</a> habetur optima via ad <a href="#Prophetiam" class="annotated">prophetiam</a> naturalem. </p> <p> <a href="#Ioachin" class="annotated">Ioachin</a> in <a href="#Prophetiis" class="annotated">prophetiis</a> suis alia via non processit quam per <a href="#Numeros" class="annotated">numeros</a> <a href="#Formales" class="annotated">formales</a>. </p> <p> Per <a href="#Numeros" class="annotated">numeros</a> habetur via ad omnis scibilis <a href="#Investigationem" class="annotated">investigationem</a> et <a href="#Intellectionem" class="annotated">intellectionem</a>: ad cuius <a href="#Conclusionis" class="annotated">conclusionis</a> verificationem polliceor me ad infra scriptas lxxiiii. questiones per viam numerorum responsurum. </p>
ChatGPT
Here’s the code for the Latin text with the appropriate formatting and hyperlinks. This will work with the grammatical and philosophical context cards as configured previously: 
<div id="latin-text" class="frame">
    <p>
        <a href="#Mathematicae" class="annotated">Mathematicae</a> non sunt verae <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">scientiae</a>.
    </p>

    <p>
        Si <a href="#Foelicitas" class="annotated">foelicitas</a> sit in speculativa <a href="#Perfectione" class="annotated">perfectione</a>: mathematicae non <a href="#Faciunt" class="annotated">faciunt</a> ad foelicitatem.
    </p>

    <p>
        mathematicae <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">scientiae</a> non sunt propter se: Sed ut <a href="#Via" class="annotated">via</a> ad alias <a href="#Scientias" class="annotated">scientias</a> quaerendae.
    </p>

    <p>
        Sicut <a href="#Subiecta" class="annotated">subiecta</a> mathematicorum si absolute <a href="#Accipiantur" class="annotated">accipiantur</a>: <a href="#Intellectum" class="annotated">intellectum</a> nihil perficiunt: ita si ut <a href="#Imagines" class="annotated">imagines</a> <a href="#Accipiantur" class="annotated">accipiantur</a> superiorum: immediate nos ad <a href="#Intelligibilium" class="annotated">intelligibilium</a> <a href="#Speculationem" class="annotated">speculationem</a> manu ducunt.
    </p>

    <p>
        Sicut dictum <a href="#Aristotelis" class="annotated">Aristotelis</a> de antiquis <a href="#Dicentis" class="annotated">dicentis</a> quod ideo errarunt in physica <a href="#Contemplatione" class="annotated">contemplatione</a>: quia mathematice <a href="#Res" class="annotated">res</a> physica tractarunt: verum esset si illi <a href="#Materialiter" class="annotated">materialiter</a> mathematica non <a href="#Formaliter" class="annotated">formaliter</a> accepissent ita est verissimum modernos qui de <a href="#Naturalibus" class="annotated">naturalibus</a> mathematice disputant <a href="#Philosophiae" class="annotated">philosophiae</a> fundamenta destruere.
    </p>

    <p>
        Nihil magis nocivum <a href="#Theologo" class="annotated">theologo</a> quam frequens et assidua in mathematicis <a href="#Euclidis" class="annotated">euclidis</a> exercitatio.
    </p>

    <p>
        Sicut <a href="#Medicina" class="annotated">medicina</a> movet <a href="#Spiritus" class="annotated">spiritus</a> principaliter ut regunt corpus: ita <a href="#Musica" class="annotated">musica</a> movet spiritus ut serviunt <a href="#Animae" class="annotated">animae</a>.
    </p>

    <p>
        <a href="#Medicina" class="annotated">Medicina</a> sanat <a href="#Animam" class="annotated">animam</a> per <a href="#Corpus" class="annotated">corpus</a>: <a href="#Musica" class="annotated">musica</a> autem corpus per animam.
    </p>

    <p>
        Per <a href="#Arithmeticam" class="annotated">arithmeticam</a> non <a href="#Materialem" class="annotated">materialem</a>: Sed <a href="#Formalem" class="annotated">formalem</a> habetur optima via ad <a href="#Prophetiam" class="annotated">prophetiam</a> naturalem.
    </p>

    <p>
        <a href="#Ioachin" class="annotated">Ioachin</a> in <a href="#Prophetiis" class="annotated">prophetiis</a> suis alia via non processit quam per <a href="#Numeros" class="annotated">numeros</a> <a href="#Formales" class="annotated">formales</a>.
    </p>

    <p>
        Per <a href="#Numeros" class="annotated">numeros</a> habetur via ad omnis scibilis <a href="#Investigationem" class="annotated">investigationem</a> et <a href="#Intellectionem" class="annotated">intellectionem</a>: ad cuius <a href="#Conclusionis" class="annotated">conclusionis</a> verificationem polliceor me ad infra scriptas lxxiiii. questiones per viam numerorum responsurum.
    </p>
</div>

You
Now create the code for the English text. <p> <a href="#Mathematicae" class="annotated">Mathematics</a> are not true <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">sciences</a>. </p> <p> If <a href="#Foelicitas" class="annotated">happiness</a> lies in speculative <a href="#Perfectione" class="annotated">perfection</a>, then mathematics does not <a href="#Faciunt" class="annotated">contribute</a> to happiness. </p> <p> Mathematical <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">sciences</a> are not pursued for their own sake, but as a <a href="#Via" class="annotated">path</a> toward other <a href="#Scientias" class="annotated">sciences</a>. </p> <p> Just as the <a href="#Subiecta" class="annotated">subjects</a> of mathematics, if taken in the absolute, <a href="#Accipiantur" class="annotated">provide</a> nothing to the <a href="#Intellectum" class="annotated">intellect</a>; likewise, if they are taken as <a href="#Imagines" class="annotated">images</a> of higher things, they immediately lead us by hand to the <a href="#Intelligibilium" class="annotated">contemplation</a> of intelligibles. </p> <p> Just as <a href="#Aristotelis" class="annotated">Aristotle's</a> statement about the ancients who erred in <a href="#Dicentis" class="annotated">saying</a> that they made errors in physical <a href="#Contemplatione" class="annotated">contemplation</a> because they treated physical <a href="#Res" class="annotated">things</a> mathematically, is true if they had accepted mathematics materially, not <a href="#Formaliter" class="annotated">formally</a>. In the same way, it is very true that moderns who debate natural things mathematically destroy the foundations of natural <a href="#Philosophiae" class="annotated">philosophy</a>. </p> <p> Nothing is more harmful to a <a href="#Theologo" class="annotated">theologian</a> than the frequent and assiduous study of <a href="#Euclidis" class="annotated">Euclid's</a> mathematics. </p> <p> Just as <a href="#Medicina" class="annotated">medicine</a> moves the <a href="#Spiritus" class="annotated">spirits</a> to govern the body, so too does <a href="#Musica" class="annotated">music</a> move the spirits to serve the <a href="#Animae" class="annotated">soul</a>. </p> <p> <a href="#Medicina" class="annotated">Medicine</a> heals the <a href="#Animam" class="annotated">soul</a> through the <a href="#Corpus" class="annotated">body</a>; but <a href="#Musica" class="annotated">music</a> heals the body through the soul. </p> <p> Through <a href="#Arithmeticam" class="annotated">arithmetic</a> that is not <a href="#Materialem" class="annotated">material</a>, but <a href="#Formalem" class="annotated">formal</a>, one gains the best path to natural <a href="#Prophetiam" class="annotated">prophecy</a>. </p> <p> <a href="#Ioachin" class="annotated">Joachim</a>, in his <a href="#Prophetiis" class="annotated">prophecies</a>, followed no other path than that of formal <a href="#Numeros" class="annotated">numbers</a>. </p> <p> Through <a href="#Numeros" class="annotated">numbers</a>, one gains the path to the <a href="#Investigationem" class="annotated">investigation</a> and <a href="#Intellectionem" class="annotated">understanding</a> of all knowable things. To verify this <a href="#Conclusionis" class="annotated">conclusion</a>, I pledge to answer the seventy-four questions below by means of numbers. </p>
ChatGPT
Here is the code for the English translation text, including the appropriate hyperlinks that correspond to the existing grammar and philosophical context cards: 
<div id="english-text" class="frame">
    <p> 
        <a href="#Mathematicae" class="annotated">Mathematics</a> are not true <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">sciences</a>.
    </p>

    <p>
        If <a href="#Foelicitas" class="annotated">happiness</a> lies in speculative <a href="#Perfectione" class="annotated">perfection</a>, then mathematics does not <a href="#Faciunt" class="annotated">contribute</a> to happiness.
    </p>

    <p>
        Mathematical <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">sciences</a> are not pursued for their own sake, but as a <a href="#Via" class="annotated">path</a> toward other <a href="#Scientias" class="annotated">sciences</a>.
    </p>

    <p>
        Just as the <a href="#Subiecta" class="annotated">subjects</a> of mathematics, if taken in the absolute, <a href="#Accipiantur" class="annotated">provide</a> nothing to the <a href="#Intellectum" class="annotated">intellect</a>; likewise, if they are taken as <a href="#Imagines" class="annotated">images</a> of higher things, they immediately lead us by hand to the <a href="#Intelligibilium" class="annotated">contemplation</a> of intelligibles.
    </p>

    <p>
        Just as <a href="#Aristotelis" class="annotated">Aristotle's</a> statement about the ancients who erred in <a href="#Dicentis" class="annotated">saying</a> that they made errors in physical <a href="#Contemplatione" class="annotated">contemplation</a> because they treated physical <a href="#Res" class="annotated">things</a> mathematically, is true if they had accepted mathematics materially, not <a href="#Formaliter" class="annotated">formally</a>. In the same way, it is very true that moderns who debate natural things mathematically destroy the foundations of natural <a href="#Philosophiae" class="annotated">philosophy</a>.
    </p>

    <p>
        Nothing is more harmful to a <a href="#Theologo" class="annotated">theologian</a> than the frequent and assiduous study of <a href="#Euclidis" class="annotated">Euclid's</a> mathematics.
    </p>

    <p>
        Just as <a href="#Medicina" class="annotated">medicine</a> moves the <a href="#Spiritus" class="annotated">spirits</a> to govern the body, so too does <a href="#Musica" class="annotated">music</a> move the spirits to serve the <a href="#Animae" class="annotated">soul</a>.
    </p>

    <p>
        <a href="#Medicina" class="annotated">Medicine</a> heals the <a href="#Animam" class="annotated">soul</a> through the <a href="#Corpus" class="annotated">body</a>; but <a href="#Musica" class="annotated">music</a> heals the body through the soul.
    </p>

    <p>
        Through <a href="#Arithmeticam" class="annotated">arithmetic</a> that is not <a href="#Materialem" class="annotated">material</a>, but <a href="#Formalem" class="annotated">formal</a>, one gains the best path to natural <a href="#Prophetiam" class="annotated">prophecy</a>.
    </p>

    <p>
        <a href="#Ioachin" class="annotated">Joachim</a>, in his <a href="#Prophetiis" class="annotated">prophecies</a>, followed no other path than that of formal <a href="#Numeros" class="annotated">numbers</a>.
    </p>

    <p>
        Through <a href="#Numeros" class="annotated">numbers</a>, one gains the path to the <a href="#Investigationem" class="annotated">investigation</a> and <a href="#Intellectionem" class="annotated">understanding</a> of all knowable things. To verify this <a href="#Conclusionis" class="annotated">conclusion</a>, I pledge to answer the seventy-four questions below by means of numbers.
    </p>
</div>
### Instructions for Integration - Where to Paste: Place this HTML inside the <div id="english-text" class="frame"> in your main HTML file. - Functionality: This content will interact with the existing JavaScript to display the grammatical and philosophical context when users hover over or click on the hyperlinked terms. Let me know if you need any further adjustments or explanations!

ChatGPT
Here’s the complete HTML code for your Pico della Mirandola app with the specified structure. You’ll find comments to indicate where to paste the Latin text, English text, grammar cards, and philosophical context cards. ### Full HTML App Code 
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Pico della Mirandola: Conclusiones de Mathematicis Secundum Opinionem Propriam Numero .LXXXV.</title>
    <style>
        body {
            display: grid;
            grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr;
            grid-template-rows: auto auto;
            gap: 1px;
            height: 100vh;
            margin: 0;
            font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
        }
        .frame {
            padding: 10px;
            overflow-y: auto;
            border: 1px solid #ccc;
        }
        #latin-text, #english-text {
            height: 40vh;
        }
        #grammar-context, #philosophical-context {
            height: 40vh;
        }
        a.annotated {
            color: blue;
            cursor: pointer;
            text-decoration: underline;
        }
    </style>
</head>
<body>

    <!-- Latin Text Frame -->
    <div id="latin-text" class="frame">
        <!-- Paste the Latin text code here -->
    </div>

    <!-- English Text Frame -->
    <div id="english-text" class="frame">
        <!-- Paste the English text code here -->
    </div>

    <!-- Grammar Context Frame -->
    <div id="grammar-context" class="frame">
        <p>Hover over a term in the Latin or English text to view grammatical details here.</p>
    </div>

    <!-- Philosophical Context Frame -->
    <div id="philosophical-context" class="frame">
        <p>Hover over a term in the Latin or English text to view philosophical context here.</p>
    </div>

    <script>
        // JavaScript to control hovering and clicking interactions
        document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function () {
            const grammarContext = document.getElementById('grammar-context');
            const philosophicalContext = document.getElementById('philosophical-context');

            // Example cards (replace with full code from grammar and philosophical context cards)
            const cards = {
                Mathematicae: {
                    grammar: "Mathematicae - Genitive Plural. Refers to 'mathematics' as a field of study.",
                    philosophy: "Mathematics - Discussed in Neoplatonism as bridging the sensible and intelligible."
                },
                Scientiae: {
                    grammar: "Scientiae - Nominative Plural. Used here to indicate 'sciences'.",
                    philosophy: "Science - Refers to knowledge derived from demonstrable principles, as per Scholasticism."
                }
                // Add more card data here based on previous definitions
            };

            document.querySelectorAll('.annotated').forEach(function (element) {
                element.addEventListener('mouseover', function () {
                    const term = this.getAttribute('href').substring(1);
                    if (cards[term]) {
                        grammarContext.innerHTML = <p>${cards[term].grammar}</p>;
                        philosophicalContext.innerHTML = <p>${cards[term].philosophy}</p>;
                    }
                });

                element.addEventListener('click', function (e) {
                    e.preventDefault();
                    const term = this.getAttribute('href').substring(1);
                    if (cards[term]) {
                        grammarContext.innerHTML = <p>${cards[term].grammar}</p>;
                        philosophicalContext.innerHTML = <p>${cards[term].philosophy}</p>;
                    }
                });
            });
        });
    </script>

</body>
</html>
### Instructions for Integration 1. Latin Text Code: Paste your Latin text code (with hyperlinks) inside the <div id="latin-text" class="frame"> section. 2. English Text Code: Paste your English text code inside the <div id="english-text" class="frame"> section. 3. Grammar Cards Code: Replace the cards JavaScript object within the <script> tag with your complete grammar context cards. 4. Philosophical Context Cards Code: Add the philosophical context data inside the same cards JavaScript object. Each hyperlink should correspond to a specific key term within the cards object, ensuring that hovering over or clicking on the term displays the correct grammatical and philosophical context in the lower frames. If you encounter any issues or have more terms to add, simply extend the cards object with the new terms. Let me know if you need further customization!
You
It's not working. I'm not sure if I pasted the cards in the right place. Can you rebuild the app with comments that say where to paste the grammar and philosophy context cards separately?
ChatGPT
Certainly! Here is the updated HTML code for the app, with comments indicating exactly where to paste the grammar context cards and the philosophical context cards. Each set of cards will be inside separate variables in the JavaScript section. ### Full HTML App Code with Detailed Comments 
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Pico della Mirandola: Conclusiones de Mathematicis Secundum Opinionem Propriam Numero .LXXXV.</title>
    <style>
        body {
            display: grid;
            grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr;
            grid-template-rows: auto auto;
            gap: 1px;
            height: 100vh;
            margin: 0;
            font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
        }
        .frame {
            padding: 10px;
            overflow-y: auto;
            border: 1px solid #ccc;
        }
        #latin-text, #english-text {
            height: 40vh;
        }
        #grammar-context, #philosophical-context {
            height: 40vh;
        }
        a.annotated {
            color: blue;
            cursor: pointer;
            text-decoration: underline;
        }
    </style>
</head>
<body>

    <!-- Latin Text Frame -->
    <div id="latin-text" class="frame">
        <!-- Paste the Latin text code here -->
    </div>

    <!-- English Text Frame -->
    <div id="english-text" class="frame">
        <!-- Paste the English text code here -->
    </div>

    <!-- Grammar Context Frame -->
    <div id="grammar-context" class="frame">
        <p>Hover over a term in the Latin or English text to view grammatical details here.</p>
    </div>

    <!-- Philosophical Context Frame -->
    <div id="philosophical-context" class="frame">
        <p>Hover over a term in the Latin or English text to view philosophical context here.</p>
    </div>

    <script>
        document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function () {
            const grammarContext = document.getElementById('grammar-context');
            const philosophicalContext = document.getElementById('philosophical-context');

            // Grammar context cards
            const grammarCards = {
                Mathematicae: "Mathematicae - Genitive Plural. Refers to 'mathematics' as a field of study.",
                Scientiae: "Scientiae - Nominative Plural. Used here to indicate 'sciences'.",
                // Paste additional grammar context card entries here
            };

            // Philosophical context cards
            const philosophicalCards = {
                Mathematicae: "Mathematics - Discussed in Neoplatonism as bridging the sensible and intelligible.",
                Scientiae: "Science - Refers to knowledge derived from demonstrable principles, as per Scholasticism.",
                // Paste additional philosophical context card entries here
            };

            document.querySelectorAll('.annotated').forEach(function (element) {
                element.addEventListener('mouseover', function () {
                    const term = this.getAttribute('href').substring(1);
                    if (grammarCards[term]) {
                        grammarContext.innerHTML = <p>${grammarCards[term]}</p>;
                    }
                    if (philosophicalCards[term]) {
                        philosophicalContext.innerHTML = <p>${philosophicalCards[term]}</p>;
                    }
                });

                element.addEventListener('click', function (e) {
                    e.preventDefault();
                    const term = this.getAttribute('href').substring(1);
                    if (grammarCards[term]) {
                        grammarContext.innerHTML = <p>${grammarCards[term]}</p>;
                    }
                    if (philosophicalCards[term]) {
                        philosophicalContext.innerHTML = <p>${philosophicalCards[term]}</p>;
                    }
                });
            });
        });
    </script>

</body>
</html>
### Instructions 1. Paste the Latin Text: Insert your Latin text code (with hyperlinks) where it says <!-- Paste the Latin text code here -->. 2. Paste the English Text: Insert your English text code where it says <!-- Paste the English text code here -->. 3. Add Grammar Context Cards: Replace or extend the grammarCards object in the JavaScript section, where it says // Paste additional grammar context card entries here. Use the format provided with keys matching the href values (e.g., Mathematicae) and the content as a string (e.g., "Mathematicae - Genitive Plural..."). 4. Add Philosophical Context Cards: Replace or extend the philosophicalCards object in the JavaScript section, where it says // Paste additional philosophical context card entries here. Follow the same format as for the grammar cards. By following these steps, you can be sure that each card is correctly linked to the appropriate terms in both texts, allowing them to display the right information in the lower frames when interacted with. Let me know if you need more help with specific entries!
You
I don't understand step three. I want to be able to just paste my grammar card code in a single spot. What do you mean replace or extend the object?
ChatGPT
To make it easier, I'll adjust the code so that you can paste the entire set of grammar and philosophical context cards in a single spot without needing to modify individual entries. This way, you can directly paste your prepared grammar and philosophical card data into designated areas. Here’s how the updated code looks, with specific spots indicated for you to paste the entire grammar and philosophical context data. You will now just replace the example data with your full card data all at once. ### Full HTML App Code with Single-Paste Locations for Cards 
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Pico della Mirandola: Conclusiones de Mathematicis Secundum Opinionem Propriam Numero .LXXXV.</title>
    <style>
        body {
            display: grid;
            grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr;
            grid-template-rows: auto auto;
            gap: 1px;
            height: 100vh;
            margin: 0;
            font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
        }
        .frame {
            padding: 10px;
            overflow-y: auto;
            border: 1px solid #ccc;
        }
        #latin-text, #english-text {
            height: 40vh;
        }
        #grammar-context, #philosophical-context {
            height: 40vh;
        }
        a.annotated {
            color: blue;
            cursor: pointer;
            text-decoration: underline;
        }
    </style>
</head>
<body>

    <!-- Latin Text Frame -->
    <div id="latin-text" class="frame">
        <!-- Paste the Latin text code here -->
    </div>

    <!-- English Text Frame -->
    <div id="english-text" class="frame">
        <!-- Paste the English text code here -->
    </div>

    <!-- Grammar Context Frame -->
    <div id="grammar-context" class="frame">
        <p>Hover over a term in the Latin or English text to view grammatical details here.</p>
    </div>

    <!-- Philosophical Context Frame -->
    <div id="philosophical-context" class="frame">
        <p>Hover over a term in the Latin or English text to view philosophical context here.</p>
    </div>

    <script>
        document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function () {
            const grammarContext = document.getElementById('grammar-context');
            const philosophicalContext = document.getElementById('philosophical-context');

            // Paste the full grammar context card data here
            const grammarCards = {
                Mathematicae: "Mathematicae - Genitive Plural. Refers to 'mathematics' as a field of study.",
                Scientiae: "Scientiae - Nominative Plural. Used here to indicate 'sciences'.",
                Foelicitas: "Foelicitas - Nominative Singular. Denotes 'happiness' or 'blessedness'.",
                Perfectione: "Perfectione - Ablative Singular. Used here to convey 'in perfection'.",
                Faciunt: "Faciunt - 3rd Person Plural, Present Indicative. Means 'they make or do'.",
                // Continue adding grammar cards here following the same format
            };

            // Paste the full philosophical context card data here
            const philosophicalCards = {
                Mathematicae: "Mathematics - Discussed in Neoplatonism as bridging the sensible and intelligible.",
                Scientiae: "Science - Refers to knowledge derived from demonstrable principles, as per Scholasticism.",
                Foelicitas: "Happiness - Common in ancient philosophy, associated with the fulfillment of human purpose.",
                Perfectione: "Perfection - Often refers to the highest state of being or virtue in Neoplatonism.",
                Faciunt: "Make/Do - In Platonic thought, associated with bringing something into existence.",
                // Continue adding philosophical cards here following the same format
            };

            document.querySelectorAll('.annotated').forEach(function (element) {
                element.addEventListener('mouseover', function () {
                    const term = this.getAttribute('href').substring(1);
                    grammarContext.innerHTML = <p>${grammarCards[term] || 'No grammatical information available.'}</p>;
                    philosophicalContext.innerHTML = <p>${philosophicalCards[term] || 'No philosophical context available.'}</p>;
                });

                element.addEventListener('click', function (e) {
                    e.preventDefault();
                    const term = this.getAttribute('href').substring(1);
                    grammarContext.innerHTML = <p>${grammarCards[term] || 'No grammatical information available.'}</p>;
                    philosophicalContext.innerHTML = <p>${philosophicalCards[term] || 'No philosophical context available.'}</p>;
                });
            });
        });
    </script>

</body>
</html>
### Where to Paste Your Data 1. Paste Latin Text: Insert your Latin text with hyperlinks where it says <!-- Paste the Latin text code here -->. 2. Paste English Text: Insert your English text with hyperlinks where it says <!-- Paste the English text code here -->. 3. Paste Grammar Cards Data: Replace the placeholder entries inside const grammarCards with your complete set of grammar card data, following the same format. 4. Paste Philosophical Cards Data: Replace the placeholder entries inside const philosophicalCards with your complete set of philosophical card data. This setup should ensure that the hyperlinks are properly linked to the corresponding cards, with the full content being displayed in the appropriate context frames. If you run into any further issues, please let me know.
