<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Pico della Mirandola: Conclusiones de Mathematicis Secundum Opinionem Propriam Numero .LXXXV.</title>
    <style>
        body {
            display: grid;
            grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr;
            grid-template-rows: auto auto;
            gap: 1px;
            height: 100vh;
            margin: 0;
            font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
        }
        .frame {
            padding: 10px;
            overflow-y: auto;
            border: 1px solid #ccc;
        }
        #latin-text, #english-text {
            height: 40vh;
        }
        #grammar-context, #philosophical-context {
            height: 40vh;
        }
        a.annotated {
            color: blue;
            cursor: pointer;
            text-decoration: underline;
        }
    </style>
</head>
<body>

    <!-- Latin Text Frame -->
    <div id="latin-text" class="frame">
        <!-- Paste the Latin text code here -->
    </div>

    <!-- English Text Frame -->
    <div id="english-text" class="frame">
        <!-- Paste the English text code here -->
    </div>

    <!-- Grammar Context Frame -->
    <div id="grammar-context" class="frame">
        <p>Hover over a term in the Latin or English text to view grammatical details here.</p>
    </div>

    <!-- Philosophical Context Frame -->
    <div id="philosophical-context" class="frame">
        <p>Hover over a term in the Latin or English text to view philosophical context here.</p>
    </div>

    <script>
        document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function () {
            const grammarContext = document.getElementById('grammar-context');
            const philosophicalContext = document.getElementById('philosophical-context');

            // Paste your complete grammar card data below in the format shown
            const grammarCards = {
                // Example: Mathematicae: "Mathematicae - Genitive Plural. Refers to 'mathematics' as a field of study."
                // Paste your complete grammar card data here
            };

            // Paste your complete philosophical card data below in the format shown
            const philosophicalCards = {
                // Example: Mathematicae: "Mathematics - Discussed in Neoplatonism as bridging the sensible and intelligible."
                // Paste your complete philosophical card data here
            };

            document.querySelectorAll('.annotated').forEach(function (element) {
                element.addEventListener('mouseover', function () {
                    const term = this.getAttribute('href').substring(1);
                    grammarContext.innerHTML = <p>${grammarCards[term] || 'No grammatical information available.'}</p>;
                    philosophicalContext.innerHTML = <p>${philosophicalCards[term] || 'No philosophical context available.'}</p>;
                });

                element.addEventListener('click', function (e) {
                    e.preventDefault();
                    const term = this.getAttribute('href').substring(1);
                    grammarContext.innerHTML = <p>${grammarCards[term] || 'No grammatical information available.'}</p>;
                    philosophicalContext.innerHTML = <p>${philosophicalCards[term] || 'No philosophical context available.'}</p>;
                });
            });
        });
    </script>

</body>
</html>
### Steps for Adding Content: 1. Paste the Latin Text: Place your Latin text with hyperlinks in the <div id="latin-text" class="frame"> section. 2. Paste the English Text: Place your English text with hyperlinks in the <div id="english-text" class="frame"> section. 3. Paste Grammar Cards: Replace // Paste your complete grammar card data here with your entire grammar card dataset, formatted like this: 
    const grammarCards = {
        Mathematicae: "Mathematicae - Genitive Plural. Refers to 'mathematics' as a field of study.",
        Scientiae: "Scientiae - Nominative Plural. Used here to indicate 'sciences'.",
        // Continue with all other terms
    };
4. Paste Philosophical Cards: Replace // Paste your complete philosophical card data here with your entire philosophical card dataset, formatted like this: 
    const philosophicalCards = {
        Mathematicae: "Mathematics - Discussed in Neoplatonism as bridging the sensible and intelligible.",
        Scientiae: "Science - Refers to knowledge derived from demonstrable principles, as per Scholasticism.",
        // Continue with all other terms
    };
After these steps, save the file and open it in a browser to test the interactivity of the links and card displays.
You
It looks like you want me to reformat the cards. Start by reformatting the code for the grammatical context cards. <!-- Grammatical Context Cards (Hidden) --> <div id="grammar-cards" class="hidden"> <div id="Mathematicae-grammar"> <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive plural form, indicating possession or association.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Μαθηματικαί (Mathematikai)</p> </div> <div id="Scientiae-grammar"> <strong>Scientiae (Sciences)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, meaning "sciences" or "fields of knowledge".</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Ἐπιστήμαι (Epistēmai)</p> </div> <div id="Foelicitas-grammar"> <strong>Foelicitas (Happiness)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative singular form, often denotes ultimate human fulfillment or blessedness.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Εὐδαιμονία (Eudaimonia)</p> </div> <div id="Perfectione-grammar"> <strong>Perfectione (Perfection)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Ablative singular form, used here to imply the means by which something is perfected.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Τελείωσις (Teleiosis)</p> </div> <div id="Faciunt-grammar"> <strong>Faciunt (They make/do)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Third person plural present active indicative of 'facere', meaning to do or make.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Ποιεῖν (Poiein)</p> </div> <div id="Via-grammar"> <strong>Via (Way)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative singular form, meaning path or road, often metaphorically used for a method or means.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Ὁδός (Hodos)</p> </div> <div id="Scientias-grammar"> <strong>Scientias (Sciences)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Accusative plural form, object of the action, here used for the objects of study.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Μαθήματα (Mathēmata)</p> </div> <div id="Subiecta-grammar"> <strong>Subiecta (Subjects)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, meaning those things that lie beneath or are foundational.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Ὑποκείμενα (Hypokeimena)</p> </div> <div id="Accipiantur-grammar"> <strong>Accipiantur (May be accepted/received)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Third person plural present passive subjunctive of 'accipere', used to imply potential acceptance.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Δέχεσθαι (Dechesthai)</p> </div> <div id="Intellectum-grammar"> <strong>Intellectum (Understanding)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Accusative singular form, direct object of the verb implying comprehension or intellect.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Νοῦς (Nous)</p> </div> <div id="Imagines-grammar"> <strong>Imagines (Images)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, referring to likenesses or reflections.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Εἰκόνες (Eikones)</p> </div> <div id="Intelligibilium-grammar"> <strong>Intelligibilium (Of intelligible things)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive plural form, indicating a relationship to things apprehended by the intellect.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Νοητῶν (Noētōn)</p> </div> <div id="Speculationem-grammar"> <strong>Speculationem (Contemplation)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Accusative singular form, meaning consideration or thoughtful examination.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Θεωρία (Theōria)</p> </div> <div id="Aristotelis-grammar"> <strong>Aristotelis (Aristotle)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive singular form, indicating possession or authorship.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Ἀριστοτέλους (Aristotelous)</p> </div> <div id="Dicentis-grammar"> <strong>Dicentis (Of saying)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Present participle genitive singular of 'dicere', indicating the act of speaking or asserting.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Λέγοντος (Legontos)</p> </div> <div id="Contemplatione-grammar"> <strong>Contemplatione (Contemplation)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Ablative singular form, suggesting the means or method of reflection or deep thought.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Θεωρία (Theōria)</p> </div> <div id="Res-grammar"> <strong>Res (Things)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, commonly used to refer to physical or conceptual objects.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Πράγματα (Pragmata)</p> </div> <div id="Materialiter-grammar"> <strong>Materialiter (Materially)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Adverbial form, indicating something pertaining to physical substance.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Ὑλικά (Hylika)</p> </div> <div id="Formaliter-grammar"> <strong>Formaliter (Formally)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Adverbial form, referring to the aspect or essence of form.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Εἰδικά (Eidika)</p> </div> <div id="Naturalibus-grammar"> <strong>Naturalibus (Of natural things)</strong> <p><em>Latin:</em> Dative or ablative plural form, indicating those things pertaining to nature.</p> <p><em>Greek:</em> Φυσικοῖς (Physikois)</p> </div> </div>
ChatGPT
Here's the code with your provided grammatical context data in a structured format. Each section has been formatted for consistency, and this is where you'll place the data in your full HTML document. ### Grammatical Context Cards Code 
<!-- Grammatical Context Cards -->
<div id="grammar-cards" class="hidden">
    <!-- Individual grammatical context cards go here -->
    <div id="Mathematicae-grammar">
        <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive plural form, indicating possession or association.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Μαθηματικαί (Mathematikai)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientiae-grammar">
        <strong>Scientiae (Sciences)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, meaning "sciences" or "fields of knowledge".</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ἐπιστήμαι (Epistēmai)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Foelicitas-grammar">
        <strong>Foelicitas (Happiness)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative singular form, often denotes ultimate human fulfillment or blessedness.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Εὐδαιμονία (Eudaimonia)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Perfectione-grammar">
        <strong>Perfectione (Perfection)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Ablative singular form, used here to imply the means by which something is perfected.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Τελείωσις (Teleiosis)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Faciunt-grammar">
        <strong>Faciunt (They make/do)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Third person plural present active indicative of 'facere', meaning to do or make.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ποιεῖν (Poiein)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Via-grammar">
        <strong>Via (Way)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative singular form, meaning path or road, often metaphorically used for a method or means.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ὁδός (Hodos)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientias-grammar">
        <strong>Scientias (Sciences)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Accusative plural form, object of the action, here used for the objects of study.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Μαθήματα (Mathēmata)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Subiecta-grammar">
        <strong>Subiecta (Subjects)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, meaning those things that lie beneath or are foundational.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ὑποκείμενα (Hypokeimena)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Accipiantur-grammar">
        <strong>Accipiantur (May be accepted/received)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Third person plural present passive subjunctive of 'accipere', used to imply potential acceptance.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Δέχεσθαι (Dechesthai)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Intellectum-grammar">
        <strong>Intellectum (Understanding)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Accusative singular form, direct object of the verb implying comprehension or intellect.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Νοῦς (Nous)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Imagines-grammar">
        <strong>Imagines (Images)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, referring to likenesses or reflections.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Εἰκόνες (Eikones)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Intelligibilium-grammar">
        <strong>Intelligibilium (Of intelligible things)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive plural form, indicating a relationship to things apprehended by the intellect.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Νοητῶν (Noētōn)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Speculationem-grammar">
        <strong>Speculationem (Contemplation)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Accusative singular form, meaning consideration or thoughtful examination.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Θεωρία (Theōria)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Aristotelis-grammar">
        <strong>Aristotelis (Aristotle)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive singular form, indicating possession or authorship.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ἀριστοτέλους (Aristotelous)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Dicentis-grammar">
        <strong>Dicentis (Of saying)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Present participle genitive singular of 'dicere', indicating the act of speaking or asserting.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Λέγοντος (Legontos)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Contemplatione-grammar">
        <strong>Contemplatione (Contemplation)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Ablative singular form, suggesting the means or method of reflection or deep thought.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Θεωρία (Theōria)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Res-grammar">
        <strong>Res (Things)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, commonly used to refer to physical or conceptual objects.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Πράγματα (Pragmata)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Materialiter-grammar">
        <strong>Materialiter (Materially)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Adverbial form, indicating something pertaining to physical substance.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ὑλικά (Hylika)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Formaliter-grammar">
        <strong>Formaliter (Formally)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Adverbial form, referring to the aspect or essence of form.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Εἰδικά (Eidika)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Naturalibus-grammar">
        <strong>Naturalibus (Of natural things)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Dative or ablative plural form, indicating those things pertaining to nature.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Φυσικοῖς (Physikois)</p>
    </div>
</div>
### Instructions for Use 1. Paste this block of code inside the main HTML document wherever you want to store the grammatical context data, such as within a <body> or <div> element with display properties to keep it hidden. 2. Each <div> element with the id attribute corresponds to a term. The id attribute value should match the href attributes in your Latin and English text for linking. 3. Once this is added, you can follow the same process for the philosophical context cards, ensuring they are in a similar format so they will also align correctly with their respective terms.
You
Now reformat the philosophical context cards so that I can paste them into the html file where you specified earlier. <!-- Philosophical Context Cards (Hidden) --> <div id="philosophical-cards" class="hidden"> <div id="Mathematicae-context"> <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong> <p>Platonic Influence: In the Republic (Books VI-VII), Plato describes mathematics as a preparatory study necessary for philosophical understanding.</p> <p>Neoplatonic Influence: Proclus, in his Commentary on Euclid, highlights how mathematics draws the mind toward higher realities.</p> <p>Pico's Paraphrasing: Pico often uses this term to emphasize the Neoplatonic hierarchy, where mathematics is subordinate to metaphysics.</p> </div> <div id="Scientiae-context"> <strong>Scientiae (Sciences)</strong> <p>Scholastic Influence: In the Medieval tradition, sciences are categorized within the trivium and quadrivium, leading to a broader understanding of divine truths.</p> <p>Pico's Expansion: He uses 'scientiae' in a broader sense, where these pursuits ultimately serve as paths to metaphysical enlightenment.</p> </div> <div id="Foelicitas-context"> <strong>Foelicitas (Happiness)</strong> <p>Aristotelian Influence: Foelicitas, or eudaimonia, is central to Aristotelian ethics as the highest good.</p> <p>Pico’s Interpretation: He associates happiness with intellectual fulfillment, similar to the Platonic ideal of the Good.</p> </div> <div id="Perfectione-context"> <strong>Perfectione (Perfection)</strong> <p>Neoplatonic View: In Plotinus' writings, perfection is the ultimate unity with the One.</p> <p>Pico’s Perspective: For Pico, perfection in mathematics and metaphysics reflects the soul’s ascent towards divine understanding.</p> </div> <div id="Faciunt-context"> <strong>Faciunt (They make/do)</strong> <p>Platonic Connection: Actions in Plato's dialogues often denote the realization of potential forms.</p> <p>Pico’s View: Actions of the soul in understanding and manifesting divine truths reflect this Platonic concept.</p> </div> <div id="Via-context"> <strong>Via (Way)</strong> <p>Neopythagorean Influence: The "way" is central to the journey of the soul toward divine enlightenment.</p> <p>Pico's Usage: He often uses this term to signify the various paths one can take towards metaphysical knowledge.</p> </div> <div id="Scientias-context"> <strong>Scientias (Sciences)</strong> <p>Scholastic Tradition: Pico builds on the medieval trivium and quadrivium, where sciences serve as tools to approach divine truths.</p> <p>His Use: Sciences are stepping stones for Pico, leading to higher metaphysical truths.</p> </div> <div id="Subiecta-context"> <strong>Subiecta (Subjects)</strong> <p>Neoplatonic Influence: In Neoplatonism, subjects or substrata are those that receive forms and thus participate in the divine.</p> <p>Pico’s Interpretation: He uses it to denote both the material and metaphysical foundations for higher thought.</p> </div> <div id="Accipiantur-context"> <strong>Accipiantur (May be accepted/received)</strong> <p>Platonic Concept: Receiving forms is akin to participating in the divine realm.</p> <p>Pico’s Paraphrasing: He implies the receptive capacity of the intellect, highlighting a Platonic dynamic.</p> </div> <div id="Intellectum-context"> <strong>Intellectum (Understanding)</strong> <p>Aristotelian Connection: Aristotle considers intellect the highest faculty of the soul, capable of grasping forms.</p> <p>Pico’s Adaptation: Understanding is the means by which one ascends to metaphysical and divine knowledge.</p> </div> <div id="Imagines-context"> <strong>Imagines (Images)</strong> <p>Platonic Concept: Images are reflections of higher forms, as in the Allegory of the Cave.</p> <p>Pico’s Usage: He uses imagines to discuss metaphysical concepts and their tangible reflections in the world.</p> </div> <div id="Intelligibilium-context"> <strong>Intelligibilium (Of intelligible things)</strong> <p>Platonic and Neoplatonic Use: Refers to objects of intellect, as contrasted with sensible objects.</p> <p>Pico’s Application: Intelligible things are central to Pico’s metaphysics, bridging the divine and material realms.</p> </div> <div id="Speculationem-context"> <strong>Speculationem (Contemplation)</strong> <p>Platonic Tradition: Contemplation is seen as the soul’s means of engaging with higher truths.</p> <p>Pico’s Usage: Speculation is tied to intellectual ascent, akin to Platonic and Neoplatonic contemplation.</p> </div> <div id="Aristotelis-context"> <strong>Aristotelis (Aristotle)</strong> <p>Influence: Aristotle's influence is pervasive in Scholasticism, often emphasizing empirical observation alongside metaphysical speculation.</p> <p>Pico’s Response: He integrates and critiques Aristotle within a Platonic and Neoplatonic framework.</p> </div> <div id="Dicentis-context"> <strong>Dicentis (Of saying)</strong> <p>Use in Neoplatonism: Language and naming often signify participation in divine Logos.</p> <p>Pico’s Approach: Refers to the articulation of metaphysical insights as participating in divine truth.</p> </div> <div id="Contemplatione-context"> <strong>Contemplatione (Contemplation)</strong> <p>Platonic and Neoplatonic Tradition: Contemplation is the highest form of intellectual activity, leading the soul back to the divine.</p> <p>Pico’s Perspective: Contemplation is both the means and end of intellectual and spiritual ascent.</p> </div> <div id="Res-context"> <strong>Res (Things)</strong> <p>Aristotelian and Platonic Contexts: Aristotle and Plato view "things" as either possessing or striving towards forms.</p> <p>Pico’s Reference: Refers to both material and immaterial realities as connected by metaphysical principles.</p> </div> <div id="Materialiter-context"> <strong>Materialiter (Materially)</strong> <p>Neoplatonic Concept: The material is always subordinate to the immaterial.</p> <p>Pico’s View: Suggests that viewing things materially is lesser than understanding them formally.</p> </div> <div id="Formaliter-context"> <strong>Formaliter (Formally)</strong> <p>Platonic Concept: Refers to the true essence or form of a thing, which transcends its material instantiation.</p> <p>Pico’s Use: He emphasizes formal over material views, in line with Platonic thought.</p> </div> <div id="Naturalibus-context"> <strong>Naturalibus (Of natural things)</strong> <p>Aristotelian and Scholastic Tradition: Natural things are studied to understand the underlying forms.</p> <p>Pico’s Perspective: Engages with nature to highlight its connection to divine and metaphysical forms.</p> </div> </div>
ChatGPT
Here is the restructured code for the philosophical context cards, where each card contains the information for specific terms and will fit neatly into the main HTML file. ### Philosophical Context Cards Code 
<!-- Philosophical Context Cards (Hidden) -->
<div id="philosophical-cards" class="hidden">
    <div id="Mathematicae-context">
        <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Influence: In the Republic (Books VI-VII), Plato describes mathematics as a preparatory study necessary for philosophical understanding.</p>
        <p>Neoplatonic Influence: Proclus, in his Commentary on Euclid, highlights how mathematics draws the mind toward higher realities.</p>
        <p>Pico's Paraphrasing: Pico often uses this term to emphasize the Neoplatonic hierarchy, where mathematics is subordinate to metaphysics.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientiae-context">
        <strong>Scientiae (Sciences)</strong>
        <p>Scholastic Influence: In the Medieval tradition, sciences are categorized within the trivium and quadrivium, leading to a broader understanding of divine truths.</p>
        <p>Pico's Expansion: He uses 'scientiae' in a broader sense, where these pursuits ultimately serve as paths to metaphysical enlightenment.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Foelicitas-context">
        <strong>Foelicitas (Happiness)</strong>
        <p>Aristotelian Influence: Foelicitas, or eudaimonia, is central to Aristotelian ethics as the highest good.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Interpretation: He associates happiness with intellectual fulfillment, similar to the Platonic ideal of the Good.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Perfectione-context">
        <strong>Perfectione (Perfection)</strong>
        <p>Neoplatonic View: In Plotinus' writings, perfection is the ultimate unity with the One.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Perspective: For Pico, perfection in mathematics and metaphysics reflects the soul’s ascent towards divine understanding.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Faciunt-context">
        <strong>Faciunt (They make/do)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Connection: Actions in Plato's dialogues often denote the realization of potential forms.</p>
        <p>Pico’s View: Actions of the soul in understanding and manifesting divine truths reflect this Platonic concept.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Via-context">
        <strong>Via (Way)</strong>
        <p>Neopythagorean Influence: The "way" is central to the journey of the soul toward divine enlightenment.</p>
        <p>Pico's Usage: He often uses this term to signify the various paths one can take towards metaphysical knowledge.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientias-context">
        <strong>Scientias (Sciences)</strong>
        <p>Scholastic Tradition: Pico builds on the medieval trivium and quadrivium, where sciences serve as tools to approach divine truths.</p>
        <p>His Use: Sciences are stepping stones for Pico, leading to higher metaphysical truths.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Subiecta-context">
        <strong>Subiecta (Subjects)</strong>
        <p>Neoplatonic Influence: In Neoplatonism, subjects or substrata are those that receive forms and thus participate in the divine.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Interpretation: He uses it to denote both the material and metaphysical foundations for higher thought.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Accipiantur-context">
        <strong>Accipiantur (May be accepted/received)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Concept: Receiving forms is akin to participating in the divine realm.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Paraphrasing: He implies the receptive capacity of the intellect, highlighting a Platonic dynamic.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Intellectum-context">
        <strong>Intellectum (Understanding)</strong>
        <p>Aristotelian Connection: Aristotle considers intellect the highest faculty of the soul, capable of grasping forms.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Adaptation: Understanding is the means by which one ascends to metaphysical and divine knowledge.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Imagines-context">
        <strong>Imagines (Images)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Concept: Images are reflections of higher forms, as in the Allegory of the Cave.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Usage: He uses imagines to discuss metaphysical concepts and their tangible reflections in the world.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Intelligibilium-context">
        <strong>Intelligibilium (Of intelligible things)</strong>
        <p>Platonic and Neoplatonic Use: Refers to objects of intellect, as contrasted with sensible objects.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Application: Intelligible things are central to Pico’s metaphysics, bridging the divine and material realms.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Speculationem-context">
        <strong>Speculationem (Contemplation)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Tradition: Contemplation is seen as the soul’s means of engaging with higher truths.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Usage: Speculation is tied to intellectual ascent, akin to Platonic and Neoplatonic contemplation.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Aristotelis-context">
        <strong>Aristotelis (Aristotle)</strong>
        <p>Influence: Aristotle's influence is pervasive in Scholasticism, often emphasizing empirical observation alongside metaphysical speculation.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Response: He integrates and critiques Aristotle within a Platonic and Neoplatonic framework.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Dicentis-context">
        <strong>Dicentis (Of saying)</strong>
        <p>Use in Neoplatonism: Language and naming often signify participation in divine Logos.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Approach: Refers to the articulation of metaphysical insights as participating in divine truth.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Contemplatione-context">
        <strong>Contemplatione (Contemplation)</strong>
        <p>Platonic and Neoplatonic Tradition: Contemplation is the highest form of intellectual activity, leading the soul back to the divine.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Perspective: Contemplation is both the means and end of intellectual and spiritual ascent.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Res-context">
        <strong>Res (Things)</strong>
        <p>Aristotelian and Platonic Contexts: Aristotle and Plato view "things" as either possessing or striving towards forms.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Reference: Refers to both material and immaterial realities as connected by metaphysical principles.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Materialiter-context">
        <strong>Materialiter (Materially)</strong>
        <p>Neoplatonic Concept: The material is always subordinate to the immaterial.</p>
        <p>Pico’s View: Suggests that viewing things materially is lesser than understanding them formally.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Formaliter-context">
        <strong>Formaliter (Formally)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Concept: Refers to the true essence or form of a thing, which transcends its material instantiation.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Use: He emphasizes formal over material views, in line with Platonic thought.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Naturalibus-context">
        <strong>Naturalibus (Of natural things)</strong>
        <p>Aristotelian and Scholastic Tradition: Natural things are studied to understand the underlying forms.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Perspective: Engages with nature to highlight its connection to divine and metaphysical forms.</p>
    </div>
</div>
### Instructions for Use 1. Place this block of code in your HTML file within the <body> section, ideally where you want the hidden data to reside. 2. Each <div> element corresponds to a specific term. The id attribute should align with the href links within the Latin and English text sections of your main document. 3. This code will function alongside the grammatical context cards and enable the app to show both grammatical and philosophical context when interacting with terms.
You
Okay build the html file so that I know where to paste in the latin text, english texts, g cards and p cards without having to replace any objects.
ChatGPT
Here is the full HTML file layout with comments that clearly indicate where to paste each section (Latin text, English text, Grammatical Context Cards, and Philosophical Context Cards): 
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Pico della Mirandola: Conclusiones de Mathematicis</title>
    <style>
        /* Basic styles for layout and frames */
        body {
            font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
            margin: 0;
            padding: 0;
        }
        .frame {
            border: 1px solid #ccc;
            padding: 15px;
            overflow-y: auto;
        }
        .container {
            display: flex;
            flex-wrap: wrap;
            height: 100vh;
        }
        .container > div {
            flex: 1;
            min-height: 50%;
            width: 50%;
            box-sizing: border-box;
        }
        .hidden {
            display: none;
        }
    </style>
</head>
<body>

    <h1>Pico della Mirandola: conclusiones de mathematicis secundum opinionem propriam numero .lxxxv.</h1>
    <div class="container">
        <!-- Upper Left Frame: Latin Text -->
        <div class="frame" id="latin-frame">
            <!-- Paste Latin Text Here -->
            <p>
                <a href="#Mathematicae" class="annotated">Mathematicae</a> non sunt verae <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">scientiae</a>.
            </p>
            <p>
                Si <a href="#Foelicitas" class="annotated">foelicitas</a> sit in speculativa <a href="#Perfectione" class="annotated">perfectione</a>: mathematicae non <a href="#Faciunt" class="annotated">faciunt</a> ad foelicitatem.
            </p>
            <!-- Continue with the rest of the Latin text... -->
        </div>
        
        <!-- Upper Right Frame: English Text -->
        <div class="frame" id="english-frame">
            <!-- Paste English Text Here -->
            <p> 
                <a href="#Mathematicae" class="annotated">Mathematics</a> are not true <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">sciences</a>.
            </p>
            <p>
                If <a href="#Foelicitas" class="annotated">happiness</a> lies in speculative <a href="#Perfectione" class="annotated">perfection</a>, then mathematics does not <a href="#Faciunt" class="annotated">contribute</a> to happiness.
            </p>
            <!-- Continue with the rest of the English text... -->
        </div>
        
        <!-- Lower Left Frame: Grammatical Context -->
        <div class="frame" id="grammar-frame">
            <p>Hover over a term to see the grammatical context here.</p>
        </div>
        
        <!-- Lower Right Frame: Philosophical Context -->
        <div class="frame" id="philosophical-frame">
            <p>Hover over a term to see the philosophical context here.</p>
        </div>
    </div>

    <!-- Grammatical Context Cards (Hidden) -->
    <div id="grammar-cards" class="hidden">
        <!-- Paste Grammatical Context Cards Here -->
        <div id="Mathematicae-grammar">
            <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
            <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive plural form, indicating possession or association.</p>
            <p><em>Greek:</em> Μαθηματικαί (Mathematikai)</p>
        </div>
        <!-- Continue with other grammatical context cards... -->
    </div>

    <!-- Philosophical Context Cards (Hidden) -->
    <div id="philosophical-cards" class="hidden">
        <!-- Paste Philosophical Context Cards Here -->
        <div id="Mathematicae-context">
            <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
            <p>Platonic Influence: In the Republic (Books VI-VII), Plato describes mathematics as a preparatory study necessary for philosophical understanding.</p>
            <p>Neoplatonic Influence: Proclus, in his Commentary on Euclid, highlights how mathematics draws the mind toward higher realities.</p>
            <p>Pico's Paraphrasing: Pico often uses this term to emphasize the Neoplatonic hierarchy, where mathematics is subordinate to metaphysics.</p>
        </div>
        <!-- Continue with other philosophical context cards... -->
    </div>

    <script>
        // JavaScript to handle hovering and clicking for context display
        document.querySelectorAll('.annotated').forEach(item => {
            item.addEventListener('mouseover', event => {
                let id = event.target.getAttribute('href').substring(1);
                displayCard(id, 'grammar');
                displayCard(id, 'philosophical');
            });

            item.addEventListener('click', event => {
                event.preventDefault();
                let id = event.target.getAttribute('href').substring(1);
                displayCard(id, 'grammar');
                displayCard(id, 'philosophical');
            });
        });

        function displayCard(id, type) {
            let frameId = type === 'grammar' ? 'grammar-frame' : 'philosophical-frame';
            let card = document.getElementById(${id}-${type});
            if (card) {
                document.getElementById(frameId).innerHTML = card.innerHTML;
            }
        }
    </script>
</body>
</html>
### Instructions: - Paste the Latin Text: Find the <!-- Paste Latin Text Here --> comment in the upper left frame and paste the entire Latin text there. - Paste the English Text: Find the <!-- Paste English Text Here --> comment in the upper right frame and paste the entire English text there. - Paste Grammatical Context Cards: Locate <!-- Paste Grammatical Context Cards Here --> in the hidden grammar-cards div and paste all grammatical context cards within that section. - Paste Philosophical Context Cards: Locate <!-- Paste Philosophical Context Cards Here --> in the hidden philosophical-cards div and paste all philosophical context cards within that section. Let me know if you need further clarification or any adjustments.

ChatGPT
Here’s the full HTML layout revised to ensure proper four-frame structure and functioning display for the context cards. You’ll be able to paste the Latin and English texts, as well as the grammatical and philosophical context cards, directly where indicated. 
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Pico della Mirandola: Conclusiones de Mathematicis</title>
    <style>
        /* Basic styles for layout and frames */
        body {
            font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
            margin: 0;
            padding: 0;
            display: flex;
            flex-wrap: wrap;
            height: 100vh;
            width: 100vw;
        }
        .frame {
            border: 1px solid #ccc;
            padding: 10px;
            overflow-y: auto;
            box-sizing: border-box;
        }
        #latin-frame, #english-frame {
            height: 50%;
            width: 50%;
        }
        #grammar-frame, #philosophical-frame {
            height: 50%;
            width: 50%;
        }
        .hidden {
            display: none;
        }
    </style>
</head>
<body>

    <h1>Pico della Mirandola: conclusiones de mathematicis secundum opinionem propriam numero .lxxxv.</h1>

    <!-- Upper Left Frame: Latin Text -->
    <div class="frame" id="latin-frame">
        <!-- Paste Latin Text Here -->
        <p>
            <a href="#Mathematicae" class="annotated">Mathematicae</a> non sunt verae <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">scientiae</a>.
        </p>
        <p>
            Si <a href="#Foelicitas" class="annotated">foelicitas</a> sit in speculativa <a href="#Perfectione" class="annotated">perfectione</a>: mathematicae non <a href="#Faciunt" class="annotated">faciunt</a> ad foelicitatem.
        </p>
        <!-- Continue with the rest of the Latin text... -->
    </div>

    <!-- Upper Right Frame: English Text -->
    <div class="frame" id="english-frame">
        <!-- Paste English Text Here -->
        <p> 
            <a href="#Mathematicae" class="annotated">Mathematics</a> are not true <a href="#Scientiae" class="annotated">sciences</a>.
        </p>
        <p>
            If <a href="#Foelicitas" class="annotated">happiness</a> lies in speculative <a href="#Perfectione" class="annotated">perfection</a>, then mathematics does not <a href="#Faciunt" class="annotated">contribute</a> to happiness.
        </p>
        <!-- Continue with the rest of the English text... -->
    </div>

    <!-- Lower Left Frame: Grammatical Context -->
    <div class="frame" id="grammar-frame">
        <p>Hover over a term to see the grammatical context here.</p>
    </div>

    <!-- Lower Right Frame: Philosophical Context -->
    <div class="frame" id="philosophical-frame">
        <p>Hover over a term to see the philosophical context here.</p>
    </div>

    <!-- Grammatical Context Cards (Hidden) -->
    <div id="grammar-cards" class="hidden">
        <!-- Paste Grammatical Context Cards Here -->
        <div id="Mathematicae-grammar">
            <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
            <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive plural form, indicating possession or association.</p>
            <p><em>Greek:</em> Μαθηματικαί (Mathematikai)</p>
        </div>
        <!-- Continue with other grammatical context cards... -->
    </div>

    <!-- Philosophical Context Cards (Hidden) -->
    <div id="philosophical-cards" class="hidden">
        <!-- Paste Philosophical Context Cards Here -->
        <div id="Mathematicae-context">
            <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
            <p>Platonic Influence: In the Republic (Books VI-VII), Plato describes mathematics as a preparatory study necessary for philosophical understanding.</p>
            <p>Neoplatonic Influence: Proclus, in his Commentary on Euclid, highlights how mathematics draws the mind toward higher realities.</p>
            <p>Pico's Paraphrasing: Pico often uses this term to emphasize the Neoplatonic hierarchy, where mathematics is subordinate to metaphysics.</p>
        </div>
        <!-- Continue with other philosophical context cards... -->
    </div>

    <script>
        // JavaScript to handle hovering and clicking for context display
        document.querySelectorAll('.annotated').forEach(item => {
            item.addEventListener('mouseover', event => {
                let id = event.target.getAttribute('href').substring(1);
                displayCard(id, 'grammar');
                displayCard(id, 'philosophical');
            });

            item.addEventListener('click', event => {
                event.preventDefault();
                let id = event.target.getAttribute('href').substring(1);
                displayCard(id, 'grammar');
                displayCard(id, 'philosophical');
            });
        });

        function displayCard(id, type) {
            let frameId = type === 'grammar' ? 'grammar-frame' : 'philosophical-frame';
            let card = document.getElementById(${id}-${type});
            if (card) {
                document.getElementById(frameId).innerHTML = card.innerHTML;
            }
        }
    </script>
</body>
</html>
### Instructions for Pasting: - Paste the Latin Text: Locate the comment <!-- Paste Latin Text Here --> within the latin-frame and insert your Latin text there. - Paste the English Text: Locate the comment <!-- Paste English Text Here --> within the english-frame and insert your English text there. - Paste Grammatical Context Cards: Locate <!-- Paste Grammatical Context Cards Here --> in the grammar-cards section, and paste your grammatical context cards within that section. - Paste Philosophical Context Cards: Locate <!-- Paste Philosophical Context Cards Here --> in the philosophical-cards section, and paste your philosophical context cards within that section. By following these instructions, each card should display in the correct frame. Let me know if you encounter any issues!
You
The frames are working but the lower right frame is still not displaying the philosophical context cards. Do we need to reformat those cards?
ChatGPT
Let’s ensure the formatting is consistent and that the lower right frame properly retrieves and displays the philosophical context cards. One common issue with hidden elements is that their visibility properties might conflict with JavaScript. Here’s how to make sure everything works: 1. Check IDs and Classes: Make sure each card's ID matches exactly what is called in the JavaScript. 2. Ensure No Conflicting Styles: Verify that .hidden only hides elements from view without affecting JavaScript’s ability to retrieve content. Here’s the reformatted code for the philosophical context cards. After pasting this into the <div id="philosophical-cards" class="hidden"> section, everything should display correctly. 
<!-- Philosophical Context Cards (Hidden) -->
<div id="philosophical-cards" class="hidden">
    <div id="Mathematicae-context">
        <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Influence: In the Republic (Books VI-VII), Plato describes mathematics as a preparatory study necessary for philosophical understanding.</p>
        <p>Neoplatonic Influence: Proclus, in his Commentary on Euclid, highlights how mathematics draws the mind toward higher realities.</p>
        <p>Pico's Paraphrasing: Pico often uses this term to emphasize the Neoplatonic hierarchy, where mathematics is subordinate to metaphysics.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientiae-context">
        <strong>Scientiae (Sciences)</strong>
        <p>Scholastic Influence: In the Medieval tradition, sciences are categorized within the trivium and quadrivium, leading to a broader understanding of divine truths.</p>
        <p>Pico's Expansion: He uses 'scientiae' in a broader sense, where these pursuits ultimately serve as paths to metaphysical enlightenment.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Foelicitas-context">
        <strong>Foelicitas (Happiness)</strong>
        <p>Aristotelian Influence: Foelicitas, or eudaimonia, is central to Aristotelian ethics as the highest good.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Interpretation: He associates happiness with intellectual fulfillment, similar to the Platonic ideal of the Good.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Perfectione-context">
        <strong>Perfectione (Perfection)</strong>
        <p>Neoplatonic View: In Plotinus' writings, perfection is the ultimate unity with the One.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Perspective: For Pico, perfection in mathematics and metaphysics reflects the soul’s ascent towards divine understanding.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Faciunt-context">
        <strong>Faciunt (They make/do)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Connection: Actions in Plato's dialogues often denote the realization of potential forms.</p>
        <p>Pico’s View: Actions of the soul in understanding and manifesting divine truths reflect this Platonic concept.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Via-context">
        <strong>Via (Way)</strong>
        <p>Neopythagorean Influence: The "way" is central to the journey of the soul toward divine enlightenment.</p>
        <p>Pico's Usage: He often uses this term to signify the various paths one can take towards metaphysical knowledge.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientias-context">
        <strong>Scientias (Sciences)</strong>
        <p>Scholastic Tradition: Pico builds on the medieval trivium and quadrivium, where sciences serve as tools to approach divine truths.</p>
        <p>His Use: Sciences are stepping stones for Pico, leading to higher metaphysical truths.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Subiecta-context">
        <strong>Subiecta (Subjects)</strong>
        <p>Neoplatonic Influence: In Neoplatonism, subjects or substrata are those that receive forms and thus participate in the divine.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Interpretation: He uses it to denote both the material and metaphysical foundations for higher thought.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Accipiantur-context">
        <strong>Accipiantur (May be accepted/received)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Concept: Receiving forms is akin to participating in the divine realm.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Paraphrasing: He implies the receptive capacity of the intellect, highlighting a Platonic dynamic.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Intellectum-context">
        <strong>Intellectum (Understanding)</strong>
        <p>Aristotelian Connection: Aristotle considers intellect the highest faculty of the soul, capable of grasping forms.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Adaptation: Understanding is the means by which one ascends to metaphysical and divine knowledge.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Imagines-context">
        <strong>Imagines (Images)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Concept: Images are reflections of higher forms, as in the Allegory of the Cave.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Usage: He uses imagines to discuss metaphysical concepts and their tangible reflections in the world.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Intelligibilium-context">
        <strong>Intelligibilium (Of intelligible things)</strong>
        <p>Platonic and Neoplatonic Use: Refers to objects of intellect, as contrasted with sensible objects.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Application: Intelligible things are central to Pico’s metaphysics, bridging the divine and material realms.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Speculationem-context">
        <strong>Speculationem (Contemplation)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Tradition: Contemplation is seen as the soul’s means of engaging with higher truths.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Usage: Speculation is tied to intellectual ascent, akin to Platonic and Neoplatonic contemplation.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Aristotelis-context">
        <strong>Aristotelis (Aristotle)</strong>
        <p>Influence: Aristotle's influence is pervasive in Scholasticism, often emphasizing empirical observation alongside metaphysical speculation.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Response: He integrates and critiques Aristotle within a Platonic and Neoplatonic framework.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Dicentis-context">
        <strong>Dicentis (Of saying)</strong>
        <p>Use in Neoplatonism: Language and naming often signify participation in divine Logos.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Approach: Refers to the articulation of metaphysical insights as participating in divine truth.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Contemplatione-context">
        <strong>Contemplatione (Contemplation)</strong>
        <p>Platonic and Neoplatonic Tradition: Contemplation is the highest form of intellectual activity, leading the soul back to the divine.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Perspective: Contemplation is both the means and end of intellectual and spiritual ascent.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Res-context">
        <strong>Res (Things)</strong>
        <p>Aristotelian and Platonic Contexts: Aristotle and Plato view "things" as either possessing or striving towards forms.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Reference: Refers to both material and immaterial realities as connected by metaphysical principles.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Materialiter-context">
        <strong>Materialiter (Materially)</strong>
        <p>Neoplatonic Concept: The material is always subordinate to the immaterial.</p>
        <p>Pico’s View: Suggests that viewing things materially is lesser than understanding them formally.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Formaliter-context">
        <strong>Formaliter (Formally)</strong>
        <p>Platonic Concept: Refers to the true essence or form of a thing, which transcends its material instantiation.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Use: He emphasizes formal over material views, in line with Platonic thought.</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Naturalibus-context">
        <strong>Naturalibus (Of natural things)</strong>
        <p>Aristotelian and Scholastic Tradition: Natural things are studied to understand the underlying forms.</p>
        <p>Pico’s Perspective: Engages with nature to highlight its connection to divine and metaphysical forms.</p>
    </div>
</div>

You
Can you rebuild the main html file and verify that the script section correctly references these IDs? Make sure I know where to paste in the philosophy cards without having to replace any example placeholders.
ChatGPT
Here's a revised version of the HTML file, fully integrated with comments to guide you on where to paste in the philosophical context cards. I have also verified that the script correctly references these IDs so that the cards should display properly. 
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Pico della Mirandola: conclusiones de mathematicis secundum opinionem propriam numero .lxxxv.</title>
    <style>
        body { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr; grid-template-rows: 1fr 1fr; height: 100vh; margin: 0; }
        .frame { padding: 10px; border: 1px solid #000; overflow-y: auto; }
        #latin-text { grid-column: 1; grid-row: 1; }
        #english-text { grid-column: 2; grid-row: 1; }
        #grammar-context { grid-column: 1; grid-row: 2; }
        #philosophical-context { grid-column: 2; grid-row: 2; }
        .hidden { display: none; }
    </style>
</head>
<body>
    <!-- Upper Left: Latin Text -->
    <div id="latin-text" class="frame">
        <!-- Paste Latin text here -->
    </div>

    <!-- Upper Right: English Translation -->
    <div id="english-text" class="frame">
        <!-- Paste English translation here -->
    </div>

    <!-- Lower Left: Grammatical Context -->
    <div id="grammar-context" class="frame">
        <!-- Grammatical cards will display here -->
    </div>

    <!-- Lower Right: Philosophical Context -->
    <div id="philosophical-context" class="frame">
        <!-- Philosophical cards will display here -->
    </div>

    <!-- Grammatical Context Cards (Hidden) -->
    <div id="grammar-cards" class="hidden">
        <!-- Paste Grammatical Context Cards here -->
    </div>

    <!-- Philosophical Context Cards (Hidden) -->
    <div id="philosophical-cards" class="hidden">
        <!-- Paste Philosophical Context Cards here -->
    </div>

    <script>
        // JavaScript to manage card display
        document.querySelectorAll('.annotated').forEach(item => {
            item.addEventListener('mouseover', event => {
                // Show grammatical context
                const grammarContent = document.querySelector(#${event.target.getAttribute('href').substring(1)}-grammar);
                document.getElementById('grammar-context').innerHTML = grammarContent ? grammarContent.innerHTML : '';
                
                // Show philosophical context
                const philosophyContent = document.querySelector(#${event.target.getAttribute('href').substring(1)}-context);
                document.getElementById('philosophical-context').innerHTML = philosophyContent ? philosophyContent.innerHTML : '';
            });
            
            item.addEventListener('click', event => {
                event.preventDefault();
                // Stabilize context on click
                const grammarContent = document.querySelector(#${event.target.getAttribute('href').substring(1)}-grammar);
                document.getElementById('grammar-context').innerHTML = grammarContent ? grammarContent.innerHTML : '';
                
                const philosophyContent = document.querySelector(#${event.target.getAttribute('href').substring(1)}-context);
                document.getElementById('philosophical-context').innerHTML = philosophyContent ? philosophyContent.innerHTML : '';
            });
        });
    </script>
</body>
</html>
### Pasting Instructions: 1. Latin Text: Paste your Latin text code inside <div id="latin-text" class="frame"> <!-- Paste Latin text here --> </div>. 2. English Translation: Paste your English translation code inside <div id="english-text" class="frame"> <!-- Paste English translation here --> </div>. 3. Grammatical Context Cards: Paste your formatted grammatical context card HTML code inside <div id="grammar-cards" class="hidden"> <!-- Paste Grammatical Context Cards here --> </div>. 4. Philosophical Context Cards: Paste your formatted philosophical context card HTML code inside <div id="philosophical-cards" class="hidden"> <!-- Paste Philosophical Context Cards here --> </div>. By pasting into these designated spots, the application should correctly display both the grammatical and philosophical context when hovering over or clicking terms. Let me know if any part needs adjustment or further explanation!

ChatGPT
It sounds like the length of the cards may be exceeding the response capacity, which can affect the hyperlink functionality. To ensure that all hyperlinks work reliably, let's split the card content across multiple sections. ### Solution Overview: 1. Separate HTML Divs for Cards: We'll split the grammatical and philosophical context cards across multiple <div> elements. 2. Reference by ID: Ensure each card has a unique ID for clear referencing. 3. Multiple <div> Containers: Create several smaller containers for both the grammatical and philosophical context cards, then link them together. ### Step-by-Step: 1. Build Smaller Card Sections: Start by creating two separate containers for the grammatical context cards, each holding half of the cards. Then do the same for the philosophical context cards. 2. Load All Sections into the Main File: Once the card sections are ready, you can paste them into the main HTML file to avoid overwhelming it with a single large block of code. Let's start with the first section of the grammatical context cards below, and we’ll proceed with the remaining parts in subsequent steps. 
<!-- Grammatical Context Cards Part 1 (Hidden) -->
<div id="grammar-cards-part1" class="hidden">
    <div id="Mathematicae-grammar">
        <strong>Mathematicae (Mathematics)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Genitive plural form, indicating possession or association.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Μαθηματικαί (Mathematikai)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Scientiae-grammar">
        <strong>Scientiae (Sciences)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative plural form, meaning "sciences" or "fields of knowledge".</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ἐπιστήμαι (Epistēmai)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Foelicitas-grammar">
        <strong>Foelicitas (Happiness)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Nominative singular form, often denotes ultimate human fulfillment or blessedness.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Εὐδαιμονία (Eudaimonia)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Perfectione-grammar">
        <strong>Perfectione (Perfection)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Ablative singular form, used here to imply the means by which something is perfected.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Τελείωσις (Teleiosis)</p>
    </div>
    <div id="Faciunt-grammar">
        <strong>Faciunt (They make/do)</strong>
        <p><em>Latin:</em> Third person plural present active indicative of 'facere', meaning to do or make.</p>
        <p><em>Greek:</em> Ποιεῖν (Poiein)</p>
    </div>
</div>
Once this part is ready, we’ll proceed with additional containers for the remaining grammatical cards and then repeat the same for the philosophical cards.

Break it into 12 chapters explaining to beginners how to build the HTML file from the ground up, in the style of a "code for dummies" sort of book. Let's start by outlining the 12 chapters.
ChatGPT
Here's a 12-chapter outline to guide beginners through the process of creating a digital edition like the one we built. Each chapter will focus on specific parts of the HTML, CSS, and JavaScript code, with clear instructions and explanations on how to piece everything together. The book will have a practical, step-by-step approach to help readers understand the fundamentals. ### Chapter Outline for "Creating Digital Editions for Beginners" --- Chapter 1: Introduction to Digital Editions - Overview: Discuss the purpose and benefits of digital editions. - Objective: Explain what will be built—a four-pane HTML digital edition with hover and click interactivity. - Tools Needed: List essential tools (text editor, web browser) and resources for learning HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Chapter 2: Setting Up the HTML Structure - Overview: Introduction to HTML and the basics of structuring a webpage. - Objective: Build the basic HTML skeleton with <html>, <head>, and <body> tags. - Practice: Create a simple HTML file with the correct tags and save it for future use. Chapter 3: Dividing the Page into Frames - Overview: Understand <div> tags and how they help structure content. - Objective: Add four <div> sections for the upper left, upper right, lower left, and lower right frames. - Practice: Style the divs with basic inline CSS to visualize the four frames on the webpage. Chapter 4: Styling with CSS - Overview: Introduction to CSS for layout and visual design. - Objective: Create a <style> section within the HTML and add CSS to style the four frames. - Practice: Apply styles like width, height, borders, and background colors to clearly define each frame. Chapter 5: Adding Latin and English Texts - Overview: How to add text content and format it with HTML elements. - Objective: Paste the Latin and English versions into the upper left and upper right frames, respectively. - Practice: Use paragraphs (<p>) and link (<a>) tags to structure and hyperlink the text. Chapter 6: Creating Hyperlinks for Interactivity - Overview: Understand how to create clickable and hoverable links with the <a> tag. - Objective: Set up links on key terms within the Latin and English texts, and make them clickable. - Practice: Experiment with <a> tags, including adding classes for targeted styling later. Chapter 7: Building the Grammatical Context Cards - Overview: Introduction to the concept of hidden content in HTML. - Objective: Create a hidden <div> section for each grammatical card and give each an id for easy reference. - Practice: Use the class="hidden" styling to hide and show content as needed. Chapter 8: Adding Philosophical Context Cards - Overview: Expand on hidden content with a second set of hidden <div>s. - Objective: Build a similar hidden section for the philosophical context cards, explaining the purpose of each term. - Practice: Use id attributes to uniquely identify each term’s philosophical context. Chapter 9: Writing JavaScript for Hover Interactivity - Overview: Introduction to JavaScript for dynamic content. - Objective: Write a JavaScript function that displays the content of the grammatical or philosophical card when a term is hovered over. - Practice: Use JavaScript to target elements by id and show/hide the appropriate content. Chapter 10: Implementing Click to Stabilize Feature - Overview: How to add click interactivity to keep content displayed. - Objective: Update the JavaScript to enable clicking on a term to “lock” the corresponding content in place until a new term is hovered. - Practice: Add event listeners for click and mouseover events, using JavaScript logic to lock and unlock cards. Chapter 11: Troubleshooting and Debugging - Overview: Common issues and how to resolve them, such as hyperlinks not working or frames not displaying correctly. - Objective: Learn simple debugging techniques and tools (like the browser console). - Practice: Test each section and troubleshoot any broken links or styling issues. Chapter 12: Final Touches and Going Live - Overview: Review, polish, and prepare the digital edition for sharing. - Objective: Add finishing touches, like external CSS for cleaner styling or a favicon, and learn how to host the digital edition on a web server. - Practice: Test the final product in different browsers, make adjustments, and upload it to a web server (if desired). --- This structure should provide a beginner-friendly guide to understanding and building a digital edition from the ground up. Each chapter builds on the last, ensuring that readers can follow along and create a complete, functioning digital edition by the end.

ChatGPT
Yes, I can fit Chapter 1 into one response and cover the introductory concepts thoroughly. Here’s Chapter 1: --- # Chapter 1: Introduction to Digital Editions Welcome to the world of digital editions! In this chapter, we’ll explore what digital editions are, why they’re valuable, and what you’ll need to build one. By the end of this chapter, you’ll have a clear understanding of the journey ahead and be ready to dive into the technical details in the next chapter. ## What is a Digital Edition? A digital edition is an online version of a text that allows users to interact with and explore the content in ways that go beyond traditional print. These editions often include features like: - Searchable Text: The entire text can be easily searched, which is perfect for research or close reading. - Hyperlinked Content: Key terms, annotations, and references can be linked to additional information, allowing for deeper understanding and contextual insights. - Multimedia Elements: Images, audio, and video can be integrated to enhance the reader’s experience. - Interactive Components: Hovering or clicking on terms may reveal definitions, translations, or contextual explanations. Digital editions can be valuable tools for scholars, educators, students, and anyone interested in a more engaging way to explore texts. ## What Will We Build? In this book, you’ll learn how to build a four-frame digital edition that allows users to interact with a text through clickable and hoverable terms. Here’s what the final product will look like: - Upper Left Frame: Displays the original Latin text. - Upper Right Frame: Contains the English translation. - Lower Left Frame: Shows grammatical information for each hyperlinked term when hovered over or clicked. - Lower Right Frame: Displays philosophical context for terms, also triggered by hovering or clicking. This setup provides readers with a comprehensive way to study the text with easy access to explanations and background information. ## Why Build Digital Editions? Digital editions offer several unique advantages: - Enhanced Accessibility: Readers can interact with the text directly, accessing definitions and explanations without needing to flip through multiple pages or reference materials. - Deeper Engagement: The ability to explore translations, annotations, and multimedia elements fosters a more immersive reading experience. - Versatility: Digital editions can be customized to meet the needs of diverse audiences, from casual readers to scholars. By creating your own digital edition, you’ll gain valuable skills in web development, HTML, CSS, and JavaScript—all while deepening your understanding of your chosen text. ## Tools and Technologies You’ll Need Creating a digital edition requires a basic understanding of web technologies. Here are the tools and resources we’ll use: - Text Editor: You’ll need a text editor to write your code. Some popular choices are: - *VS Code*: A free, powerful editor with many helpful extensions. - *Sublime Text*: Lightweight and highly customizable, with a range of useful features. - *Notepad++*: A simple and straightforward option, ideal for beginners. - Web Browser: You’ll need a browser to test your work. Any modern browser will work (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Edge). Browsers also offer developer tools that will help you debug your code. - Basic Understanding of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript: - *HTML* (Hypertext Markup Language): This is the foundation of web pages, used for structuring content. - *CSS* (Cascading Style Sheets): CSS controls the appearance of your web page, including layout, colors, and fonts. - *JavaScript*: JavaScript is used for interactivity, enabling features like hover effects and clickable elements. If you’re new to these technologies, don’t worry! We’ll be covering the basics along the way, and you’ll have ample opportunity to practice as you build your digital edition. ## Getting Started: Setting Up Your Workspace Before we dive into building, it’s important to set up your workspace. Follow these steps to prepare for coding: 1. Choose and Install a Text Editor: - Download and install the text editor of your choice. - Open your text editor and create a new file. Save it as index.html to set up your HTML file. 2. Create a Project Folder: - Create a new folder on your computer. This folder will hold all the files related to your digital edition, such as your HTML file and any images or additional resources you might add. 3. Open Your HTML File in Your Browser: - After saving your index.html file, open it with your web browser to view your progress. - As you work on your project, you’ll be able to refresh this browser window to see updates in real-time. 4. Set Up a Folder for Your Project: - In your project folder, create subfolders for assets like images and stylesheets. This will help keep your project organized as it grows. ## What’s Next? In the upcoming chapters, we’ll dive into the code that will bring your digital edition to life. We’ll start with setting up the basic HTML structure of your page, and then layer on CSS for styling and JavaScript for interactivity. Creating a digital edition can seem like a big task, but by breaking it down into manageable steps, you’ll find it’s both rewarding and achievable. Take it slow, practice each step, and don’t hesitate to experiment with your own ideas as you go along. By the end, you’ll have a valuable resource to share and a deeper understanding of how digital texts come together. --- This chapter provides a foundation for understanding digital editions, explains the tools you’ll need, and prepares you to start building in the next chapter. Are you ready to dive into HTML? Let’s move to Chapter 2 and start coding!

ChatGPT
Certainly! Let’s move on to Chapter 2, where we'll begin writing the HTML structure for your digital edition. --- # Chapter 2: Building the Basic HTML Structure In this chapter, you’ll learn how to create the fundamental structure of your digital edition using HTML. This structure will define the layout of your four frames and prepare your project for styling and interactivity in later chapters. ## What is HTML? HTML, or Hypertext Markup Language, is the standard language used to create web pages. It provides the basic framework of a website, which is then enhanced with CSS and JavaScript. HTML uses *tags* to define different types of content, like paragraphs, headings, and links. Let’s break down how we’ll use HTML to create our digital edition. ## Setting Up the HTML Document Every HTML file begins with a doctype declaration and an HTML tag that wraps around all other content. We’ll include some other foundational tags as well: - <html>: The root element of the page. - <head>: Contains meta-information, like the page title and links to external resources. - <body>: Contains the actual content displayed on the webpage. ### Step-by-Step Guide to Setting Up the HTML Document 1. Open your text editor and create a new file. Save it as index.html in your project folder. 2. Add the basic HTML structure using the code below: 
   <!DOCTYPE html>
   <html lang="en">
   <head>
       <meta charset="UTF-8">
       <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
       <title>Pico della Mirandola: Digital Edition</title>
   </head>
   <body>
       <!-- Content will go here -->
   </body>
   </html>
- The <meta charset="UTF-8"> tag ensures that your document uses the UTF-8 character set, which supports most characters, including special symbols. - The <meta name="viewport" tag ensures the website displays correctly on different devices by setting the width to match the screen size. - The <title> tag specifies the text that will appear in the browser tab. ## Creating the Frame Layout Next, we’ll set up the structure for your four frames. We’ll divide the page into a two-by-two grid: two frames on the top (Latin text and English translation) and two frames on the bottom (Grammatical context and Philosophical context). ### Step-by-Step Guide to Creating Frames 1. Inside the <body> tag, add four <div> elements, each with a unique id. These ids will help us style and control the frames with CSS and JavaScript in later chapters. 
   <body>
       <div id="latin-text" class="frame">
           <!-- Latin text will go here -->
       </div>
       <div id="english-text" class="frame">
           <!-- English translation will go here -->
       </div>
       <div id="grammar-context" class="frame">
           <!-- Grammar context will go here -->
       </div>
       <div id="philosophy-context" class="frame">
           <!-- Philosophical context will go here -->
       </div>
   </body>
Here, each <div> represents one of the frames in your digital edition. Let’s break down the ids: - latin-text: Will hold the Latin version of the text. - english-text: Will contain the English translation. - grammar-context: Will display grammatical information. - philosophy-context: Will show philosophical context. 2. Add placeholder text inside each <div> to see how the frames look when you load the file in your browser. Replace the comments (<!-- ... -->) with placeholder text, like this: 
   <div id="latin-text" class="frame">
       <p>Placeholder for Latin text</p>
   </div>
   <div id="english-text" class="frame">
       <p>Placeholder for English translation</p>
   </div>
   <div id="grammar-context" class="frame">
       <p>Placeholder for grammar context</p>
   </div>
   <div id="philosophy-context" class="frame">
       <p>Placeholder for philosophical context</p>
   </div>
3. Save your file and open it in a web browser. You should see four sections with placeholder text. At this stage, they may not look like distinct frames yet, but we’ll add styling in the next chapter to make them visually distinct. ## Next Steps Congratulations! You’ve successfully set up the HTML structure of your digital edition. Right now, each frame is a simple box with placeholder text. In the next chapter, we’ll add CSS to style these frames, positioning them side by side and giving them a more polished look. By the end of Chapter 3, you’ll be able to view the frames as they’re meant to be seen, neatly arranged in a grid. You’re well on your way to building a fully interactive digital edition! --- That wraps up Chapter 2. Let’s dive into Chapter 3 next, where we’ll bring this structure to life with CSS!
